story:
Our Story

Our Christmas is the story of the way many American-Latinos celebrate the holidays. Our Christmas is a story of a new Urban-Latino culture filled with old traditions and new unconventional traditions, music, and dance. Our Christmas is a story of love, family, friends, good times, bad times, hope, laughter...and coquito!  



The Impact

We want to educate others about a rich culture that exists but is rarely recognized in today's world. America is the melting pot, where thousands of cultures meet and live in one place. America has a huge Latino population. This Latino population is vast and is very diverse with backgrounds and origins from all over the world. What many people do not think about is how those who have immigrated to this country now have given birth to second, third, and even fourth generations. A new culture has emerged! An American-Latino culture that mixes old traditions and American custom. This new culture has a lot more impact then it is given granted for. This Urban-Latino American culture is a movement that is slowly AND surely progressing. Ever heard of In The Heights ?! Thus, we want to be a part of this movement to highlight our beautiful culture. What better way to do it than to highlight it on one of the most wonderful times of the year?


What We Need & What You Get

We need money for production costs: Music/Musicians, Rehearsal Space, Props, Decorations, Lights, Mics, Costumes, Instruments, and Promotional Materials (flyers, postcards, etc.) and the performance space. Your contribution will help keep important independent productions such as these become a reality. By donating you will help to tell a great story of an underrepresented population in the arts but a prevalent one! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and get involved in the Urban-Latino American Culture movement! If you would like to assist us by providing a means for production, i.e. donate rehearsal space, an instrument, etc. please contact us at ourchristmas10@gmail.com! THANK YOU!

story:
What is "Penelope"?
 
"Penelope" is a truly original adaptation of James Joyce's "Ulysses" brought to life by three young women from Los Angeles. They perform Joyce's text verbatim, exploring his idea of the female mind, and challenging historical roles of sexuality.
 
We need your help to produce "Penelope" for it's global debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival!
 
Our goal is $5156 - that's $1 for every mile from LA to Edinburgh.
 
Here is a portion of the expenses to take "Penelope" to Scotland:
-$450 Fringe Registration
-$1358 Venue Rental (theSpace)
-$120 Venue Insurance
-$5600 Plane tickets from LA to Edinburgh for 4 people
-$1840 Lodging
-Plus food, marketing materials, etc.
 
We have really unique and exciting prizes!
-Private Yoga and Martial Arts
-Postcard updates sent by the cast from Edinburgh
-Personalized media/video shout outs
-Baked goods
-And more
 
Your contribution will truly make a difference. Performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is a performer's dream. We hope you believe in this project and can help us share it around the world.
 
Here are some other ways you can help:
-Forward this campaign to your family and friends 
-Create hype for our campaign by sharing on Facebook, Twitter and other social networks 
-Attend our show in LA at the Doghouse Theatre this July

story:
A Bit About Us

Hello!

We are Raving Mask Theatre, a student-led theatre company based in Durham, England. We are associated with Durham Student Theatre and Durham University. We have put on a number of successful and award-winning shows, but going to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival would surpass all of our past achievements!  

Our show, 'The Noctambulist' is a new and exciting piece of writing that has already had a successful run in Durham, but we need your help to make it a success in Edinburgh. We have already secured an excellent venue (which you can check out here: https://www.paradise-green.co.uk/companies/venues-spaces/paradise-in-the-vault/the-vault/) but we need another £600 to maximise the potential of our show. Anything at all that you can donate will directly influence the success of our show, and would be enormously appreciated by all of the cast and crew.

A Bit About the Show

'The Noctambulist' is a comedy-drama. Albert is a layabout waster scrounging off his friends. By day he does nothing but sit around, thinking up ideas of how he can change the world - at night he sleepwalks. Then a girl appears at the door with a delivery of fruit and veg, offering salvation and pomegranates. 

After a successful run in Durham in February, the show was described by drama website First Night as 'Truly outstanding' (https://community.dur.ac.uk/dst/firstnight/review.php?review=203) and won awards at the Durham Drama Festival for Best New Writing, Best Supporting Actress and Best Actor.

Donating

Money that you donate will help us specifically in three areas: publicity, set and props.

Publicity: Flyering on the Royal Mile can create great exposure for any show, but in order to do this we want to ensure that we have the best possible posters and flyers that we can afford! This will really make a difference to the number of audience members that come and see us. We also plan on doing some publicity stunts as well, so your money will of go towards buying props for these events too.

Set: It's so easy to ruin the charm of any show if the set appears shoddy and half-finished. Trying to create a realistic, small, domestic space is not as easy as it sounds, and so the money that you donate will be directed towards ensuring that we can create as realistic a setting as possible.

Props: The show is full of food and drink: from beer to tea, from biscuits to fruit, it all adds up financially. Part of the charm of the show is being immersed in the characters' living space, as we watch them eat and drink and go about the small and often comic details of their lives. So anything that you can donate would really help us achieve this image.

As you can see on this page, we will be offering some lighthearted perks as a thanks for your donations. Please do get involved, we promise that they won't be a disappointment!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We appreciate that these are tough times and that not everyone has money to hand. But you can help us even if you can't donate by telling your family, friends and work colleagues about our show and linking them to this page.

    And of course, if you really want to support us, there's no better way to do it than by coming to see us in Edinburgh, where we will be performing from the 2nd August until the 17th August. Details about our show times and ticket prices can be found here: https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/noctambulist.

    Thank You for Your Support

    We have worked extremely hard to get to this point, and we are proud of our achievements. But to realise our dream we are now dependent on your support! Thank you for reading, we would love to see you all in Edinburgh!


    Raving Mask Theatre

story:
About Us

Truck Bed Productions was founded in 2012 by HSPVA theatre students. Our name was created after the first show, when everything we needed to perform could fit comfortably in a truck bed. We joined together to create a space for original and risky new plays in Houston- on a student budget. Our mission states: “while some theatre uses the latest lighting equipment and top-dollar sets, theatre is about the story. A fantastic story can be told anywhere.”

We think theatre should give you a perspective you've never seen before. We think theatre should be as fun as a concert. We think theatre should be not just be live, but alive. We are a local theatre company devoted to the promotion of new theatrical works by any means necessary. Join our community for a night.

Summer 2014 Goal 

This summer, we have partnered with The Orange Show to produce two new original plays, an event titled: “Nothing in Nowhere: A Grand Flea Circus.” The cost for renting the space is $1000 for both nights, and the extra $200 covers the cost for live music and post-show refreshments.

About the Shows

This Gun Can’t is a world premiere by company founder and Fordham University Playwriting student, Keenan Hurley.This Gun Can’t takes place over the course of one Halloween evening at the Great Georgia Circus. The play explores the relationship between two burnt out security guards and a young tightrope walker; throughout the night, all masks come off as these three wanderers dream of escaping the cages they've built for themselves. Cast members include Elizabeth Martinsen, Roby Attal, and Mateo Mpinduzi-Mott. Director is Cecelia White.

In our most ambitious project yet, we are also presenting Enough Sweat to Float a Canoe, an original short play inspired by the spirit of Houston folk art legend and The Orange Show creator, Jeff McKissack. This is a one-man show starring Wesley Whitson, written by the ensemble and directed by Keenan Hurley.

story:
•  ANY AMOUNT WILL BE APPRECIATED!!!  
  •  We have Only 2 Days Left to Raise more than $4000 toward our GOAL!
  • Thanks to My Many Friends in Williston North Dakota, who have given more than $750 to FACT directly which is NOT shown on this campaign!
  • Please, even $5 to $10 will be greatly accepted & appreciated. Of course larger amounts are Accepted.
 Won't YOU Help Me Put My Heartfelt & Fun Memories                                          of Growing Up In Texas ON STAGE?
 After 50 Years as a JACK-Of-All-Theatrical Trades, I am CELEBRATING 50 Years in the Professional Theatre --- and I cannot Imagine anything BETTER than seeing this comedy-drama "MY DADDY Was The Biggest STAGEMOTHER in TEXAS!" Come to LIFE again Off Broadway.
  SOLD OUT Performances greeted my Play which most likely could be the most FAVORITE I've ever written.  First seen at The DUPLEX in NYCs West Village and then the 2004 NY International FRINGE Festival with my friend, the late-Ron Pallilo (Welcome Back Kotter). Both productions were greeted with Praise and Smiles!
“Daddy Is A Saucy Beaute!” ---The Village Voice

“Effectivelybalances dual missions of having fun and telling a
troubling story.” --- Curtain Up, New York

“Moving, Heartfelt like a William Inge script.” ---TalkinBroadway.com

What We Need So We Can Bring It Back to NYC

$7500 to Guarantee we can get the Production Up & Running for at least a 5 Week, 15 Performance presentation in March 2015. 

OUR COSTS

THEATRE Rental (3 Performances per week), BOX OFFICE Staff, Lightning Rental, Dressing Room, Public Lobby Rental, Costumes, Set-Props, Insurance and Actor Salaries. Plus NY Advertising (It ain't cheap!)

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize, some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean YOU can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!!!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Invite your FACEBOOK friends to Take a look at our Campaign.

And that's all there is to it except please Link Your Friends to our Campaign.

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bring-my-daddy-to-off-broadway-nyc/x/6782234

story:
How all started

We started raising small, non-commercial meets in Hanover City, on public places. From all over the republic they came together to dance with us. 2011 was the first setback: we wanted to arrange the meet with the permission of the government. The bureaucracy failed, the place we were looking for, was owned partly by the town itself and a land agency. But we didn't want to cancel the event, as hundreds have already submitted vacations for that day. I wrote a letter to the major, nevertheless we arranged the event at the next day. The people came to dance and listen to the music, so the police did and closed it. The letter to the major made an impact. The next year we sat together in the town hall, discussed and got a place to dance and play music! A committee for youth in public subsidized fruits, water and the equipment rental. You can see how it all passed off on our YouTube Channel.

2014 – the next set back.

Except a bar forced us to lower the music in 2012, till 2013 it all went great. But the place we switched to 2013 interferes now with a construction site. It's growing and growing and growing. So we changed the location to the other side of the place in 2014, closer to the power and more place – we thought it…

The day started with police and ended the same. At the parking area, next to the place was mart - as every saturday (why didn't we recognized it last year? Anyway...). Our tends obstructed the approach from the pedestrian area to the parking area - so the head of the mart said (seems logic - a approach from a pedestrian area). After an hour of nonsense talking with him, he accepted, that every market stall can use the normal approaches - no one of them had a problem with it, reluctantly. We started half an hour later than planned. But the next problem wasn't far away. The buildings were all old, the windows too, so they didn't absorb any sound. A resident complained about the loudness, so we had to dramatically decrease it. Few minutes before the end a police car joined us – tired officers, just asking when the event will close as another complain reached them. We told them that there are just two more songs, they nodded, sat back into the car and snoozed till it was quiet.

What's now?

The place gets more and more unattractive, but the floor is still one of the best in that dimension in the city. We haven't got that much options left, so we need your help.

There is a nice place, covered by a big roof at and fast reachable from the main station at the fairgrounds, where 2000 the Expo took place. But it's owned by the fair agency, so we can't get it as cheap as places owned by the town itself. We will lose the electric power box - sponsored by a company which raises "skate by night", a skate through the whole city allover the roads - as well. We have sponsored the event the last years from our private money. It was already a three-digit amount, but now grows up to an amount with a digit more. But if we all invest small amounts, in sum it will be enough to do it once more!

Support is all we need

If you like our event, but can't donate, we'll be pleased if you spread the love by sharing! If you have some ideas that could help us, don't hesitate to text us! Just add a comment or write us at indiegogo@rvltn.net

story:
"Censored on Final Approach" - Infinite Variety Productions' New Play coming to two cities!

IVP  is a not-for-profit theatre company dedicated to telling the unknown stories from women's history - herstory. Censored on Final Approach by Phylis Ravel tells the true story of the WASP (Women Air Force Service Pilots). Over a thousand women were trained and tested to serve in World War II, flying and transporting cargo, simulating strafing missions, and providing tow target artillery practice (meaning they flew the planes and pilots from another plane shot at their tail for target practice). 

Thirty-eight WASP fliers lost their lives while serving during the war, eleven in training and twenty-seven on active duty. Because they were not considered military under the existing guidelines, a fallen WASP was sent home at family expense without traditional military honors or note of heroism. The army would not even allow the U.S. flag to be placed on the coffin of the fallen WASP. It took over 30 years for these women to gain military status. Still, most people do not know of their courageous act.

We hope to change that. 

We have done it before! 

Our first production, A Piece of My Heart by Shirley Lauro, started in a small NYC theater, and it has since traveled around the country for almost three years--from high schools and colleges to VA Centers all over the US.  A Piece of My Heart tells the story of the women who served in Vietnam during the war in the military and as nurses, USO performers, and Red Cross volunteers.

Now we want to tell the story of the Women Air Force Service Pilots.  

We are planning two major runs of Censored on Final Approach.  Our first will run in NYC from August 18th through August 26th at The Gym at Judson Memorial Church.  The second will run free performances for all Veteran's at the Women In Military Service for America Memorial in Arlington, VA from November 1st through November 11th, with a special closing night in honor of Veteran's Day.

We hope that by providing free admission in Arlington, we can reach a wider audience, thereby further promulgating the legacy of the WASP.  But it's an expensive endeavor.

With your help, we can bring to life the incredible story of the WASP, and keep their legacy alive for generations to come. 

Our projected budget for August at The Gym: $6,300

We have been offered discounted theater space at The Judson Memorial Church this August. But we need a bit more money to transform the space. From authentic costumes, to powerful lights and crafty projections, IVP will bring you a night you won't forget, a night that brings you all the way back to the 1940's.

Space Rental: $1,200

Rights to the play: $300

Costumes: $900

Set/Props/Lights: $3,000

Stipends for Light, Sound, Projection, Costume and Set Designers: $750

Stipend for Stage Manager: $150

Our projected budget for November in Arlington: $13,700

Our gracious hosts at the Women in Military Service for America Memorial have offered to provide housing and metro transportation for our cast and crew.  However, to keep these performances free to the public, we need your help to afford the following:

Stipends for Actors, Stage Manager, and Director: $5,000

Meals: $3,600

Round-trip transportation to Arlington: $100

Advertising and Marketing: $3,500

Rights to the play: $1,000

Shipping set and props round-trip: $500

Opening on August 18th, the day before National Aviation Day, we hope to use our show to honor the many women, past and present, who gave their lives to fly for our country. Your help will make this possible. 

Thank you!

Censored on Final Approach by Phylis Ravel tells the true story of the WASP (Women Air Force Service Pilots). Over a thousand women were trained and tested to serve in World War II, flying and transporting cargo, simulating strafing missions, and providing tow target artillery practice (meaning they flew the planes and pilots from another plane shot at their tail for target practice). Thirty-eight WASP fliers lost their lives while serving during the war, eleven in training and twenty-seven on active duty. Because they were not considered military under the existing guidelines, a fallen WASP was sent home at family expense without traditional military honors or note of heroism. The army would not even allow the U.S. flag to be placed on the coffin of the fallen WASP. It took over 30 years for these women to gain military status. Still, most people do not know of their courageous act.We hope to change that. We have done it before! Our first production, A Piece of My Heart by Shirley Lauro, started in a small NYC theater, and it has since traveled around the country for almost three years--from high schools and colleges to VA Centers all over the US.  A Piece of My Heart tells the story of the women who served in Vietnam during the war in the military and as nurses, USO performers, and Red Cross volunteers.Now we want to tell the story of the Women Air Force Service Pilots.  We are planning two major runs of Censored on Final Approach.  Our first will run in NYC from August 18th through August 26th at The Gym at Judson Memorial Church.  The second will run free performances for all Veteran's at the Women In Military Service for America Memorial in Arlington, VA from November 1st through November 11th, with a special closing night in honor of Veteran's Day. We hope that by providing free admission in Arlington, we can reach a wider audience, thereby further promulgating the legacy of the WASP.  But it's an expensive endeavor. With your help, we can bring to life the incredible story of the WASP, and keep their legacy alive for generations to come. Our projected budget for August at The Gym: $6,300We have been offered discounted theater space at The Judson Memorial 
Church this August. But we need a bit more money to transform the space. From authentic costumes, to powerful lights and crafty 
projections, IVP will bring you a night you won't forget, a night that 
brings you all the way back to the 1940's.Space Rental: $1,200Rights to the play: $300Costumes: $900Set/Props/Lights: $3,000Stipends for Light, Sound, Projection, Costume and Set Designers: $750Stipend for Stage Manager: $150Our projected budget for November in Arlington: $13,700Our gracious hosts at the Women in Military Service for America Memorial have offered to provide housing and metro transportation for our cast and crew.  However, to keep these performances free to the public, we need your help to afford the following:Stipends for Actors, Stage Manager, and Director: $5,000Meals: $3,600Round-trip transportation to Arlington: $100Advertising and Marketing: $3,500Rights to the play: $1,000Shipping set and props round-trip: $500Opening on August 18th, the day before National Aviation Day, we hope to use our show to honor the many women, past and present, who gave their lives to fly for our country. Your help will make this possible.  Thank you!

story:
IN A NUTSHELL

This campaign will raise the funds for 3Girls Theatre Company to produce a FREE Summer Festival July 7-13, 2014, at Thick House in San Francisco. 3GT is the San Francisco theatre company that puts women's work onstage where it belongs, and this festival brings women-driven theatre FREE to anyone who would like to attend.


HOW YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP

Your contribution, large or small, will fund the basics: space rental at Thick House, 1695 18th St, San Francisco, paying stipends to our artists, and helping us spread the word to bring audiences to the theatre. Your support makes our Summer Festival happen!

We're trying to reach our goal by JUNE 28, 2014, with a "stretch" to July 3.


ABOUT 3GIRLS THEATRE

Founded in 2011, 3Girls Theatre's mission is to put women's work on the stage where it belongs. Because the number of women's plays being produced nationwide is so dismally small, 3Girls has made it a priority ... in fact, women's work is the ONLY work we produce.

Since its inception three years ago, 3Girls Theatre has produced five full productions and nearly 20 readings of new works by women playwrights, composers and lyricists ... all to acclaim by critics and audiences alike.

3Girls is a San Francisco-based, 501(c) 3 organization, and your donation is fully tax deductible. 3Girls strongly believes in the power of community, which is why we use a crowd-funding source like Indiegogo.


OUR SUMMER FESTIVAL: ZOWEE!

We have a terrific week-long line-up of entertainment, readings, art, and more:

  • A "play-off" of readings of three new plays, one of which will be selected for production by 3GT in 2015. Enjoy The Anniversary Effect, by AJ Baker, Monday, July 7, Moments of Truth, a musical by Caroline Altman and Patricia Milton Wednesday, July 9, and Henrietta English, by Lee Brady, Thursday, July 10. All readings take place at 7:30 p.m.
  • Critics and Playwrights - we're all in this together: A frank and engaging panel discussion about reviewing new works, with three distinguished local theatre critics: Robert Hurwitt of the SF Chronicle, Jean Schiffman of the SF Examiner, and Lily Janiak of the SF Weekly. This not-to-be-missed panel will take place Tuesday, July 8 at 7:30 p.m.
  • LezWrites! An evening of readings of short plays and solo performance pieces by San Francisco Bay Area lesbian writers, curated by Margery Kreitman. Friday, July 11, 7:30 p.m.
  • Women Veterans: an art exhibit featuring works by women veterans.
  • Low Hanging Fruit, a new play by Robin Bradford that focuses on the plight of homeless women veterans, will have two readings: Saturday, July 12 at 8 pm and Sunday, July 13 at 2 p.m. Join us for a reading, reception, and audience discussion about the issues raised by the play, in collaboration with Swords to Plowshares.

All events take place at Thick House, 1695 18th St, San Francisco, CA 94107.


A FREE AND OPEN FESTIVAL

As you may know, we usually rely on ticket sales or membership as the primary source of revenue to fund our events. But we want to ensure that as many people as possible can access our work this summer - so we are not charging admission for any of our events. We don't receive any other grant or subsidy to produce the festival, and we're not charging for attendance ... which means your donations are the exclusive way we can MAKE IT HAPPEN.


WHAT YOUR DONATION MEANS

3Girls Theatre is the little company that could! We have been very successful in producing women's work, AND we have also benefited from very generous donations. Because of our success, we have been steadily building community. Now it's time to expand our base and bring women's challenging, exciting work to new audiences ... all without charge. YOU are the key to our success!


OTHER WAYS TO HELP

You may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Volunteer to help out at any one of our events.
  • Tell your friends, and help spread the word.
  • Use those Indiegogo share tools to send a shout-out about our campaign!

story:
Ariel Rivka Dance's 8th Season

ARD IS ON A HUGE MOMENTUM SWING and this is your chance to BE A PART OF an exciting time for our growing dance company! The upcoming Festival Showcase of ARD, includes exciting collaborators and partners as our newly expanded company of 7 fantastic dancers (and 3 apprentices) performs at New York Live Arts May 28-30th, 2015.

We are presenting our new work Ori, set to 4 live cellos and danced by 7 incredible  dancers. We are beyond proud to be working in collaboration with acclaimed choreographers Carolyn Dorfman (who will be presenting two works) and Sean Curran (who is setting/creating two works on ARD dancers), and soloists Paul Dennis (formerly of Jose Limón Dance Company) and Carrie Ellmore-Tallitsch (Martha Graham Dance Company).

This showcase of amazing talents brings together a wide spectrum of dance. THERE IS SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE! This festival presents ARD at an incredible new venue (NYLA) and builds from the success of our 2014 season, the premiere of The Book of Esther which brought over 650 audience members at Alvin Ailey, and toured to Philly and around NYC.

  • Tickets available now!

Please Help Our Dance Company Grow

  • Our budget is $50,000, we've raised $43,000.
  • The support will help our Dancers, Musicians, and Designers receive fees closer to what they deserve for all their hard work.
  • ARD is fiscally sponsored by the Live Arts Collaboration, so all donations are tax-deductible and will be used to support this production!
  • Spread the word and send everyone to Ariel Rivka Dance to buy tickets!

Who Cares about Dance?

It turns out a lot of people do!  We've gone from 4 (thanks to our moms and dads)

to more than 145 supporters and in just three years, our audience has grown from 200 to 650 per season.

  • Live music and a wide array of work gives you a chance to see many sides of modern dance.
  • You'll be able to view the work online.  If you donate $50 or $100 receive CDs of David's work and/or a T-Shirt...
  • Bring a Friend to see the show!

About the Festival and Ariel Rivka Dance:

Marking its eighth New York City season, Ariel Rivka Dance (ARD) premieres Ori, a husband-and-wife collaboration with Ariel Grossman’s hypnotic choreography and David Homan’s original music. Meaning “my light” in Hebrew, Ori manipulates fast-paced lighting shifts and their consequent shadows to create a raw, energetic performance by seven contemporary ballet dancers and four electrifying cellists.

The program continues with two pieces by one of today’s most invigorating choreographers, Sean Curran. According to The New York Times, he is a “breathtaking tour de force.” An artist with a background in Irish step dance, postmodern experiments, and Broadway hoofing, Curran is known for having the “sharp intelligence of a conceptualist and the raw physicality of an athlete” (The Boston Globe). Audiences will see two of his latest works: the world premiere of Trio set on three of ARD’s dancers and to the music of David Homan; and the U.S. premiere of Desert Dance, a reinvented work for ARD’s entire company informed by the idea of dancers slipping between the natural environment and a mystical atmosphere.

Completing its 2014-2015 Season, which featured an international tour to Sarajevo and several national performances, Carolyn Dorfman Dance brings its bold athleticism back to New York City. The company will premiere Dorfman’s newest work WAVES, a sensation-based exploration of sonic and movement possibilities that groups together real-time collaboration between live music and dance. NJArts.net described the workas, “a community that leaves no one behind.” Additionally the company will perform Interior Designs (ID), a visually stunning tour de force that incorporates a commissioned score, original video projections and video mapping and integrated lighting and costume designs. According to The Star Ledger, “Interiors Designs draw[s] everyone into its complex, digital world.”The entire theater becomes the stage as Dorfman and her collaborators create an immersive environment that reveals the internal and external worlds of both performer and spectator."

Book-ending the program are solo works performed by two extraordinary modern dancers: Carrie Ellmore-Tallitsch (Martha Graham Dance Company) and Paul Dennis (formerly of Jose Limón Dance Company). Described by Oberon’s Grove as “a solo I could easily watch and savor again and again,” Zjawa —choreographed by Katarzyna Skarpetowska for Carrie Ellmore-Tallitsch—takes audiences on a journey to the bottom of an enchanted lake inhabited by women. Following his successful tour performing solo works by iconic 20th century choreographers through Milan, Florence and the island of Trinidad, Paul Dennis, premieres the next edition, yet untitled, of his solo concert. Choreographed by Deborah Goffe with original score by Damon Honeycutt, this work is predicated on candid conversation between old friends, the search for an anchor, and the ongoing effort to reconcile inside intention with outside expectation.

story:
The Novato Theater is a cornerstone landmark of Downtown Novato - yet it has been closed for over 20 years. The classic art deco cinema has the potential to be a cultural hub for our community and provide a boost to the economic vitality of Downtown. 


We're now asking the community to help make our vision a reality.  


The "New" Novato Theater 

The renovated Theater will be designed to maintain its nostalgic art deco look, but with fresh new amenities, including a large downstairs theater with seating for 250 people, an upstairs theater with 48 removable seats, a spacious lobby for receptions and concessions, and state-of-the-art sound and visual systems.

It will serve as a community cultural center for year-round film programming, and, for the first time, live music and performing arts events, including simulcast showings of opera, dance performances, live Broadway Theater, and other musical events. 

The facility will be available to rent for community meetings, private events, and educational outreach programming.

Educational objectives of this project include student workshops that will teach Novato’s youth the arts of storytelling, playwriting, and improvisation. Adults and senior citizens can engage in the arts through many other activities, including a Film Club, festivals, and a variety of workshops.

The Novato Theater is an important link to our past and will be an integral part of our future. Novato Theater's Educational Outreach Program emphasizes excellence in film and the arts, and encourages both the young and old creatives in our community to pursue their artistic passions. 

New Leadership

Executive Director Christina Stroeh's passion for this project is inspiring.  Recently retired, with 27 years of experience as the drama and choral instructor/director at Terra Linda High School, this lifelong Novato resident brings unprecedented enthusiasm and experience to the team.  

During her career, Christina educated thousands of students on performing arts skills like leadership, set design, stage management, and production, making her the ideal leader for this campaign. With Christina leading a new, dedicated Board of Directors, and nearly half of the necessary funds already raised, we are turning to the community - both in Novato and beyond - to help us reach our goal and reopen the grand old Theater. 


A Team That Means Business

Local business and community leaders are working diligently with a comprehensive business plan to get the Theater up and running again. Collaborative efforts between municipal government, trade groups, and these local businesses have driven the project forward, resulting in donations from over 700 individuals and 70 organizations.  

With such broad support from the community already in place, we ask for your help in the final push to reopen the doors to this classic Novato monument.

Significant Funds Already Secured

The total campaign goal is $4.7 million. To date, we have raised $1.9 million, including a recent boost in fundraising with pledges of $1 million from the City of Novato and $180K from our Board of Directors.

Our existing funds include a total of $250K from the County of Marin, $110K from the Margaret E. Haas Fund, $25K from the Marin Community Foundation, and hundreds of donations from local citizens who share our vision.  

We are now launching the next phase of our capital campaign to raise the final $500,000 to start construction. While the IndieGoGo campaign will only raise a small portion of that goal, it's an opportunity for our supporters to create new conversations about the theater on social media, bring new donors into the fold, offer donor rewards, and demonstrate that even small donations can be important steps in our journey to begin construction.

Benefits to the Community

Small theaters bring both cultural and economic benefits to communities, as has been seen elsewhere in Marin County with the success of the Lark and Rafael theaters. 

We believe that reopening the Novato Theater will bring much to our hometown, from the construction phase, which will include increased spending on local wages and supplies, to the impact the reopened theater will have on local businesses, as we draw more people into our Downtown.


In particular, we believe that restaurants and bars, both on Grant Avenue and elsewhere in Novato, will experience increased business, as locals hit the town for dinner and a movie on those beautiful North Bay evenings. We look forward to bringing "date night" back to Downtown Novato. 

A Successful Campaign for Novato

The rebuilding of our beloved Novato Theater is truly a community project that will benefit all, today and for generations to come. Our theater will be a cultural, aesthetic, educational, financial, historical, and purely enjoyable venue - once we meet our goal. We can do it with your help!

story:
We acknowledge that at present we are being spare on details. It doesn't mean we don't have them. We've been exploring options for creating a new theatrical performance venue on a few different scales. The most basic incarnation would be a black box theatre with a seating capacity of approx 60-100, and the ideas we have grow and expand from there. Let us be clear - we are not saying that our budget for the entire project is the $130,000 that we are fundraising - simply that it is what we hope to raise in addition to the capital we already have for the project. We want to create the best space that we can, and make the best investment we can, both for Workshop Theatre and the Calgary Theatre Community. The additional capital we are hoping to raise via crowd-sourcing is going to factor in to what we are able to achieve with regard to the overall project. 

We will continue to update on where we are at with things in the next few weeks, but we felt that it was important to get the ball rolling!

So...for now...those of you who aren't familiar with our history, a little backstory...We are Calgary's Longest Running Community Theatre and will be celebrating our 49th year this season. 

In the early 1940s a very talented and highly dedicated teacher taught drama in Room 14 at Western Canada High School. Her name was Betty Mitchell and her methods were avant-garde at the time. Her pupils were so inspired to continue in theatre after leaving high school that Miss Mitchell constituted an amateur theatre company. This was the birth of Workshop 14. From 1959 through 1965 Workshop 14 thrived. It later amalgamated with the Musicians and Actors Club, housed in the old Isis Movie House, across the railway tracks on First Street S.W., and became Mac 14. 
By the end of the 1960's Theatre Calgary emerged from Mac 14 and it was felt that a community theatre arm should continue in the footsteps of what had been a noble element in Calgary's theatre scene. Workshop Theatre was formed and mounted its first season in 1969-1970. 
Workshop Theatre is Calgary's longest running community theatre organization. This volunteer-operated organization performs four main stage productions during the year, all at Pumphouse Theatre. Workshop Theatre produces some of the best community theatre in Calgary with past and present hits from New York, London and Canadian stages, as well as new works by local playwrights using non-equity performers and backstage crews from the Calgary area. 
Workshop Theatre is committed to providing local theatre enthusiasts an opportunity to develop and master their performance and stagecraft skills.

We will continue to update on where we are at with things in the next few weeks, but we felt that it was important to get the ball rolling!
So...for now...those of you who aren't familiar with our history, a little backstory...We are Calgary's Longest Running Community Theatre and will be celebrating our 49th year this season. 
In the early 1940s a very talented and highly dedicated teacher taught drama in Room 14 at Western Canada High School. Her name was Betty Mitchell and her methods were avant-garde at the time. Her pupils were so inspired to continue in theatre after leaving high school that Miss Mitchell constituted an amateur theatre company. This was the birth of Workshop 14. From 1959 through 1965 Workshop 14 thrived. It later amalgamated with the Musicians and Actors Club, housed in the old Isis Movie House, across the railway tracks on First Street S.W., and became Mac 14. By the end of the 1960's Theatre Calgary emerged from Mac 14 and it was felt that a community theatre arm should continue in the footsteps of what had been a noble element in Calgary's theatre scene. Workshop Theatre was formed and mounted its first season in 1969-1970. Workshop Theatre is Calgary's longest running community theatre organization. This volunteer-operated organization performs four main stage productions during the year, all at Pumphouse Theatre. Workshop Theatre produces some of the best community theatre in Calgary with past and present hits from New York, London and Canadian stages, as well as new works by local playwrights using non-equity performers and backstage crews from the Calgary area. Workshop Theatre is committed to providing local theatre enthusiasts an opportunity to develop and master their performance and stagecraft skills.

story:
On Wednesday, January 25th, Columbia School of the Arts MFA Program will present the opening night of CAMINO REAL at the Connelly Theater in the Lower East Side, a production we’ve been working steadily on since July of last year. This is Matt Trucano's graduate thesis show under the tutelage of Anne Bogart and Cary Bland Simpson's New York producing debut; we have a cast of highly talented, lyrical actors and a production team of amazing designers and technical personnel. 

As of right now, we’re $500 below our fundraising mark and need help to push through. Our designers are savvy people who have spun gold out of pennies but we need help to finish funding the physical production elements and make sure everything is 110% pure glitter for opening night.

Matt and Cary agree that CAMINO REAL is both necessary and timely right now as Tennessee Williams was not only a larger-than-life playwright but also a gay man struggling in a time that rejected “alternative lifestyles.” The show is a phantamasgoric tale of rich and poor, outsiders and excluders, love and death, politics and morals, and all things in-between - we wish there was an easy plot synopsis, but alas…it’s better seen than explained! In this era of exclusionary politics and harmful emotion running high, there's no better time to turn to the theatre. 

Your donation would mean the world to help us make the show as good as it can be!

Thank you,

The Camino Real Team xo

 

ABOUT THE DIRECTOR: Matt Trucano directs plays, musicals, and operas in order that he might foster a greater sense of the human capacity for inner empowerment and outward tenderness. Born and raised in Deadwood, South Dakota, he was co-founding artistic director of Chicago-based company, The Bricklayers (2007-2014), whose productions included Mother Courage and Her Children, Twelfth Night: Galaxy 4.2, and Don Juan in Vegas, all of which toured the Midwest, as well as Ship of Fools, created with fifty actors with and without disabilities in Minneapolis. Additional directing credits include: Tartuffe, The Cherry Orchard, The Maids, Pump Boys and Dinettes, and new plays The Glass Piano and The Wedding Party.

story:
THE SHOW

 

Over the course of LOOM stories are shaped and re-shaped as six women weave an original tapestry on a floating, circular frame.

LOOM is a show unlike any other we’ve produced, or even seen before. Performed against a backdrop of an original weaving being created in real time onstage, we also aim to keep blurring the boundary of theater and contemporary circus, all while examining modern day feminist issues through a lens of mythology.

What does it mean to choose between your nature and your family? What compassion can we find for those who’ve committed the most cardinal of female crimes? And what does it signify when a woman uses her body in the pursuit of power? These are a few of the questions that we’ll pose—to the audience, and to ourselves.

LOOM is presented in collaboration with Air Temple Arts, Connecticut’s premiere circus and aerial arts training facility. It will premiere in Northampton, MA and New Haven, CT in June 2019.

 

THE TEAM

 

LOOM features a female fronted cast, most of whom are coaches at Air Temple Arts. They are Casey (single point trapeze), Cole (aerial hoop), Jill (aerial sling, pas de deux), Lauren (corde lisse), Stacey (aerial silks), Sylvie (cloud swing).

 

THE FUNDS

 

To produce LOOM we’re trying to raise a minimum of $4,200. It’s a lot to ask, but that money only covers our theater rentals, and some of our promotional materials. We have a great track record of sold out shows, and are planning to do well in ticket sales to cover other costs but theaters require up-front deposits and the money from tickets won’t be available until the show is over!

 

If we can exceed our initial goal, we can start to cover the cost of costumes, props, and paying our performers. The unfortunate reality is that shows like this are often by default a labor of love—trading the opportunity to perform original art, with the ability to get paid for it.

No amount we raise would pay each of our performers a fair working wage for the countless hours they’ve put in, but any little bit would be appreciated beyond words!

 

WHAT’S THERE TO LOSE?

 

Honestly? Mostly sleep.

 

It’s hitting the stage in June whether or not we reach our funding goal. We’ve already put too much into this show not to see it through—whether that means we sleep in the next few months or not—but we hope you’ll help us bring LOOM to the stage well rested!

 

Stacey has produced eight professional shows before, and two crowdfunding campaigns, all of which have been highly successful. We have a great community behind us, and chances are, if you’re reading this, you’re part of that community).

 

THE REWARDS

 

We have plenty of great rewards* for you, to tangibly show our appreciation for your assistance in making LOOM a reality!

 

We have LOOM branded tops for all genders both cozy and breezy, a mythologically themed photo shoot complete with snacks and drinks, adult circus day camp and rehearsal sneak peeks (complete with snacks, are you sensing a theme?), digital downloads of the show, and the Song of Eurydice – the original poetry of the show (plus some new, book-only poems), detailing Eurydice’s story in her own words, in a limited edition book, signed by the cast.

 

Too many great rewards to choose from? We know! Several options will let you combo your favorites.

 

*Our eternal gratitude and a giant hug is included with all contributions, regardless of size.

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

 

Want to help but short on change? Boy do we get it. You can help by sharing our campaign, and the show, on social media; telling your friends and family how great we are; and of course, coming to see the show in June!

 

Sharing the campaign is easier than ever, just use the Indiegogo share tools below!

story:
About the play:

Jane is not okay. She's a promising poet without a muse, a single mother without lessons to pass along. Her dating life's a shambles, and her “helpful” friends are only helping make things more complicated. “This” by Vancouver born, “House of Cards” show runner, Melissa James Gibson is a bright, witty, un-romantic comedy that follows the uncertain steps of a circle of friends navigating the unfamiliar challenges of middle age.

We expect most of you will laugh, some of you may cry, and all of you will be entertained.

Who are we?

Kindred Entertainment’s mandate is to bring professional, high quality, entertaining theatre to the people of Vancouver. Some of our previously produced, critically acclaimed, shows include ‘White Hot’ and ‘Either We talk or We Don’t talk’.

Our team is made up entirely of theatre professionals, working for reduced rates or donating their time, in the effort to bring great theatre experiences to Vancouver. But it’s only through your donations that we can make that possible. As with many independent theatre groups, we are not able to pay our bills on ticket sales alone. Your support is ESSENTIAL to the financial success of our shows.

Kindred Entertainment is Vancouver owned, operated and independently funded. We do not receive any grants or bursaries. Any profit we make after covering our expenses is shared amongst the cast, director and production team.

What we need:

We have set our goal at $15,000 because that is about half the budget that we’ll require to deliver a quality theatrical experience for our Vancouver audiences, and ensure that the integrity of the play remains intact. Funding raised for this project will go towards all expenses incurred to produce this play including but not limited to: play performance rights (paid to the author), the cost of the venue, props, set materials, costumes, insurance, publicity materials, payment of actors and production team etc.

What You’ll Receive:

Due to it’s very limited run (10 public performances only), and from our experience in producing previous shows we anticipate this run will sell out, so all of our supporters who donate $25 or more will receive at least one ticket to the show (see perks for more specific details). Most of our perks come with a glass (or a bottle) of wine or drink of your choice and some include dinner at our partner’s restaurant to ensure you’re able to make the most of your evening. There are also opportunities to advertise your business or charity of choice as a part of some of our perk packages.

Thank you:

We are passionate about bringing entertaining and relevant theatre to Vancouver audiences and your support makes all the difference to us. We are solely funded by ticket sales, donations and fundraising. It’s your vital support that ensures we can continue to provide top-notch productions to the Vancouver theatre community.

Social Networking:

If you can’t contribute financially, you can still support us by spreading the word.

Word of mouth is always the best advertising so please share our info with your friends. Like us on Facebook, Follow us on twitter and Instagram. Use the hashtag’s #THISplay #kindred #kindredentertainment.. Links to our sites are at the bottom of the page.

Thank you for supporting us and the Arts in Vancouver. See you at the show!

story:
Catholic Guilt was first written and performed in the 2016 SolowFest in Philadelphia. It was remounted in the winter of 2016 as part of White Pines Productions' Bright Nights series. The third showing of Catholic Guilt will go up this coming December in Philadelphia, PA in the Calvary Center chapel space at Curio Theater Company. 

What is the show about? Catholic guilt was first written to take a look at religion and it's affect on the psyche. Religion can bring people together, and bring peace and meaning to life. It is often a huge part of one's identity. But what about the dark side of it? It can be polarizing, creating a sense of "us vs. them". Religion often drives people to act out of fear. People infused with religious dogma can become neurotic because of the fear of not being able to fulfill their religion's expectations. Kelly explores these ideas through the telling of her own personal experience.  

About the creator (Kelly not God): Kelly McCaughan is an actress, deviser, improviser, and writer in Philadelphia. She graduated from with BFA from Indiana University of Pennsylvania and has been working in Philadelphia for 7 years.  She has worked with local theater companies such as EgoPo Classic Theater, Revolution Shakespeare, Luna Theater Company, Manayunk Theater company, White Pines Productions, Philly PHIT, Walking Fish Theater, The Cabaret Administration, and Plays and Players. She was a previous ensemble member of Bright Invention with White Pines Productions as well as an ensemble member of Bye Bye Liver: The Philadelphia Drinking Play. She served as a writer and actor for her award winning sketch comedy group, High Dramma, and still collaborates with them from time to time. Outside of Philadelphia, Kelly has worked in NYC (People's Improv Theater), Pittsburgh (Arcade Comedy Club), Montreal (Theatre Sainte Catherine), Baltimore (Lou Costello Room). This past summer she co-starred in the HBO comedy, Crashing, and most recently finished filming a supporting role in a Feature film.


 Where will your $$$ go? 

The money raised through this campaign will go towards covering:

  • Performance space rental 
  • Compensation for director and technical support
  • Photography
  • Videography
  • Props and costumes
  • Marketing and social media outreach
  • Programs for the show
  • We Hear You campaign to stop sexual abuse

In addition, a portion of the donations and ticket sales will go towards We Hear You , a social impact campaign designed to get help to survivors of sexual abuse. The campaign was created by filmmakers of the Netflix docu-series, The Keepers http://thekeepersimpact.com/get-involved/.  Kelly's show does not explore sexual abuse in the Catholic Church, but she was compelled to do her small part in combating abuse both in the Catholic Church and beyond.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

  • Share this campaign (On facebook, Via email, Via Twitter)
  • Buy tickets to the show

 

Team

Carly L. Bodnar - Director 

Carly Bodnar is a director, teaching artist, producer, and sometimes actor. She id the Co-Artistic Director and Founding Member of ReVamp Collective, a Philadelphia based feminist-centric theatre company. For the past three years Carly  has directed for ReVamp and most recently directed the world premiere of Jimmy Gorski is Dead. Carly’s other directing credits include; Blithe Spirit at Hedgerow Theatre (Barrymore Recommended), Company at La Salle University, Sarah Treem’s A Feminine Ending, chorus director for Shakespeare in Clark Park’s Coriolanus, She received her BA in Theatre from Temple University with a minor in Art History. Next up Carly is directing Shelli Pentimall Bookler’s All the Dead Biddles. For more information visit www.carlylbodnar.com

 

James Jackson- Technical Director

James Jackson (Technical Director - Lighting, Projection & Sound) has known Catholic Guilt, even though he’s not Catholic. James’ most recent work includes lighting the Harrison Stengle Fringe Festival production of GATZ!; directing and producing the world premier of Lynn Nottage’s exploration of the history of slavery in America “One More River To Cross; Tech Directing the Barrymore award winning productions of The Seagull by EgoPo Classic Theatre and the Barrymore award winning 11th Hour production of LIZZIE!.  James is also engaged in creating brand imagery as a freelance photographer (raveneyes.com); directing and producing independent films throughout the North East under his production brand, Light Thief Productions; and designing, directing, and producing many other Philadelphia area theatrical productions. James would like to thank his crew for their hard work; his wife Cassandra Zook, for her patience and support; and his dad, John L. Morascini, for inspiring his work in theatre: In memory of him July 11th, 1951 - February 19, 2013 <3

 

*For mature audiences only. This show contains strong language and adult content*

 

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

-Kelly McCaughan

Photography: Hannah Van Sciver

Videography: Daniel Ison

story:
Welcoming who?

My name is Alex Romania, I'm an interdisciplinary performing artist living and working in NYC. What does that mean? Well... I make strange things in a strange time. Right now I'm making a project called 'junkhead', which has come to be a reflection on a few years of being sick with something called Bartonella, an ugly bacteria you get from a tick bite which effects pretty much every part of your being (don't worry about my health, really, I'm in great health now and well on my way to even better health, but that experience has been a big influence on my art work ; ) I had Bartonella while I made my last work 'KLUTZ',  a massive piece in the historic Playhouse at Abrons Arts Center, involving 8 performers (my 75 year old father's performance debut) two musicians, a lighting designer, and a video designer. I didn't realize Bartonella flares up in stressful times - during that project I was experiencing symptoms I wasn't aware were due to this bacteria in my body. I'm now in good health, and I look back at that period feeling I was possessed by something strange. While sick I discovered a brilliant coping mechanism - horror / sci-fi cinema - some which I have come to appreciate as masterpieces, some which I thumb at as odd culture sores. I've been thinking a lot about what these horror films, contemporary media, my experience of being sick, and the suburban spaces I grew up in say in relation to one another. I've been in the studio collaborating with performers Maira Duarte and Malcolm-X Betts, composer Marc Mosteirin, interdisciplinary artist Max Abeles, and recently Hyung Seok Jeon who is helping me run a video installation for the performance. We've been creating in the messy terrain this project explores, and I'm raising money to pay these incredible artists for their time so that we can bring our work to life at Brooklyn Studios for Dance this May 1-4, 2019. 

Welcoming what?

What's a performance project without three silicone copies of my body, a handmade hotdog priest mascot, 100 silicone hotdogs, an installation of cathode ray tubes, black-lights, and... oh yeah, performers!?! I've been hard at work creating the foundation for every aspect of this piece (except my performers, I didn't create them obviously). Since July, my bedroom has been a special FX studio, a video synthesis lab, rehearsal space, and yes sometimes a bedroom. My collaborators have generously given their time, energy, and spirits in this ridiculous work of absurd proportion. They are invested in the project, and I am invested in getting them adequate artist fees for their work. Also, these odd silicone copies of my body I have made take a tremendous budget to create, they are the centerpiece of the work and they require regular maintenance. There's a lot to support in this project, and as a way to show our gratitude for your support we've got some KLUTZ brand totes, T-shirts, and new stickers (wooh!) for you as perks (and oh yes much more). We've gotten some financial support and rehearsal space through an artist residency I hold with Movement Research, as well as additional rehearsal space through Brooklyn Studios for Dance, but we are still in need to raise more money to pay artist fees and material costs, which is why we are launching this campaign. 

Why welcome 'junkhead'?

'junkhead' is a challenging work that looks at the pre-apocalyptic state of the 21st century, the behavior of governments, and the expression of capitalist/consumer economies as spaces of sickness. I'm also asking some personal questions in this work - like how an artistic work can hold up the maker, rather than press down on them? Seems sort of ironic to ask that question and create a 50lb silicone suit to dance inside of... but hey, that's art I guess. I could write the rest of my PR nonsense here like:

'Speech, video, sound, and action form a chaos meditation of thought memes contemplating the psychosis of governance as delusional capitalist suicidal ideation as egomaniacal death worship as parasitic zombie whiteness as the spacetime emoji continuum of mediareality loops of apocalypse nostalgia. junkhead is overload with hopes beyond the body (of)___________.'

You know, that kind of nonsense ; this work began as a reflection on my experiences of a mind altered space living with the effects this bacteria Bartonella, so, yeah, it's more than a little bit about that space where your grasp on reality starts to slide (again, I'm in good health now, so no need to worry ; ). I think this is a powerful work that has the potential to speak beyond my experience - I'm asking my collaborators to go on a challenging, vulnerable, and exhausting journey with me on stage and in the studio. Your contributions will go towards artist fees and material costs for bringing this project to it's full fruition, getting well deserved fees to well deserving artists. In my last project KLUTZ, I raised over $6,000 to meet the expenses of that project; I'm doing a smaller campaign this time as it's pretty soon after my last round of fundraising. A contribution of any size goes a long way and is deeply felt.

Welcoming no failure.

This project is going to happen regardless of $, but hey, it would make it a whole lot easier and better with your support, and it would make at least one happy, healthy, and humble artist. I've been making my work here in NYC for over 6 years, and hopefully will continue to for much longer. Your contributions are a way for me to compensate my collaborators adequately for their work, and to perhaps get myself an artist fee ; ) I wouldn't be the first director who turned down an artist fee to make a better production, but hey, it's nice value your own time as the lead artist as well. This production will happen no matter what, but your contributions will have a far greater impact than I could communicate here. Any contribution to this campaign will help me to make my art and I can't explain the significance of that gift in words. 

Welcoming you!

We don't care about your money. I mean, we can use it ; ) but mostly, we care about you. If you care to support us but you can't do so financially right now, we would welcome your support in getting the word out there about our campaign (I hear there are some great Indiegogo share tools to do this on social media?) and hey, we will definitely be in need of a volunteer for each performance to help set up and break down each show, so if you're in NYC and want to offer help that way, we wholeheartedly welcome you!
story_txt:
Welcoming who?
My name is Alex Romania, I'm an interdisciplinary performing artist living and working in NYC. What does that mean? Well... I make strange things in a strange time. Right now I'm making a project called 'junkhead', which has come to be a reflection on a few years of being sick with something called Bartonella, an ugly bacteria you get from a tick bite which effects pretty much every part of your being (don't worry about my health, really, I'm in great health now and well on my way to even better health, but that experience has been a big influence on my art work ; ) I had Bartonella while I made my last work 'KLUTZ',  a massive piece in the historic Playhouse at Abrons Arts Center, involving 8 performers (my 75 year old father's performance debut) two musicians, a lighting designer, and a video designer. I didn't realize Bartonella flares up in stressful times - during that project I was experiencing symptoms I wasn't aware were due to this bacteria in my body. I'm now in good health, and I look back at that period feeling I was possessed by something strange. While sick I discovered a brilliant coping mechanism - horror / sci-fi cinema - some which I have come to appreciate as masterpieces, some which I thumb at as odd culture sores. I've been thinking a lot about what these horror films, contemporary media, my experience of being sick, and the suburban spaces I grew up in say in relation to one another. I've been in the studio collaborating with performers Maira Duarte and Malcolm-X Betts, composer Marc Mosteirin, interdisciplinary artist Max Abeles, and recently Hyung Seok Jeon who is helping me run a video installation for the performance. We've been creating in the messy terrain this project explores, and I'm raising money to pay these incredible artists for their time so that we can bring our work to life at Brooklyn Studios for Dance this May 1-4, 2019. 

Welcoming what?

What's a performance project without three silicone copies of my body, a handmade hotdog priest mascot, 100 silicone hotdogs, an installation of cathode ray tubes, black-lights, and... oh yeah, performers!?! I've been hard at work creating the foundation for every aspect of this piece (except my performers, I didn't create them obviously). Since July, my bedroom has been a special FX studio, a video synthesis lab, rehearsal space, and yes sometimes a bedroom. My collaborators have generously given their time, energy, and spirits in this ridiculous work of absurd proportion. They are invested in the project, and I am invested in getting them adequate artist fees for their work. Also, these odd silicone copies of my body I have made take a tremendous budget to create, they are the centerpiece of the work and they require regular maintenance. There's a lot to support in this project, and as a way to show our gratitude for your support we've got some KLUTZ brand totes, T-shirts, and new stickers (wooh!) for you as perks (and oh yes much more). We've gotten some financial support and rehearsal space through an artist residency I hold with Movement Research, as well as additional rehearsal space through Brooklyn Studios for Dance, but we are still in need to raise more money to pay artist fees and material costs, which is why we are launching this campaign. 


Why welcome 'junkhead'?
'junkhead' is a challenging work that looks at the pre-apocalyptic state of the 21st century, the behavior of governments, and the expression of capitalist/consumer economies as spaces of sickness. I'm also asking some personal questions in this work - like how an artistic work can hold up the maker, rather than press down on them? Seems sort of ironic to ask that question and create a 50lb silicone suit to dance inside of... but hey, that's art I guess. I could write the rest of my PR nonsense here like:
'Speech, video, sound, and action form a chaos meditation of thought memes contemplating the psychosis of governance as delusional capitalist suicidal ideation as egomaniacal death worship as parasitic zombie whiteness as the spacetime emoji continuum of mediareality loops of apocalypse nostalgia. junkhead is overload with hopes beyond the body (of)___________.'
You know, that kind of nonsense ; this work began as a reflection on my experiences of a mind altered space living with the effects this bacteria Bartonella, so, yeah, it's more than a little bit about that space where your grasp on reality starts to slide (again, I'm in good health now, so no need to worry ; ). I think this is a powerful work that has the potential to speak beyond my experience - I'm asking my collaborators to go on a challenging, vulnerable, and exhausting journey with me on stage and in the studio. Your contributions will go towards artist fees and material costs for bringing this project to it's full fruition, getting well deserved fees to well deserving artists. In my last project KLUTZ, I raised over $6,000 to meet the expenses of that project; I'm doing a smaller campaign this time as it's pretty soon after my last round of fundraising. A contribution of any size goes a long way and is deeply felt.

Welcoming no failure.
This project is going to happen regardless of $, but hey, it would make it a whole lot easier and better with your support, and it would make at least one happy, healthy, and humble artist. I've been making my work here in NYC for over 6 years, and hopefully will continue to for much longer. Your contributions are a way for me to compensate my collaborators adequately for their work, and to perhaps get myself an artist fee ; ) I wouldn't be the first director who turned down an artist fee to make a better production, but hey, it's nice value your own time as the lead artist as well. This production will happen no matter what, but your contributions will have a far greater impact than I could communicate here. Any contribution to this campaign will help me to make my art and I can't explain the significance of that gift in words. 

Welcoming you!
We don't care about your money. I mean, we can use it ; ) but mostly, we care about you. If you care to support us but you can't do so financially right now, we would welcome your support in getting the word out there about our campaign (I hear there are some great Indiegogo share tools to do this on social media?) and hey, we will definitely be in need of a volunteer for each performance to help set up and break down each show, so if you're in NYC and want to offer help that way, we wholeheartedly welcome you!

story:
Short Summary

The Stars of Tomorrow program was started in 2018 by Chandra Galloway. The show is completely student run, from the cast and crew, right up through the staff. She wanted to provide a space where students of all ages and all theatre backgrounds were able to learn and grow in their love of theatre. This program is not just for students who already have a background in theatre, it is also for those who want to learn more and explore that interest in their lives, whether they wish to be behind the scenes or onstage.

This campaign is not just so we can raise a little bit of money for our show, without this campaign our show may not be possible, and after watching the growth of all these students last year we just cannot let that happen.  

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a show is not cheap or easy. The money raised from this campaign will go directly towards paying for the royalties, scripts, and rehearsal fees. By donating you will receive a special gift from the cast, staff, and theatre company, starting with a thank you in our program and going up to you or your business/organization being recognized on all of our posters and other promotional items.

 

Other ways to help:

We understand that not everyone is able to donate money to our cause. We just ask that you spread the word and share this with your friends and family. 

If you would like to donate an unspecified amount or want more information please contact Chandra Galloway at tctcstarsoftomorrow@gmail.com.

story:
Brutal Cessation

Directed by Bethany Pitts, performed by Alan Mahon and Lydia Larson

'I have fantasies... I lead you to a table… and I hurt you.'

A relationship. A relationship rotting. Purgatory.

Is having no reason to stay a reason to leave? At what point does the abuser become the abused? And why aren't we more afraid of women?

Two actors, one couple, swapping roles.

We'll be participating in the Progression Programme at GLYPT (Greenwich and Lewisham Young People's Theatre) in July, inviting them into our rehearsal room and providing four opportunities for young talent to shadow us. Applications are open here. 

 

Dust

Directed by Sara Joyce, performed by Milly Thomas
Watch the trailer

A woman. A suicide. A choice. A fly on the wall. A funeral. A Bakewell tart. A life. A lie. A truth. An ending. Of sorts.

Alice thinks that life isn’t worth living. So she kills herself. Sort of. She is stuck, a fly on the wall. Forced to watch the aftermath of her suicide and its ripple effect on her family and friends, Alice quickly learns that death changes people. And that death is not the change she hoped for.

 

Who Are We

Milly Thomas is a London-based writer and actor, whose credits include Quacks (BBC2); Cargo (The Arcola Theatre); Dry Land (Jermyn Street Theatre); & Downton Abbey (ITV). Her plays ‘A First World Problem’ and ‘Clickbait’ have both played to sold out runs at Theatre503. She is a member of the Young Writers’ Lab 2015 and Writer’s Lab Alumni 2017 at Soho Theatre and of ‘Headstart’ – a group comprising of ten playwrights assembled by Headlong Theatre Company and Blacklisted Films. For television Milly has written episodes of 'River City' for BBC Scotland and 'Clique' for BBC3.

Milly Thomas, photo by Faye Thomas

 

Brutal Cessation

Alan Mahon trained at The Lir Academy in Dublin. Since graduating he has performed frequently in Ireland and England. Credits include: If We Got Some More Cocaine I Could Show You How I Love You(Old Red Lion), Hamlet in Hamlet (Tobacco Factory) and King Lear (Dublin Fringe).

Bethany Pitts was Assistant Director at Theatre Royal Plymouth from 2012–2013, working under Artistic Director Simon Stokes, and prior to that worked as Resident Assistant Director at Theatre 503. Credits include Spine (Underbelly Edinburgh / Soho Theatre / UK Tour – Fringe First Winner 2014); Tether (Underbelly Edinburgh); Much Further Out Than You Thought (Underbelly, Edinburgh & UK Tour); FreeFall (Pleasance Islington – Nominated for Off West End Best Director) DESERT (National Tour / Latitude Festival).

Lydia Larson trained at GSA. She is an Offie-nominated actress for her performance in Skin a Cat by Isley Lynn (The Vaults/The Bunker). Other credits include A Super Happy Story (Fruit) and Travesty (Assembly Rooms).

Michelle Barnette is a freelance creative producer and general manager. She is currently working on the Westway Trust's summer fesitval, Portobello Rising, and has previously worked for the Kevin Spacey Foundation as an intern and workshop leader on their education project Hothouse. Credits include: The Scar Test (Soho Theatre, general manager), Brutal Cessation (Assembly, Edinburgh), Dust (Underbelly, Edinburgh), and a new musical currently in development.

Alan Mahon in rehearsals for Brutal Cessation. Photo by Katie Edwards.

Dust

Sara Joyce is the Associate Director at The Bunker Theatre. She was previously the Resident Director at the Almeida and the Resident Assistant Director at Soho Theatre. Work includes:  Elsa (Edinburgh Assembly); The Scar Test (Soho Theatre); Bush Theatre Emerging Writers’ Showcase; Crestfall (Rada), Three Short Plays by Samuel Beckett; The Win Bin (Old Red Lion).

Holly De Angelis is a freelance creative producer. Since graduating from The University of Manchester in 2014, Holly has worked at the Soho Theatre (current), The Royal Court & Graeae. Holly is also arts programmer for Brainchild festival.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We're jointly fundraising £4,000, splitting whatever we get right down the middle between the two shows.

Most of our major costs like the venue fees and PR are covered, so the funding will be used towards

  • Travel to & from Edinburgh
  • Paying the team
  • The cost of printing the flyers, posters and scripts
  • Accommodation

If we don't get the full amount, the funding will still be used towards these expenses.

In return for supporting these two important projects we have a lot of rewards on offer including

  • Signed posters and scripts
  • Tickets
  • A play - written and performed especially for you!
  • If we reach our target, you get to vote to see who gets to dump a bucket of ice water on our writer Milly Thomas - which will be filmed and shared during the Fringe

The Impact

Milly is continuing to establish herself as a feminist writer & actress who often explores crucial issues for 21st century women. Comedian and founder of The Guilty Feminist, Deborah Frances-White says ‘Milly Thomas is an extraordinary performer, a fearless writer and one of the most relevant, vibrant, funny and insightful millennial voices working in British Theatre Today. Often controversial, always daring, never disappointing- like the love child of Charlie Brooker and Diablo Cody’.  ​

You’ll be supporting not one but two predominantly female-led, young creative teams. Both plays have  received a great deal of media attention and are already selling tickets. Brutal Cessation was recently placed in Lyn Gardner’s ‘What to see & where to go’ at the Edinburgh Fringe 2017

Any financial contribution you could make, however big or small, would make a huge difference at this critical stage in our fundraising process.

Even if you can't donate, word of mouth means so much in Edinburgh so if you like what we have to say, please share our page far and wide! Follow us @dust_theplay & @BrutalCessation

story:
Master Sigh

Shauna Sorensen and Dancers 2nd evening length performance 

 

Master Sigh is a meeting of music, street art, and dance. The Top to Bottom mural, created by Arts Org, is a public street art project located in the heart of Long Island City (LIC). Shauna Sorensen and Dancers have taken the first part of 2017 to research the murals and create 40 minutes of new movement inspired by several of the murals painted on the building. The company will perform this movement as well as present a site-specific dance video at our 2nd evening length performance on October 21st and 22nd at The Local NY.

The company was honored to receive the Queens Council on The Arts: New Works Grant for 2017. Master Sigh is made possible by the Queens Council on The Arts with public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council. Even with this generous grant, we still need to raise $798 to help us fund the filming process that Master Sigh requires. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • To ensure we get the high quality filming we need for the site-specific dance video and to film the performance for archival purposes, the company needs to raise $798. 
    • $200 to pay filmmaker for filming at the murals 
    • $82 to rent camera stabilizer equipment 
    • $300 to pay filmmaker the day of the performance 
    • $150 to pay dancers the day of the mural filming 
    • $66 to pay for Indie Go Go fees 
  • Perks
    • Donate $10: receive a Thank You email from all the dancers 
    • Donate $25: personalized dance to be posted on social media and Thank You email from all the dancers   
    •  Donate $50: free beer during after party at the Local NYC, personalized dance to be posted on social media, and Thank You email from all the dancers
  • If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will first go towards paying the filmmaker for filming at the murals and then to the camera stabilizing equipment; the remainder will go towards paying the dancers the day of the mural filming. 

The Impact

Projects such as the Top to Bottom mural bring together the diverse population of LIC, and educate all people - young and old, students and professionals - about the importance of urban art. By celebrating the Top to Bottom mural through dance, film, and sound, we will be drawing attention to this movement of public/private art right at our doorstep while bringing a bounty of beauty into the industrial, gritty streets of LIC.

Shauna Sorensen and Dancers premiered their first evening-length dance piece in the spring of 2015. This project was an amazing year and a half spent in the studio. The process of building movement, editing the piece after each performance, molding spatial patterns, and being involved in a long-term project was truly rewarding. We are honored to be given the opportunity to dive into that creation process again. Utilizing film will help push the company's creative limits and help create a thoughtful performance experience for the audience. With your donations to the campaign, the company will be able to make a quality dance video to show during our performance and will be given the opportunity to have excellent archival video to use for future submissions and performances. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute we could still use your help!!!

  • You could donate your time on the weekend of the show or during dress rehearsal. 
  • If you have a young dancer in your life, they can attend the company's fundraiser "Jumps and Turns" class on Monday October 9th. Contact shaunaj83@yahoo.com for details. 
  • Spread the word to others who might consider contributing to our campaign. 

THANK YOU <3
