story:
Oh hi there...

Hello friends, we are Dreamback a new Dublin-based theatre collective. We aim to make theatre that plays with form to investigate contemporary themes that resonate on a macro scale, through a micro lens. 

Our new upcoming production of The Wendy House needs your help! 

A bit about the play: 

Written and Performed by Claudia Kinahan The Wendy House follows six year old Lily as she packs up her favourite worldly possessions. She’s going to her Wendy House and once she gets there she’s never coming back.

Lily spends her life travelling between a rural Irish village and a large paediatric hospital in Dublin.

Through the delicate intertwining of her memories, Lily explores the struggles that families face in moments of trauma and the fearless power of childhood innocence and imagination.

Following a well received twenty minute excerpt at Scene + Heard 2017, a full production was scheduled for May 1st-12th 2018. We have recently spent some time redeveloping the script based on the feedback we received after Scene + Heard and are ready to hit the stage!  

But Who Are We? 

Dreamback is a newly established theatre collective founded by Rachel Bergin, Nadine Flynn and Claudia Kinahan. 

Dreamback’s recent credits include Patrick, as part of The New Irish Playbook at Smock Alley, an extract from The Wendy House at Smock Alley’s Scene + Heard, 2017 and a rehearsed reading of With Wolves, written by Nadine Flynn at The New Theatre.

Our Amazing Team: 

  • Lighting Design // Dara Hoban
  • Set Design // Ellen Kirk 
  • Sound Design // Richard Durning 
  • Costume Design //Annachiara Vispi 
  • Assistant Producer // Brian McMahon Gallagher 
  • Stage Manager // Ellie Hendry 
  • Production Manager // Oscar O'Leary Fitzpatrick

  • What Do We Need? 

As one of Dreamback's first major productions it's important that we can make an impact with The Wendy House. 

Your help with this campaign will allow us to afford: 

  • Rehearsal Space 
  • An exciting Set Design 
  • A stunning Lighting Design 
  • A dynamic Sound Design 
  • The perfect Props
  • Printing of our beautiful Posters, Programmes and Flyers 
  • Online and outdoor marketing campaigns 

Currently we have secured an excellent venue, a fantastic team and a unique and vibrant script, now all we need is your help to bring it all to the stage. 

Dreamback is currently a completely unfunded company so we need a little helping hand to make our vision a reality. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Buy a ticket!

story_txt:
Oh hi there...
Hello friends, we are Dreamback a new Dublin-based theatre collective. We aim to make theatre that plays with form to investigate contemporary themes that resonate on a macro scale, through a micro lens. 
Our new upcoming production of The Wendy House needs your help! 
A bit about the play: 
Written and Performed by Claudia Kinahan The Wendy House follows six year old Lily as she packs up her favourite worldly possessions. She’s going to her Wendy House and once she gets there she’s never coming back.
Lily spends her life travelling between a rural Irish village and a large paediatric hospital in Dublin.
Through the delicate intertwining of her memories, Lily explores the struggles that families face in moments of trauma and the fearless power of childhood innocence and imagination.
Following a well received twenty minute excerpt at Scene + Heard 2017, a full production was scheduled for May 1st-12th 2018. We have recently spent some time redeveloping the script based on the feedback we received after Scene + Heard and are ready to hit the stage!  
But Who Are We? 
Dreamback is a newly established theatre collective founded by Rachel Bergin, Nadine Flynn and Claudia Kinahan. 

Dreamback’s recent credits include Patrick, as part of The New Irish Playbook at Smock Alley, an extract from The Wendy House at Smock Alley’s Scene + Heard, 2017 and a rehearsed reading of With Wolves, written by Nadine Flynn at The New Theatre.
Our Amazing Team: 

Lighting Design // Dara Hoban
Set Design // Ellen Kirk 
Sound Design // Richard Durning 
Costume Design //Annachiara Vispi 
Assistant Producer // Brian McMahon Gallagher 
Stage Manager // Ellie Hendry 
Production Manager // Oscar O'Leary Fitzpatrick



What Do We Need? 
As one of Dreamback's first major productions it's important that we can make an impact with The Wendy House. 
Your help with this campaign will allow us to afford: 

Rehearsal Space 
An exciting Set Design 
A stunning Lighting Design 
A dynamic Sound Design 
The perfect Props
Printing of our beautiful Posters, Programmes and Flyers 
Online and outdoor marketing campaigns 

Currently we have secured an excellent venue, a fantastic team and a unique and vibrant script, now all we need is your help to bring it all to the stage. 
Dreamback is currently a completely unfunded company so we need a little helping hand to make our vision a reality. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Buy a ticket!

story:
Your Alternative Musical Theatre

MTM is known for doing the weird stuff.  We like to get down and dirty and thrill you in ways you never thought possible.  It may seem scary at first, but trust us, we've got all kinds of amazing things in store. 

And the safety word is kumquat. (Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson reference.  Oh did we mention that show was on the Best of the Arts lists for 2013 in both Isthmus and 77 Square?) 


Being weird is hard.  And expensive.

The company Executive Director took an arts management course in college.  She was asked to balance a budget for an imaginary theatre company.  "This is impossible," she said at the time.  (Don't worry, she figured it out about five years later.) 

Your money from this campaign will help to fund the sets and costumes needed for our summer 2014 production of BONNIE & CLYDE.  


Why do the weird stuff? 

We all love a good production of Carousel.  The thing is, you can get that in lots of places.  Musical theatre is growing and changing.  That means we honor the classics and keep looking to the future.  MTM gives Madison audiences the chance to see shows about trapped cavers, crimes of the century, hostages, rock star presidents, legendary historical figures, and commercial failures.  And of course, tortured artists.  About which we know nothing.  Nothing at all*.  

Won't you help us make 2014 the year to beat? 

*Please note sarcasm.

story:
Hello! My name is Francine Odri and I am a Children’s Theatre Director at Mainstage’s Summer Stage program in Blackwood, N.J. Summer Stage has been a Gloucester Township staple for 25 summers and we are very excited to celebrate our 26th year! Summer Stage is truly a special and magical place. Here, we foster a safe and loving environment that nurtures young performers to achieve their dreams. Many of our staff members, myself included, have grown up through the program and love it so much that we want to perpetuate that magic for further generations.

This summer, one of our three shows is Willy Wonka Jr., which features a “Flying” scene with Charlie and Grandpa Joe. In order to make this production the best that it can be and the summer as magical as possible, we are trying to bring Flying by Foy, the same company that flew Mary Martin in the original Peter Pan musical, to Summer Stage. Mainstage has worked with Flying by Foy in the past (most recently in their production of Peter Pan this past November), but money for the arts this summer is particularly tight with three other shows to produce and we need your help!

We are in the process of gaining sponsors to fund the bulk of Flying by Foy’s cost, but we are still a bit below our goal. If we do not reach our entire goal, the funding will go to enhancing the children’s experience in the show in whatever way possible, including bubble machines and other additions to the set.

Last November, Mainstage was successful in gaining funding to bring Flying by Foy to Peter Pan through a campaign similar to this, so we are hopeful that we may reach our goal again! Please consider contributing to this great project–anything will help! Your support will help create a truly great production and a magical summer for dedicated young performers.

story:
Capoeira Mestre Bimba Bay Area is excited to announce its first ever batizado!  We are raising funds to bring our Mestre (teacher) from Brazil, along with other guest teachers from our worldwide group. This fundraising effort will pay for travel expenses, workshop fees, t-shirts, food and other costs that go into this significant three-day event being held from June 4 to 6. 

Our students have been working hard and they love capoeira. The batizado represents a recognition of their hard work and motivation to keep improving and moving forward in this art form. This event cannot happen without our teacher, Mestre Bamba: Mestre Bamba, who has been opening the door for hundreds of kids and adults in Bahia, Brazil, where social and economic disparity is tangible. Capoeira gives confidence, discipline, and self-value to these kids in need. It educates them about African Brazilian culture, about African Diaspora and provides a history lesson in every song and in every movement. Offering scholarships and teaching in poverish communities throughout the city of Salvador, Bahia, Mestre Bamba provides a hope for many and he is the reason we are here teaching today. 

Our Story

Capoeira Mestre Bimba Bay Area was started by Professor Caçador (Jadson Souza) and Estagiário Sereno (Helio Conceição) in 2010. Both teachers trained under Mestre Bamba in the historic neighborhood of Pelourinho, in Salvador, where Capoeira was born. After teaching at the Associação de Capoeira Mestre Bimba, Jadson moved to the Bay Area in 2010 where he started his local Capoeira practice giving lessons on a playground of a nearby elementary school. Next he joined the team at Destiny Arts, a 25-year-old nonprofit that teaches violence-prevention through the arts to Bay Area youth. Since working with Destiny Arts, Jadson has taught in various elementary schools, dance studios and martial arts gyms. For him, his most rewarding work was teaching Capoeira and music to developmentally disabled adults at the Clausen House in Oakland. Jadson currently offers an adult Capoeira program in Oakland, a children’s program in Alameda, and is part of the city of San Pablo’s COPT (Childhood Obesity Prevention Task Force). In a year, Jadson has taught over 50 kids in San Pablo, a city that has the 3rd highest rate of obesity in the state.  

Helio, who has been learning capoeira since he was 5 years old—throwing kicks with his uncle beneath a mango tree—has taken his training and brought it first to Traverse, Michigan, in 2007 where he taught at Leelanau Center for Contemplative Arts. Beginning in 2010, Helio has been teaching at various locations in the Bay Area. He now teaches weekly classes at the Berkeley YMCA and was part of its outreach program to help keep elementary school kids active. He also teaches at an alternative high school in Oakland and has several adult classes throughout the Bay Area where he offers scholarships for underprivileged teens and adults.
As African descendants, Jadson and Helio are aware that their work goes beyond teaching the movements of capoeira. Teaching in public schools and community centers in areas that are not so affluent, they represent leadership for minorities that don't normally see people like them in these roles. 

What is Capoeira?

Capoeira is an African-Brazilian martial art with a foundation in dance, music, and acrobatics. Developed around the 16th century, on the plantations and senzalas (estates) of colonial Brazil, Capoeira was born out of a desire of expression, a necessity of freedom, and a means of survival for African-Brazilian men. Its roots stem from the resistance of slavery and it has since evolved into an instrument of social, educational, and cultural enrichment. Capoeira is a part of Brazil’s identity and was recently declared a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

What is a Batizado?

A batizado is a Capoeira ceremony where new students are symbolically introduced to the world-wide Capoeira community and receive their first cordos (belts). Other Capoeira Mestres, instructors and students are invited to the ceremony, where they joyfully welcome new Capoeiristas (people that play Capoeira) to the art form. As in many aspects of Capoeira, the batizado has its own symbolism and is a very special event. It is not a competition but rather a weekend-long event filled with community and activities where Capoeiristas share their knowledge and love of this beautiful art form.

If you would like more information, please visit CapoeiraOaktown.com. We are excited to have you partnering with us. Thank you in advance for your contributions.

                    --Jadson (Caçador), Helio (Sereno), Alice (Piu Piu) and all the students of                                                                                            Capoeira Mestre Bimba Bay Area

story:
TRÉGEREK KÖZT//AMONG BATTENS

(scroll down for English)

Sziasztok! Mi fiatal színházi háttérmunkások egy csapata vagyunk, egy éve végeztünk a Színház- és Filmművészeti Egyetem színházi rendezőasszisztens osztályában. Jelenleg a Trégerek közt elnevezésű projekten dolgozunk, melynek célja, hogy a háttérszakmák képviselőivel való beszélgetéseken keresztül bemutassa a fiataloknak a különböző színházi háttérszakmákat.
2015-ben sikerrel debütált Poszt-it! programsorozatunk a POSzT-on; ezen felbuzdulva elhatároztuk, hogy idén Budapesten, immáron a színházak közreműködésével is megvalósítjuk a projektet. Az első alkalom a lelkesen csatlakozó Örkény Színházban lesz, és a kellékes feladatait veszi górcső alá. Sík Kata kellékes már a POSzT-on is részt vett a programban, és ismét vállalta, hogy mesél a szakmájáról. Beszélgetőpartnere Csuja Imre és Zsigmond Emőke lesz.
A programsorozat részeként márciustól június elejéig havonta 1-2 alkalommal, más-más budapesti színházban, egy másfél órás beszélgetés keretében mutatná be a terítéken lévő háttérszakmák a terület egy jeles képviselője, valamint egy fiatal és egy tapasztalt színész. Ahhoz, hogy megszülethessen ez a programsorozat, és hogy minél többekhez eljuthasson, a ti támogatásotokra van szükségünk.
Segítsetek, hogy előtérbe kerülhessen a háttér!
Ha pénzzel nem is tudsz minket támogatni, rengeteget jelentene, ha megosztanád a kampányunkat a barátaiddal és ismerőseiddel. Minden segítségért örülünk!
Részletekért, időpontokért, képekért kövesd a Facebook-oldalunkat: https://www.facebook.com/szinhazihatterszakmak/...
Köszönjük a segítséget!

Első alkalom
téma: kellékes
résztvevők: Sík Kata kellékes, valamint Zsigmond Emőke és Csuja Imre színművészek
időpont: 2017. március 2. 16 óra
helyszín: Örkény István Színház Stúdió (Asbóth utca 22.)
moderátor: Kovács Bálint

 

Második alkalom
téma: színpadtechnika
résztvevők: Német Tibor műszaki igazgató, Bodon Károly fővilágosító és Schell Judit színművész
időpont: 2017. április 4. 14:30
helyszín: Thália Színház, nagyszínpad (Nagymező utca 22.)

Harmadik alkalom
téma: súgó
résztvevők: Fodor Marianna súgó, valamint Rudolf Péter és Simon Kornél színművészek
időpont: 2017. május 3. 17:30
helyszín: Centrál Színház, kisszínpad (Révay utca 18.)
moderátor: Kovács Bálint

 

ABOUT US

Hello, we are a group of young assistant directors; we completed our studies at University of Theatre and Film Arts, Budapest a year ago. We are currently working on a project that aims to introduce the different members of the theatrical production team.
In 2015 we launched Poszt-it!, another project of ours, similar to this one, at POSzT, the biggest Hungarian theatrical festival – its success inspired us to bring the idea to Budapest, joining hands with the theatres. The first event is going to take place at Örkény Theatre, and we are going to examine the everyday duties and unexpected difficulties of a prop master. Kata Sík is willing and kind to tell everyone about her job, as she’d done in 2015 with Judit Pogány; this time Imre Csuja and Emőke Zsigmond is going to join her.
Five different theatres would host our events between March and June, each time presenting a different theatrical profession with the help of a representative member of the area, a young and a veteran performer/artist/actor. We need your support to implement this project, to spread it and to reach as many people as possible.
Please, help us to bring the backstage crew into public view!
We understand that sometimes it is not always possible to offer financial support. However, you can help us to make this project a success by sharing, liking, talking about it and generally spreading the word about this campaign. We greatly appreciate any kind of help!
For updates, photos and more fun stuff follow our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/szinhazihatterszakmak/...
Thank you for your help!

story:
With the unfortunate passing of Prince we thought it would be a good/fun idea to host a party room at CONvergence 2016 in Bloomington this year in his honor. A lot of great music and a lot of geek dancing.

My name is Garrick and I've been an attendee at CONvergence for the last 6 years. Got heavily involved in volunteering last year, and continuing into this year. This won't be my first con by a long shot, but it will be the first party room I've hosted. I have an avid love of all things geek and pop-culture, and am especially a huge movie and music nerd. I thought a dance party would be a fitting tribute to a genius artist who was taken too soon.

Since this is a last minute addition to the party rooms we are trying to raise the funds to help offset a majority of the costs associated with hosting a party at the convention.

The more money we can raise the more amenities the room can offer. There's party room rental, sound equipment, decorating, and if we raise enough, possible drinks to offer.

Rough budget breakdown (will be tweaked as we go)
Cabana Room rental - $800
Sound Equipment - $240
Decorations - $100
Additional funds past this will be used to add beverages, and other items we're considering.
story_txt: With the unfortunate passing of Prince we thought it would be a good/fun idea to host a party room at CONvergence 2016 in Bloomington this year in his honor. A lot of great music and a lot of geek dancing.My name is Garrick and I've been an attendee at CONvergence for the last 6 years. Got heavily involved in volunteering last year, and continuing into this year. This won't be my first con by a long shot, but it will be the first party room I've hosted. I have an avid love of all things geek and pop-culture, and am especially a huge movie and music nerd. story:
La obra teatral Ana, el mago y el aprendiz, escrita por Arístides Vargas, se presentará el 26, 27 y 28 de febrero de 2016 en la Sala Beckett, en Río Piedras, Puerto Rico. El proceso creativo está siendo muy enriquecedor para todo el equipo de producción, sin embargo, carecemos de fondos económicos para poder lograrlo. Los gastos de promoción, teatro, escenografía, vestuario, libretos, programas y otros materiales adicionales, conllevan adquirir fondos culturales con los que no contamos. Las obras teatrales financiadas, utilizan miles de dolares en producción, y por supuesto, no es para menos. Nosotros estamos utilizando materiales reciclados en todas las formas posibles, para no incurrir en gastos (dinero que no tenemos), pero siempre es necesario para poder ejecutar el arte.  Pedimos encarecidamente que ayuden a que el Teatro emergente del país continúe creciendo. Tenemos mucho amor, mucho arte y sobre todo, muchas ganas. 

Dirección: Anamaris Santiago Santos

Diseño de escenografía e iluminación - Karla Santiago Berríos

Diseño de vestuario: Yolianne Rivera

Asistente de dirección: Sergio Antongiorgi

Ilusionista: Johan Sebastian González Alfonso

Actuación: Víctor Geraldo Colón Rodríguez

                         Giaselle Limery

                         Victoria Gómez Joy

Diseño de promoción: Johany Santiago 

La filosofía que asumimos está inclinada en lo emergente y lo no institucionalizado. Esto no quiere decir que no podemos trabajar bajo una institución de ser necesario, pero tratamos de hacer siempre las producciones “sudá’s y desde abajo” como decimos en la calle.  Aunque muchos de nosotros tenemos experiencias de varios años en las artes escénicas, siempre aprendemos a cantazos. Por supuesto, tenemos como escudo nuestras experiencias anteriores. Nuestra estética es MUY exigente. Trabajamos con un teatro de imagen e inteligente. Somos fieles creyentes de compartir conocimiento para que el arte siga multiplicándose.

“Ana, el mago y el aprendiz”. El texto es uno de los más geniales que la directora de la pieza (bajo su concepto artístico) ha tenido la oportunidad de leer.  Arístides Vargas y el grupo Malayerba han tenido una trayectoria increíble por muchos años de trabajo. La directora ha tenido la dicha de poder estudiar con ellos en varias ocasiones. El método de dirección que está siendo utilizado mezclará técnicas de muchas influencias latinoamericanas que Anamaris ha tenido la oportunidad de conocer. Influencias desde Perú, Costa Rica, Panamá, Argentina, Uruguay, Bolivia y Ecuador. Confiamos en que cada uno de los integrantes de esta gran producción artística está dando lo mejor de sí. Todos somos “novatos con experiencia”, pero tenemos un sentido muy claro de las artes escénicas y de nuestra filosofía artística.

story:
The Montreal Krump Alliance is a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion and support of Krump culture throughout Quebec and Canada. Our mission is to push the Krump movement by making it accessible, visible and notorious through its various aspects.

We are reaching out to the community around us to help build this project and take it to the next level. We want to raise $7500 for two events coming up this summer and fall, which will help establish Montreal on the world map as a city known for Krump culture, dancers and events.

The money will go directly to our main events: The Clash 3 and Gutta Zone. This will help to cover artist fees, flights, accommodations, venue, DJs, transportation, promo materials, online promotion, food and beverages and administrative costs.

In exchange for your donations we our offering some amazing gifts including drop in classes with teachers from MKA, passes to the Clash and Gutta Zone, personal training program designed for you personally or a year long pass to classes with one of our teachers. Check out the Perks section to get more details.

By contributing to the creation of these two events you will help to further establish Krump in Quebec and Canada. Krump is a young dance and is still growing, events like The Clash and Gutta Zone encourages young dancers to push themselves to be better and that in turn pushes the whole culture.

MKA has big plans for the future and hosting events like this will help us to be known across Canada as a center for Krump nationally and on the international level we will also create a reputation.

Your contributions will help us build Krump in Montreal and bring this inspirational dance to a larger audience. Whether you are able to contribute at this time or not we still need you to help us get the word out. Please share the link to this campaign and tell your friends and lovers of dance. We feel this is a great project to support and we thank you in advance for any contributions you are able to make.

MKA: NOTRE MISSION

Montreal Krump Alliance (MKA) est un organisme à but non-lucratif dédié à la promotion de la culture au Québec et à travers le Canada. Notre mission est de faire grandir ce mouvement en le rendant plus visible et accessible à travers le Quebec et éventuellement, à l'international. Le MKA mise également sur les bienfaits physiques et sociaux du Krump chez les enfants et jeunes adultes.

L'OBJECTIF DE CETTE CAMPAGNE

Nous faisons appel à la communauté qui nous entoure pour nous aider à bâtir nos projets futurs. Notre objectif est d'amasser $7500 afin de financer les deux événements majeurs sur lesquels nous travaillons présentement: The Clash 3 et Gutta Zone.

The Clash attire des gens de tous les styles de danse et nous sommes ravis d'accueillir le créateur du Krump ,"Tight Eyez", comme juge pour cette 3e édition. Gutta Zone, pour sa part, servira de qualification canadienne officielle pour l'un des plus gros tournois de Krump au monde: EBS (European Buck Session), qui a lieu en Allemagne annuellement. Nous tenons également à mentionner que nous voulons un jour créer une académie de Krump, un espace utilisé pour la creation, l'échange et l'éducation sur la danse et la santé.

Les fonds amassés serviront directement à financer les évenements mentionnés ci-haut. Ces fonds aideront à couvrir les frais des artistes invités, billet d'avion, accommodations, équipement sonore, DJs, transport, outils promotionnels, nourriture/breuvages et les frais administratifs.

UN CADEAU EN ECHANGE DE VOS DONS

En échange de vos dons, nous vous offrons un éventail de cadeaux tels que l'accès à des cours à la carte avec nos enseignants du MKA, une passe d'entrée pour The Clash 3 et Gutta Zone, un programme d'entrainement physique personnalisé et une année de cours avec un enseignant du MKA de votre choix. Nous vous invitons à visiter la section des cadeaux pour plus d'information.

MERCI

Nous vous serions reconnaissants de partager le lien de cette campagne, que vous ayez contribué ou non. Parlez-en à vos amis, votre famille et aux amateurs de danse dans votre entourage. Nous sommes très heureux de lancer ce projet de financement et vous remercions d'avance pour votre contribution.

story:
About Monopoleyes

Monopoleyes - a harmless trading game for all the family? Not in this world…

Monopoleyes is a black comedy, which tells the dark tale of an unemployed and downtrodden Joe Bloggs becoming enslaved by larger than life ‘avatars’ of the game. He must face the trial of rolling the dice and let the fates take control of his, and his family’s destiny… Can he be saved?

Is there anything the Love, Hope, Charity, Courage and Faith can do to save his soul, or will the corporate entities -  Rolls Royce (the banker), Cannon (the military industrial complex), Boot (the strong arm of the law), Top Hat (the media empire) -  win through and conquer all in their path?


Monopoleyes is a scathing political allegory, an adventure into the secret world of shadow governments, a journey into who really makes the big decisions, but more importantly, what part do we play in this?

Through its content as well as its affordable tickets, Monopoleyes aims to attract a demographic that wouldn't normally go to the theatre and inspire its audience to become more engaged in politics.

What We Need & What You Get

As Stolen Thread Productions' first project, we need your help in funding it! Although we have already managed to gain funding from the Arts Council England and will earn additional funds from the tickets sold, we still need an additional £600 to fully support the production costs. This is where you come in!

In return we will show our immense gratitude through a range of rewards depending on your contribution. You could even get tickets to our VIP Gala night!

The Impact

Stolen Thread Productions is a brand new company that aims to bring as much love and passion around theatre/film/TV in the North-West as there is in London by supporting local talent and communities. It is YOUR CONTRIBUTION that will help us achieve this!

Other Ways You Can Help

Cannot make a contribution? Then help us spread the word by sharing our campaign with your friends or, even better, get your ticket and come see it for yourself!

story:
Reputation Control: Emerging Playwrights' Rep

July 21-31, 2011 at The Drilling Co. Theatre, 236 West 78th Street, NY, NY

INTRODUCING Squeaky Bicycle Productions' premiere of two exciting new plays!

Reputation Control is an Equity Approved Showcase that asks the question: 

What truly defines us? How important is one's Reputation to who they are, and who they become? In the city that never sleeps, with millions of people vying to make their mark, we've all had to evaluate our place and position in this world. Reputation Control presents two plays that deal with this very question, a question that everyone struggles with, and a question that must be asked- Am I as I am perceived? 

THE PLAYS:

Feedback, by Jane Miller, is a play from our 2011 Winter Reading Lab now being presented as a full-production. Feedback is the story of Holly, a woman whose personal life and unrealized goals lead her to seek rebranding. What will Perceptions recommend so that Holly can reach her full market value?

AND

The Tragedie of Cardenio, by Ben Bartolone, award winner at the 2010 Midtown International Theater Festival.The Tragedie of Cardenio introduces us to Jeffrey Rome who has the life every aspiring celebrity writer dreams about: all of the fame and none of the respect. After finding Shakespeare's lost play, Jeffrey must choose between critical acclaim and something much bigger


The Impact

Squeaky Bicycle Productions is fueled by a hunger to create new and exciting work in the city we love. We are committed to supporting, encouraging, and providing opportunities to the many brilliant playwrights, actors, and creators who are the lifeblood of NYC Theatre.  We strive to provide an outlet for Emerging Artists to explore new works through development and performance; utilizing professional actors, directors, and designers with a collaborative and innovative mind set.

We're in our second season, and we're dedicated to conitinuing our reputation of doing quality work with exceptional artists. The best way to do that? Show our patrons what great work we're capable of! Reputation Control will be entertaining and thought provoking theatre - presenting the very best that Squeaky Bicycle Productions has to offer. Please help us continue the journey of our artists and our company.

We hope you'll see the show, and see what your donation helped make happen!


What We Need & What You Get

The production is happening soon, and the money we raise through our campaign can take care of some of the production costs associated with presenting TWO full length plays in Rep:

  • Rehearsal Space- $750
  • Printing and Advertising- $250

Additional support will move the play forward to the next level:

  • Additional Set Design Elements- $300
  • Video Production- $400
  • Publicity and PR team- $1,000

(Any amount we raise will go directly to production costs for Reputation Control: Emerging Playwrights' Rep)


THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FOR YOUR SUPPORT! 

Every dollar counts!

Other Ways You Can Help

Do you have materials that you think we could use, or a special knack for design or production? Please let us know. We are always expanding our list of Squeaky Bike volunteers and we'd love if you would join us!

story:
Our Story

Founded in 2011 7 Hills Improv sought to bring Chicago style Improv to Southwest Virginia. Using his Chicago Improv training Neal Tosi(Executive Director) held two workshops with Lynchburg College graduate Ashley Byrne to seek out company members. We found our ensemble and hit the road. Playing a bar here and there we rehearsed and perfected our team. As time went on we discovered that we had developed our own style that reflected our Virginia roots. A style influenced by the great Improv theaters of Chicago and Neal's training but with a look and feel all its own. As Neal went back to training in Chicago Beverly Owens stepped in as Director. Adding a style and flair all her own 7 Hills went on to start to play multiple venues and theater festivals. Continuing to break new ground 7 Hills has now expanded to cover in school workshops and performances.

The Impact

We impact Virginia in several ways. We draw in tourist, boost awareness of the arts in schools with no drama programs and elevate the learning experience of those with active drama departments, provide entertainment and education in the arts to our community and beyond, and give a theatrical outlet through Improv to Southwest Virginia. We see the possibilities of Improv as endless from flash mobs to our classic Improv shows. We hope to spread our unique style of comedy all over.

What We Need & What You Get

We need MONEY! From costumes to rental fees keeping funny and current can be an expensive proposition. We are looking for a permanent space to rehearse, hold workshops, and perform. The money donated will go directly to helping to pay rent on a location, advertising materials for our Improv Education program, and basic set pieces and costumes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on facebook @7 Hills Improv and share our indiegogo page!

story:
*Note: Above is a demo of my work- It would be lovely if you would take the time to take a look!


My Story

        I'm a high school student. I worry about the same things other students of my age do, like turning in assignments on time, making friends, and getting along with my sibling. I also look forward to the same things other students do, such as time with friends and days off of school. However, everyone is unique, and has different interests. Mine is the circus.
         I was a gymnast for nine years, then discovered a circus camp where I lived. Through the camp, I gained a new passion, and later joined the youth troupe. Through performing with the troupe, I began to live and breathe circus. On average, I spend a total of 11-15 hours a week at the circus, whether it be rehearsing, training, performing, or teaching. Over the past couple of years, I have decided that I want to devote my life to it. It's gone beyond enjoyment, recreation, or even competition. I know that when I graduate high school in two years, I want to perform and teach- I would even love to earn a contract with Cirque du Soleil.
         Here's the problem: I've been chasing this dream for about four years now. Unfortunately, I don't have the resources around me to achieve my goal; There is no height in the ceilings, there are no tumble traks or harnesses, or spring floors. What I would really love to do is go to a school in Canada closely connected to Cirque Du Soleil, intensively train there for a couple of weeks, and gather the skills and knowledge I need to make my dream possible. However, a project like this is terribly expensive, and I need your help. 

The Impact

Simply put, if you donate to my cause, you help me to achieve my dreams. Everyone can be a dreamer, and if you are passionate enough about your dreams, they can come true. The circus is my passion, and I want to turn this into my life. Even if I don't make enough to cover the full cost of a trip to Montreal, I will be able to put whatever I make to good use. All of my proceeds will go towards training like this. If I don't reach my $1000 goal, and even if I only make under $100, I will be able to pay for one private session with an amazing instructor. And even that means the world to me. 


What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to make $1000 by my sixteenth birthday on May 8th. The cost of the training in Montreal is $1530 in all, and I will try and supplement the rest of what I don't make on my own. The $1000 will get me:

- Housing in Montreal for two weeks

- Intensive training at an incredible circus school

- Food for two weeks

- A priceless experience, and the opportunity to chase my dreams

How's that for a sweet sixteen?


*By helping me out, you'll get some benefits too :D


Please, Please, Please, consider donating to my cause. I'm trying to raise enough money to do something that will change my life- every dollar counts. I understand that donating may be inconvenient, or hard, but all I ask is if you can't donate, that you spread the word. Tell your friends, family, and tumblr followers about it, and help me reach my goal. 


Thank you so much. Even the fact that you have taken time to read this means a lot to me.
story_txt:
*Note: Above is a demo of my work- It would be lovely if you would take the time to take a look!

My Story
        I'm a high school student. I worry about the same things other students of my age do, like turning in assignments on time, making friends, and getting along with my sibling. I also look forward to the same things other students do, such as time with friends and days off of school. However, everyone is unique, and has different interests. Mine is the circus.         I was a gymnast for nine years, then discovered a circus camp where I lived. Through the camp, I gained a new passion, and later joined the youth troupe. Through performing with the troupe, I began to live and breathe circus. On average, I spend a total of 11-15 hours a week at the circus, whether it be rehearsing, training, performing, or teaching. Over the past couple of years, I have decided that I want to devote my life to it. It's gone beyond enjoyment, recreation, or even competition. I know that when I graduate high school in two years, I want to perform and teach- I would even love to earn a contract with Cirque du Soleil.         Here's the problem: I've been chasing this dream for about four years now. Unfortunately, I don't have the resources around me to achieve my goal; There is no height in the ceilings, there are no tumble traks or harnesses, or spring floors. What I would really love to do is go to a school in Canada closely connected to Cirque Du Soleil, intensively train there for a couple of weeks, and gather the skills and knowledge I need to make my dream possible. However, a project like this is terribly expensive, and I need your help. 
The Impact
Simply put, if you donate to my cause, you help me to achieve my dreams. Everyone can be a dreamer, and if you are passionate enough about your dreams, they can come true. The circus is my passion, and I want to turn this into my life. Even if I don't make enough to cover the full cost of a trip to Montreal, I will be able to put whatever I make to good use. All of my proceeds will go towards training like this. If I don't reach my $1000 goal, and even if I only make under $100, I will be able to pay for one private session with an amazing instructor. And even that means the world to me.

- Food for two weeks
- A priceless experience, and the opportunity to chase my dreams
How's that for a sweet sixteen?

story:
Odradek is producing Bruckner's PAINS OF YOUTH in Oracle B*Sides - a program designed to expand the offering of free art to the community in Public Access Theatre. Our proposal was selected to participate in the B*Sides because of its high quality and compelling content. This production will be a unique experience for theater-goers from every walk of life, and it won't cost anyone anything to see it. Join us! Help us make free art for all!

Our production of Pains of Youth will be completely free for everyone to see, which is awesome, but this means we will not be making any profit. We need your assistance to help us raise money for the show expenses, and have some pocket change afterwards so we can continue on into our 2013/14 season. Donating to the project is your way of helping a young, up-and-coming company continue to achieve their dreams, and you will be assisting to give free art to Chicago.

Opens Saturday, September 21, 2013
Through Saturday, October 13, 2013.

@ Oracle Theatre
3809 N Broadway St.  
Chicago, IL 60613
publicaccesstheatre.org

Synopsis:
Promiscuous, pitiless and bored, six sexually entangled medical students restlessly wander in and out of a boarding house, studying, drinking, taunting, spying. Freder sets about savagely experimenting with the young, pretty maid, with half an eye on his former lover Desiree, a wild, disillusioned aristocrat. Petrell abandons Marie for the ruthless underdog Irene. Marie doesn’t waste any time weeping – Desiree wants her. This discontented post-war generation diagnose youth to be their sickness and do their best to destroy it. Bourgeois existence or suicide; there are no other options.

Director Josh Altman is the Literary Manager of Redtwist and whose directing credits include The Glass Menagerie, with Redtwist, Iphigeneia at Aulis , with Lights out Theatre Company and The Narrows with Red Tape. Josh has had the pleasure of assisting directors like David Cromer, Pam MacKinnon, Charles Newell and William Brown at Steppenwolf, Court, Writers' and TimeLine.
We’re pretty jazzed to be working with him.

Our history:
Since Odradek’s inception in 2010, we have mounted several popular arts festivals and full productions of Bert Royal’s Dog Sees God, Brigham Mosely’s Pretty, Smart, Poetic, and Charles Mee’s Paradise Park. This February, we were fortunate to host Brigham Mosely during the Midwestern tour of his one man show Mo[u]rnin’. After: a mythic autobiography for the queer prodigal son.


Poster credit to Od company members Kat Quintian and Jonathen Wikholm

www.odradektheatre.com

story:
Friends,

Today, on my 29th birthday (June 30th!), the world gave to me:

1. Two flying waterbugs in my apartment.  Thank you New York.

2. An acceptance letter from the Middle East Youth Leadership Jam.  Thank you Middle East Jam screening committee!

3. An even-more-historic-than-Mubarak-times uprising in Egypt, which has restored my hope in the insistence of the Egyptian people to challenge fate, again and again, when it has been unkind.  Thank you, Egyptian people, for restoring my hope in what has otherwise been a bleak year, and for the birthday present!

 

Point number 3 has made me even more happy about point number 2.  It is now, more than ever, exciting to be meeting with other changemakers across the Middle East, and to have the opportunity to build bridges and communicate about the struggles and challenges facing our region.  I am thrilled to have applied and been accepted to this program, whose main purpose is to connect the dots of youth activism across the region. 

The program takes place in Jordan, partly in Amman and partly in the Wadi Rum desert.

How you can help.

Alas, money does not grow on palm trees, though give the Egyptians enough time and they might figure that shit out.  Until then, I am in need of funds to make my participation in the program an actual reality, to cover the travel expenses and program fees.  Here is where, friends, your generosity and potential guilt for forgetting to call me on my birthday, if applicable, come in.

Here is what I am hoping to fund:

  • Airfare to Jordan and back. (around $1,200)
  • Funds for the program itself. (up to $1,500)

I am trying to raise $2,250 (after indiegogo fees, that actually comes out just over $2,000), which won't cover the entire cost of the program, but will BE AN ENORMOUS HELP.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution in any way is appreciated, whether it be fiscal or otherwise.  If you can't contribute by funding the campaign, feel free to share, get a rich uncle to donate in your stead, or to save up the amount you would have contributed and give it to me in hug-currency instead, the next time I see you.

story:
You were there.  You saw what we can do.

You came to Gibson's private NYC Showroom on March 4th and you saw VERY VERY get born.   And we're still so grateful that you were there. Because it was a hell of a life-changing experience and it wouldn't have been the same without you. With a little help from a few generous friends and relatives, we ponied up the cash ourselves and made that thing happen.  We had an incredible time and we've been pounding the pavement with this thing all year.  Our opportunity to take our next big step is here and we need your help to make it happen.

Or maybe you saw Duke's Band play Studio 6 and you wanna see more of this VERY VERY.

You love theatre and you love rock and roll and you didn't know anything about us until we brought you into the legendary Studio 6 to see Duke's Band play with The Lobbyists and Supermajor.  We had a blast that night playing a bunch of songs from VERY VERY and now we're full speed ahead.  With your support, we can make it happen.

Or you caught us at Fresh Ground Pepper NYC's Birthday Party last year.  Or at the Deconstructive Theatre Project in Bushwick.

And you want to support innovative, cutting edge music theatre created with the sensibilities of the artistic community that you're a part of.

However you've heard of us, be you U-Melt fan, Shakespeare kid, or average pedestrian, we've got a sold out concert reading on Dec 9th that we need to pay for.

Well, yes!  Sold out with free seats!  It's another staged reading and free of charge, so that's that. But seats got reserved in a matter of hours and we still can't believe it.  We want to go to Rahway and kick ass.

  • We're being presented by American Theater Group in a 90 minute concert reading of VERY VERY .  This is Rick Sordelet, Joe Mancuso, and Jim Vagias.  They're a new organization dedicated to the development of new works - musical and classical.  Perfect fit.  A lot of you know at least one of these guys.  And, if you do, you know that they're the real deal.  
  • The idea is to get their business behind us and nail down a run of VERY VERY next Spring at The Hamilton Stage, the brand new state-of-the-art theatre built by Union County Performing Arts Center where ATG produces.
  • We're shooting for 10k. We need to pay our company.  We need to bring in lights and sound to make it great. We need to pay for travel.  We need to feed people. We need to rent vehicles to transport our company and VIPs to the event.  We need to pay our press agent.  We need to pay for publicity.  
  • Also, we're going to produce a high profile NYC concert in early 2014 and we need the cash to start to make that happen.

This is just the beginning.

It's the next step on a very long road.  And we can't do it without you.

story:
Aloha from Hilo Hawaii, Im Mary Chapman. I am an acrobat, and I have an opportunity to go to Montreal to train with some amazing acrobats who are holding a teacher training, and month long intensive, blending acrobatics and yoga  and dance. By attending this training, I will be gaining new inspiration to bring back to teach in classes and workshops all over the Hawaiian Islands, and the Bay Area in California- where I go teach regularly, as well as what other future corners of the globe I will venture. I will have the opportunity to train deeper with Goldie, my acro partner, so we can perform at a more professional level. I will have a focused month of studying this art to refine what I already love, and let it expand to the next level.

I am asking for $4,500. To break that down, the training itself is $2,600. The travel to get there and back will be around $1000 and Im thinking the living expenses for the month will be around $1000. 

Acroyoga is a rare gem that is very unexposed to the public at this time. Anyone who has ever "flown" will be able to tell you how therapeutic and restorative this practice can be. We need the human connection, we need the trust, we need the playful experience that this adventure allows. I dream of bringing this back to share, to allow more people to learn to take a break from their stressful lives and let go, share breath, find balance, and try something new.

If you help support this journey, I will make sure you get your chance to sip the acroyoga elixer, and feel the benefits of this art. I will be offering personalized video tutorials, and personal training services to my contributors. If we are in the same area, I will fly you, I will help you feel the yummy release, and give you the tools you need to share this with your friends, this is just the beginning.

If you could pass this information along to anyone you think might be able to help support the cause, please do. I appreciate your time, and hope that you are loving your life as much as I am...and if you are not, let me know, I can help ;)

story:
Hello. My name is Ellis Linford-Pill and I am a musical theatre student and have just finished my first year at the prestigious school Laine Theatre Arts. I have been involved with dance since the age of 11 and trained at the Jill Stew School of Dance in Witney for many years, after which I was offered a place at Laine with a scholarship. Unfortunately, a few weeks ago, the housing benefit I received to pay for my rent was taken away after a higher court ruling, causing me to find £4000 a year myself. As I don't have this kind of money, and am not entitled to any kind of student loan, I am setting up this campaign to help me raise money to keep me in my training for the next two years.

This campaign is extremely important to me, as it may mean whether I complete my training or not. I have worked extremely hard and am very proud of where I have got so far, and to lose my vital training due to lack of money would be extremely upsetting for me, my family and everyone who has helped me get to where I am.

With this training at Laine, I could go on to perform worldwide in many different areas such as the West End, UK and World tours, television, music and many more places like many past students have gone on to do. So completing this training could get me in to my dream career and carry me on to be successful in the musical theatre industry.

I need to raise as close to £8760 as I can get, as this is the cost of my rent for the next two years. However, if I do not achieve this target, the money raised will still be extremely helpful in helping me to stay on at Laine for as long as I can. Any amount donated, however small, will be very helpful for my campaign and I will be extremely grateful.

Any help in getting this campaign heard would be very helpful, so if possible I would ask to share it on social media sites and any other ideas you may have.

Thanks very much in taking time to read this, I am extremely grateful for any help you can give.

Thanks very much, Ellis

story:
Like us on Facebook for sexy updates and viral happiness!

The play

“Scenes of a Sexual Nature” is mostly based on a series of seven loosely related stories of couples in Hampstead Heath Park in north London. The scenes appear out of sequence and jump back and forth between one story and another. Sex and love. Some seek it, some need it, some spurn it and some pay for it, but we’re all involved in it.

There are two amazing stories on this play besides the one written. The first is how we actually got to make this play happen, and the second, how we got the venue where we are performing it.

First.

In 2010, I watched the movie “Scenes of a Sexual Nature.” I thought it would be a brilliant theater play, checked it out and found out it was an original script from Aschlin Ditta. I did my research and contacted his agent to ask for the rights of the play to adapt it to theater in Spanish, because my clout is stronger in Venezuela, which is my home country, Argentina, Colombia and Spain. That began almost two years of sending emails back and forth with no outcome. In 2012, very frustrated, I decided to look for Mr. Ditta himself via Twitter. I’ve been in the online marketing and social media industry for many years — that’s what I do. I found two Aschlin Dittas, one of whom happened to be the one, and within a day I had the development agreement in my hands. THANK YOU SOCIAL MEDIA! I adapted Ditta’s movie script into a play, and it was ready to be produced in 2013.

Last year my marketing agency, the Mini Agency, shifted to being a resource-based agency. That means we provide clients with our online marketing services, and they provide us with their resources. In some cases, money is another resource.

And here comes the second …

Second.

In June 2013, I started working with Teatro SEA as their marketing director, and the resource-based deal we worked out was for us to give them our services in exchange for two months a year in their theater. This new variable led me to readapt the play into English to produce it in New York City at SEA. Aschlin Ditta agreed, and voila!

Teatro SEA has an amazing three-year-old space in Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Pictures below!

Why we are in Indiegogo?

Producing this play has been a collaborative effort between actors, crew and production team. Because the theater is being paid with the Mini Agency’s services, we did not need money upfront to book the space, but like every production, we have expenses to cover.

As we strongly believe in the power of collaboration and the willingness of nice people, we believe there is nothing better than crowdfunding to go through this experience.

This play costs a lot more money than $6,000 to produce, but because of our deal, this is what we need to break even. This amount will be used to cover some of the production expenses, including scenery, salaries and marketing.

Our experiment is to show people that under the collaboration wing, we all win. When we started producing this play, we wanted to do an Equity Showcase — we found plenty of bureaucracy, money requirements and less-than-fair policies behind Equity’s protocol. So, because “life is about creating yourself,” we asked ourselves, “Can’t we do this by tapping into our networks? Is it possible to build a production supported by regular, everyday people and make our living out of it?” To all these questions, our answer was YES, and here we are. Every penny we make will be split among actors, crew and production team. We have created perks for every actor to encourage their friends and family to contribute to their craft.

Expenses and Budget

Cast

The Stage


Goals

“Scenes of a Sexual Nature” has been a long and amazing process. Our goal is to make people ask questions of themselves about basic human relationships, the purpose of life and happiness.

Therefore, our work does not end here — we are looking forward into the future. We are planning on taking this play to the Fringe Festival during the summer with a larger budget and more experience under our belts.

Benefits for backers.

$1 SUPPORT THE ARTS! :)

$5 Happiness Supporter: Thank you! Happiness and gratitude already conquered you :D and we’ll show it on a Facebook post and with a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$10 Forever Sexy: Oh yes! With your donation, you’ll get a “Forever Sexy” sticker and our gratitude and happiness forever + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$20 Promotion on Social Media: Big crew, big network! With your donation, you’ll get a promoted post on our networks that will expose your project, organization and/or company to more than 1,000 people in New York City and more than 15,000 people worldwide + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$30 Buy Your Ticket: Watch the play! If you want more than one ticket add 30$ per extra ticket, i.e. 90$=3 tickets. With your donation, you’ll get tickets to join us in the Lower East Side for a night of laughs, sexiness and a bit of drama + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$50 Give It Up for Olivia! Joe! Beatriz! Greg! Natalie! Jason! Amy! Bill! Joan! and Eddie!: You are a good Samaritan! With your donation, you’ll contribute directly to the actors’ salary, get a ticket to watch the play and a bottle of red wine! + a poster signed by the whole cast + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$60 Buy Your Ticket + Wine!: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get a ticket to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$80 Buy 2 Tickets + Wine!: Cheers! With your donation you’ll get two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.

$1000 Associate Producer: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get an Associate Producer credit, two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a poster signed by the whole cast, the writer and the director + a “Forever Sexy” sticker.

$2500 Executive Producer: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get an Executive Producer credit, two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a poster signed by the whole cast, the writer and the director + a “Forever Sexy” sticker.

Risks and Challenges.

As in any other production, our biggest challenge is to produce a high-quality play with limited resources. We’ve been struggling to set everything up, but we have a committed team and really good friends who are willing and able to help by contributing to our show.
story_txt: Like us on Facebook for sexy updates and viral happiness!The play“Scenes of a Sexual Nature” is mostly based on a series of seven loosely related stories of couples in Hampstead Heath Park in north London. The scenes appear out of sequence and jump back and forth between one story and another. Sex and love. Some seek it, some need it, some spurn it and some pay for it, but we’re all involved in it.There are two amazing stories on this play besides the one written. The first is how we actually got to make this play happen, and the second, how we got the venue where we are performing it.First.In 2010, I watched the movie “Scenes of a Sexual Nature.” I thought it would be a brilliant theater play, checked it out and found out it was an original script from Aschlin Ditta. I did my research and contacted his agent to ask for the rights of the play to adapt it to theater in Spanish, because my clout is stronger in Venezuela, which is my home country, Argentina, Colombia and Spain. That began almost two years of sending emails back and forth with no outcome. In 2012, very frustrated, I decided to look for Mr. Ditta himself via Twitter. I’ve been in the online marketing and social media industry for many years — that’s what I do. I found two Aschlin Dittas, one of whom happened to be the one, and within a day I had the development agreement in my hands. THANK YOU SOCIAL MEDIA! I adapted Ditta’s movie script into a play, and it was ready to be produced in 2013.Last year my marketing agency, the Mini Agency, shifted to being a resource-based agency. That means we provide clients with our online marketing services, and they provide us with their resources. In some cases, money is another resource.And here comes the second …Second.In June 2013, I started working with Teatro SEA as their marketing director, and the resource-based deal we worked out was for us to give them our services in exchange for two months a year in their theater. This new variable led me to readapt the play into English to produce it in New York City at SEA. Aschlin Ditta agreed, and voila!Teatro SEA has an amazing three-year-old space in Manhattan’s Lower East Side. Pictures below!Why we are in Indiegogo?Producing this play has been a collaborative effort between actors, crew and production team. Because the theater is being paid with the Mini Agency’s services, we did not need money upfront to book the space, but like every production, we have expenses to cover.As we strongly believe in the power of collaboration and the willingness of nice people, we believe there is nothing better than crowdfunding to go through this experience.This play costs a lot more money than $6,000 to produce, but because of our deal, this is what we need to break even. This amount will be used to cover some of the production expenses, including scenery, salaries and marketing.Our experiment is to show people that under the collaboration wing, we all win. When we started producing this play, we wanted to do an Equity Showcase — we found plenty of bureaucracy, money requirements and less-than-fair policies behind Equity’s protocol. So, because “life is about creating yourself,” we asked ourselves, “Can’t we do this by tapping into our networks? Is it possible to build a production supported by regular, everyday people and make our living out of it?” To all these questions, our answer was YES, and here we are. Every penny we make will be split among actors, crew and production team. We have created perks for every actor to encourage their friends and family to contribute to their craft.Expenses and BudgetCastThe StageGoals“Scenes of a Sexual Nature” has been a long and amazing process. Our goal is to make people ask questions of themselves about basic human relationships, the purpose of life and happiness.Therefore, our work does not end here — we are looking forward into the future. We are planning on taking this play to the Fringe Festival during the summer with a larger budget and more experience under our belts.Benefits for backers.$1 SUPPORT THE ARTS! :)$5 Happiness Supporter: Thank you! Happiness and gratitude already conquered you :D and we’ll show it on a Facebook post and with a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$10 Forever Sexy: Oh yes! With your donation, you’ll get a “Forever Sexy” sticker and our gratitude and happiness forever + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$20 Promotion on Social Media: Big crew, big network! With your donation, you’ll get a promoted post on our networks that will expose your project, organization and/or company to more than 1,000 people in New York City and more than 15,000 people worldwide + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$30 Buy Your Ticket: Watch the play! If you want more than one ticket add 30$ per extra ticket, i.e. 90$=3 tickets. With your donation, you’ll get tickets to join us in the Lower East Side for a night of laughs, sexiness and a bit of drama + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$50 Give It Up for Olivia! Joe! Beatriz! Greg! Natalie! Jason! Amy! Bill! Joan! and Eddie!: You are a good Samaritan! With your donation, you’ll contribute directly to the actors’ salary, get a ticket to watch the play and a bottle of red wine! + a poster signed by the whole cast + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$60 Buy Your Ticket + Wine!: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get a ticket to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$80 Buy 2 Tickets + Wine!: Cheers! With your donation you’ll get two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a “Forever Sexy” sticker + a “thank you” in our Facebook page.$1000 Associate Producer: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get an Associate Producer credit, two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a poster signed by the whole cast, the writer and the director + a “Forever Sexy” sticker.$2500 Executive Producer: Cheers! With your donation, you’ll get an Executive Producer credit, two tickets to watch the play and a bottle of red wine to enjoy as you watch! + a poster signed by the whole cast, the writer and the director + a “Forever Sexy” sticker.Risks and Challenges.As in any other production, our biggest challenge is to produce a high-quality play with limited resources. We’ve been struggling to set everything up, but we have a committed team and really good friends who are willing and able to help by contributing to our show.

story:
Who We Are and What We Do

The Wild Rumpus Theatre Development Group (TWR) is a not-for-profit New York based ensemble of professional artists and managers. Led by Artistic Director Steve Wargo and Managing Director Jennifer America, TWR is dedicated to fundamentally changing the way theater is made by throwing our entire focus on the long-form development of new pieces of theatrical entertainment.

In short: we don't seek to produce the plays we create. We do seek to take the necessary time (and often, it's a very long time) in the writer's room and rehearsal studio to incubate and build pieces from the ground-up through trial and a lot of errors. When, and only when, a piece has survived our rigorous development process will we present a "blueprint" version of the work to the public and our industry in the hopes that the product we have painstakingly developed will find a future life on the commercial or professional nonprofit stage.

We obsess about our process so that, in time, the right people can obsess about our product. This is a very novel concept in the top-down, product-driven theater market that is NYC. It can work. It will work. In the short term, though, generosity is key.

What We Need

Our business model is very simple and our overhead is quite low for the amount of work we have planned for 2014. Our current operating expenses are comprised of startup and business maintenance costs, rehearsal studio rental, and artists stipends. The amount of work we can accomplish is limited only by the amount of money we can raise throughout the year. Our first major fundraising goal is set at $8,500. This will cover our startup costs and provide workshops through December 2013, at which time we will have presented to the public our development process and announced our workshops for 2014.

Your Gift and Its Impact

A gift to The Wild Rumpus is more than X-hours of studio rental or subway fare for our artists or keeping our website live. It's a vote of confidence in our approach, our passion and our philosophy. Your contribution to our work will make a lasting impression in changing the way plays are made. You can literally buy us the time we need to collaborate as fully as we possibly can in as safe an environment as we can build, and in return, allow us to deliver something extraordinary to the world.

Other Ways to Help 

Spread the word about The Rumpus by following the links below for our Facebook and Twitter pages and website.

Your contribution can also come in the form of complimentary studio space and script printing by emailing us at jen@wildrumpusnyc.com.

story:
Who We Are

We are the fourteen of fourteen. We are—

Jared Allen, Tyler Alverson, Kate Conway, Colin Gardner, Emily Guernsey, Keith Hale, Katherine Jones, Caroline Klidonas, Winston Koone, Emily Merlin, Chet Norment, Emily Tryon, Victoria Webster, Kym Zlogar

...and we need your help. 

Why We Are Fundraising

We work in a highly competitive industry. Come senior year, it is important for us to network with as many people in the professional performing arts world as possible. We are all in love with what we do, and passionate about our art. But to be able to continue to do what we love we must get the job first! We are raising money for two things:

  • Our public Senior Showcase on November 15 and 16 with invited industry professionals from the Southeast.
  • Our private sessions with invited professionals: A casting director and an agent from each coast: Los Angeles and New York City.

Putting up a show can be costly, but bringing in important people costs even more.  To bring in our four selected agents and casting directors, we will need $8,000. That's $2,000 a head, and well worth it. We will have face time with people that can help us begin a career in the big, scary real world. We will take classes and work intimately with these people, as well as perform our showcase material for them, providing us with an invaluable experience.

Please know that we are doing everything in our power to fundraise! We have been very lucky in our events so far, and have more events set up throughout the year. Here are some other ways we are fundraising:

  • Profit shares with local businesses
  • Car washes
  • Merchandise such as tumblers, t-shirts, and DRAMA sunglasses
  • Bakesales
  • Games such as Assassins
  • ... and more!

Your Impact

By raising enough money to reach our goal, we will be able to bring in two representatives in the performing arts business from each coast. This unique experience will allow us to have face time with, work with, and perform for industry professionals who can help us obtain jobs following graduation. In other words, are helping out the future Hollywood and Broadway stars of the next generation!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are strapped for cash, as sometimes we all are, please take the time to post our Indiegogo link on your Facebook or Twitter page to share it with friends and family. Every person that sees this could take us even one dollar closer to our goal. Every cent matters!

Thank you for your time and your donation!

story:
Our Story

In June, a major flood devastated the city of Calgary. The Improv Guild, a not for profit theatre society, was caught in the middle of the disaster. Our home, the Impro Depot, was filled with river water for days leaving behind inches of thick, muddy sludge. Thanks to countless volunteers, we survived. But we sustained more than $20,000 in damages and losses. We are seeking financial support in the amount of $5,000. This amount will help cover the costs of rebuilding our studio and the replacement of assets essential to our programming. We’re not asking for the entirety of what we lost, just enough to get us back on our feet. Any help is truly appreciated.

This flood hit us at a really hard time. September marks our 10th anniversary as an organization. As a result we had been planning to significantly increase programming and celebrate the success of our small, hardworking arts organization. Because of this flood everything is up in the air.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking $5000 in support to help cover the costs of:

  1. Cleaning supplies, paint, drywall and building supplies
  2. Ruined furniture such as couches, shelves and tables
  3. The cost of 2 refrigerators that were lost
  4. Ruined speakers and other electronic equipment
  5. Replacement of props and costumes

In return, we are offering the following perks depending on your level of support:

  1. Invitation to volunteer and donor appreciation show
  2. Free tickets to Boardwalk Calgary Improv Festival
  3. A plaque on our studio wall with your name on it

If we do not meet our fundraising goal any donations will still be used as outlined above.

Be a flood angel. Even $10 will go a long way to help.

Why this Campaign is Important

In 2003 the Improv Guild formed as a small grassroots artists cooperative. At the heart of the organisation are the ideals of support, creativity and community. Years later these ideals are still essential to our operation but our reach has grown. We produce the Boardwalk Calgary Improv Festival, which brings performers from all over the globe to Calgary. Hundreds of students have gone through our improv school. We also now have a strong youth component to our company, having produced an annual high school improv championship for the last two years as well. But all of this programming centres around our home, a humble studio at 2405 MacLeod Tr. S which was innondated by the water of the Elbow river.

We are passionate about telling great stories and making people laugh. Please help us do that again. Calgary needs laughter right now.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us the spread the word on twitter, facebook and beyond.

Visit our websites: www.improvguild.com and www.calgaryimprovfestival.com. Find out about what we do and what we mean to the Calgary community.

story:
CRITICAL POINT THEATRE: We aim to resonate

We aim... to function as a public forum for community conversation in order to maintain a thriving local democracy.

We aim... to be present and engaged in our community—whatever that is—as an ensemble of dedicated local artists

Please consider supporting The Pavilion, the first performance independently produced by Critical Point Theatre, a new ensemble founded by Julia Katz, Alexander Burns, and Deborah Cline. As young artists, we want to make passionate, professional, and engaged performance that has immediate resonance with our local audience in Virginia and nationwide.

We're self-motivated and want to dive right into performance as creators of new work and cultivators of classical and contemporary performances.

Learn more about us at criticalpointtheatre.com!

 

WHY THE PAVILION?

The Pavilion is a contemporary play from renowned writer CRAIG WRIGHT (Recent Tragic Events), about TIME, from the beginning of the Universe all the way to the individual minutes of each persons life. The Pavilion is a play about maturation and regret, as two battle-weary individuals wonder if it's possible to erase their scars.

 

The play tells the story of Peter (Wilson Murphy) and Kari (Kelsey Secules), former high school flames whose relationship ended sourly when Peter coldly walked out on Kari upon learning that she was pregnant. The two meet decades later at their high school reunion, and Peter has one night to confront his past.  The curious and powerful Narrator (Matthew Schott) leads the confused couple on an unforgettable evening.

 

We chose to present The Pavilion as our first show because Wright's simple storytelling conceit let us focus our attention on exploring the magnetic language of the script. We love this script. As young artists exploring our own maturity and growth over the last few years, we can relate to the driving force to right past wrongs (can't everybody?).  

 

THE SHOW DATES: 

PREVIEWS: JUNE 28-29 @ 7:30 PM JUNE 30 @ 3 PM

Warm Hearth Village Center: 2603 Warm Hearth Drive, Blacksburg VA 24060 $10 General Admission/Special Admission for Warm Hearth Residents

 

JULY 5-6 @7:30 PM JULY 7 @ 3 PM 

DC Arts Center: 2438 18th Street NW, $20 General Admission/$15 students, DCAC members

 

JULY 12-13 @ 7:30 PM JULY 13 @ 2 PM

June M. McBroom Theatre: 302 Campbell Avenue SE, Roanoke, VA 24013

$15 General Admission/FREE Community High students

 

JULY 26-27 @ 7:30 PM

EMP Collective: 307 West Baltimore Street, Baltimore, MD 21201

$20 General Admission/$15 students

 

WHY DONATE?

Critical Point Theatre is a small ensemble managed by three early twentysomethings fresh from Virginia Tech. We managed to cobble some funds for "The Pavilion" independently, but would love not to drive our company straight into debt. Your contribution would help us focus on creating the best theatre experience possible, instead of worrying about our bank account.

What will your generous contribution actually go towards? First and foremost:

  • PERFORMANCE SPACE –The $1,300 we’ve asked for will go towards the money we've spent on securing our performance spaces. While we've sought out extremely economical venues, renting professional stages in four cities is still a significant expense.

Any money we raise PAST our $1,300 goal will go towards:

  • CAST AND CREW STIPENDS – Critical Point Theatre is committed to paying our artists for their time and energy.  Theatre is our profession, and that means rewarding our professionals.
  • PRODUCTION COSTS -- The Pavilion calls for design elements, and this money would fund our props, scenic elements, and practical lighting instruments.
  • PUBLICITY – No production is complete without an audience, and getting The Pavilion out to as many people as possible requires publicity.  Our publicity plans include postcards, flyers, and posters for each city, as well as print and social media, and additional money would help us create more, higher quality materials.

 

WE WANT TO INVOLVE YOU!

We understand that not everybody can contribute financially, but you CAN still help contribute to the launch of Critical Point Theatre and this production. If you're looking to get involved, here are a few suggestions:

  • Can you envision collaboration with your workplace or business? We'd love to help you with our skills as storytellers and artists in exchange for advertising space, goods or services, etc. Let us know how we can help!
  • Are you an artist? We're looking for theatre artists and passionate community members to join us in our adventure. Please get in touch!
  • Want to give us some advice? As emerging artists, we're looking for all of the artistic, financial, and legal advice we can get. If you have access to any of these resources and would be willing to help, we'd appreciate it!

AND MOST OF ALL, SPREAD THE WORD

  • Visit our website!
  • Like us on Facebook!
  • Follow us on Twitter!

Let your friends and coworkers know about us!

CAST AND CREW STIPENDS – Critical Point Theatre is committed to paying our artists for their time and energy.  Theatre is our profession, and that means rewarding our professionals.

PRODUCTION COSTS -- The Pavilion calls for design elements, and this money would fund our props, scenic elements, and practical lighting instruments.

PUBLICITY – No production is complete without an audience, and getting The Pavilion out to as many people as possible requires publicity.  Our publicity plans include postcards, flyers, and posters for each city, as well as print and social media, and additional money would help us create more, higher quality materials.

 
WE WANT TO INVOLVE YOU!
We understand that not everybody can contribute financially, but you CAN still help contribute to the launch of Critical Point Theatre and this production. If you're looking to get involved, here are a few suggestions:


Can you envision collaboration with your workplace or business? We'd love to help you with our skills as storytellers and artists in exchange for advertising space, goods or services, etc. Let us know how we can help!

Are you an artist? We're looking for theatre artists and passionate community members to join us in our adventure. Please get in touch!

Want to give us some advice? As emerging artists, we're looking for all of the artistic, financial, and legal advice we can get. If you have access to any of these resources and would be willing to help, we'd appreciate it!

AND MOST OF ALL, SPREAD THE WORD

Visit our website!
Like us on Facebook!
Follow us on Twitter!

Let your friends and coworkers know about us!

story:
My Story

I am sixteen and I have been dancing since I was ten years old. I got a late start (most dancers start when they're three) but I caught on quickly and became passionate about pursuing a career in dance. I worked extremely hard (you'd know if you saw my feet) and excelled greatly in a short amount of time. 

The moment I knew I wanted to have a career in dance came when I was 15 years old. I injured my foot and was unable to dance for five months. It was torture. When I finally healed, I decided that I never wanted there to be a day in my life where I didn't dance. It is part of who I am and I never want to lose that.

What I'm Asking

I would appreciate your help in raising funds to help me attend the American Dance Festival. It is a six week summer dance intensive that I feel is valuable to my growth as a dancer. It is intensive enough to make up for the few years I lost before I started dancing, and the five months I lost while I was injured. It will also help me make connections in the dance world. This program will help my growth as a person, as an dancer, and as an artist.

What I Need

The entire intensive, tuition and room/board, costs approx. $3200. I am only asking for $1600 here, half the cost, but I appreciate all I can get. I auditioned for a scholarship which I am hoping will help cover the rest. I need some help raising money to meet the expenses. I cannot afford it without your help. I appreciate any donation, however small. 

The Impact

Without this $1600, I will not be able to attend this program and it will be difficult to find this training somewhere else; it is impossible to find such a high level program at a lower cost. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to my campaign, please sprend the word. That will help me reach more potential donors. Thank you.
