story:
This will be the first year that The Recruits are going to Vegas to compete and we are so excited! We are especially happy that even though this small group of young and dedicated dancers has only been together as a crew for less than a year, we have already accomplished so much and have even been chosen to be one of the teams representing Canada in the Adult Division for Hip Hop International 2013.

With travelling outside of the province for competitions, brings some financial struggles when it comes to the plane tickets, hotel room, registration fees & food as some of us in the dance team are still students and only working part-time. 

Please support us on our journey to make our debut on an international stage! Every little bit counts!

Even if you aren't able to donate, please spread the word and share this project through the power of social media and word of mouth to help us reach our goal!!

story:
THE PROJECT

These two short shows were originally developed for Dixon Place theatre on New York's Lower East Side and have undergone considerable revision since then: “3 Lies about Brooklyn” centres on Farrell's troubled childhood and the discovery that he was one of Ireland’s notorious Magdalene Laundry babies shipped to the US under the auspices of one of the Catholic Church’s uglier institutions.  Adopted at 3 and a half by dysfunctional working class Irish couple in Brooklyn, this is a story of Dickensian Orphanages, sexual abuse and the shadowy corruption of the Church herself.  It is also largely comic.   The second half of the bill is the latest in Farrell's ongoing "Walt Whitman: Time Traveler" series and focuses on Walt Whitman and his Irish born “comerado” (ie, lover) Peter Doyle and their banter as they pretend one day, to complete the visit to Ireland which was cancelled after Whitman's first stroke in 1873,

WHY WE EXPERIENCED A FUNDING SHORTFALL AT THE LAST MINUTE

The idea of bringing these shows to Ireland was first suggested by the late Gordon Campbell whose independent arts organization, The Academy of Everything is Possible had agreed to underwrite that visit in part.  Sadly, Mr. Campbell passed in early June, after the theatre, plane tickets etc had been booked.  With no clear provision left with his estate, Farrell now finds himself well short of the funds needed to realise this project.

Despite having already raised $4,000, we are still experiencing a shortfall critical shortfall - the gap created by the sudden death of our sponsor.  Raising this $1500 will go a long way towards closing that gap!

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE SPENT

The  $1500 here would be used to cover related transport, printing and production costs, as well as a few meals for the crew (all of whom have agreed to pitch in pro bono in light of the immediate crisis.)  No one is expecting to make any money on this tour, so your assist here will go a long way to augmenting the Box Office and keeping the producers as out of the red as possible.

THE PERKS

Our perks are all reasonably priced and will allow each supporter to experience the show either alive on opening night or on video, after the fact.  The most modestly priced perk ($4) is like buying a coffee at the interval - a small one at that!

WHY THIS CAMPAIGN MATTERS

 These two one acts (Walt Whitman in Ireland and 3 Lies About Brooklyn) need to be seen in Ireland.  The first because it affirms the unique inspiration Whitman’s poetry gave to the nationalist struggle:  that it was Ireland that fully embraced Whitman’s conviction that democracy was a moral necessity.  That contribution has been neglected due to the efforts of Lady Gregory and WB Yeats to corrupt the original ambitions of the Irish Literary Revival (which was a forward looking and revolutionary campaign) into one of dreamy nostalgia and fairy tales.

The second,  (3 Lies) because the continuing upheaval caused by the revelations of the Ryan Report have made the Magdalene Laundries the subject of theatre and film but never has the story been told from the POV of one of the children who was smuggled abroad and whose identity was erased.

ABOUT JOHN FARRELL AND BROOKDALE ENTERTAINMENT

Farrell is well known to his peers as a pro-active artist, forceful and committed to seeing the projects he starts followed through on and realized.  The original Walt Whitman project at Dixon Place last year (Amorous Wet) of which Walt Whitman in Ireland is built upon, was the result of a successful Kickstarter campaign.  His decision to use Indiegogo is because of its more flexible, user-friendly platform, it’s international reach and the fact that this event is not solely dependent on reaching the target sum (though it “would be sweet” if it did.)

Please give any assistance you can to helping realize this tour at a solid, professional standard.

story:
Short Summary

Resurrection Theatre has been producing quality community theater on a shoestring budget for three years, and honestly, that's just the way we like it. Without big budget sets or technical effects we are able to focus on the heart of each show and the connection it can form for the audience communally.  And, to toot our own horn, we consistently produce 4- and 5-star shows like An Adult Evening of Shel Silverstein, Gruesome Playground Injuries, and Next Fall. But we're hungry for more. From our producers to our volunteer directors, designers, stage crews, and actors, Resurrection Theatre is here  for the love of the art, and we'd like to take our little Theatre Company That Can to a new level, and we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

Why are we asking for $5,500?

Facility Rental and Script Royalties -- No matter how big or small the production,  rent and royalties are always a concern. Meeting our funding goal will make a big dent in that department and allow us to focus more of our resources on bringing you wonderful productions.

Ticket Pricing -- Have you noticed the $5-10 jump in everybody's prices this season? Being able to cover those fixed costs mentioned above without having to worry about making it all up in ticket sales allows us to keep our ticket prices down. Really, donating $5 or $10 now is going to save you $50 in the long run! 

501(c)(3) Non-Profit Registration --  We want your future donations to Resurrection Theatre to be tax deductible! Part of the money we raise during this campaign will be used to pay the filing fee for our 501 (c) (3) application.

Expanding Horizons -- While our vision as a company is that shoestring budgets can yield some amazingly creative and moving stories, sometimes our directors have grand visions which need a grander budget. You would be helping those visions come to life. 

The Impact

We’ve all done it. We have all stood back after seeing something wonderful produced. We have all observed, and pondered, and wished. We have uttered the phrase: “I wish I could do that.”

It is the belief of this company, this family of creative explorers, that art, story, and the general wonder of theatre is not solely upon the shoulders of one person. The wonder of theatre is created by a band of artists. Some see the spotlight and receive accolades and glory. Others operate out of sight, appreciated by those close to the art, but rarely acknowledged by the general audience. All of these people, be they technician or designer or actor...they are all producers. Their efforts bring about the stories told, they produce the breathless moment that we all sit and share. Those people are listed in the programs you hold. You can read their names. Their names in that small booklet proclaim: “I helped to make this moment” 

Resurrection Theatre would like to invite you help create a moment. To become a producer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute to our campaign this time? That's ok! There are other ways to help!

  • HELP US SPREAD THE WORD! Post this on Facebook! Tweet about it! Tell everybody how much you love us and want us to keep on producing awesome theatre that you can afford to see! IndieGoGo makes it super easy for you to share! Just click on the icons over there in the doobly-doo!
  • AUDITION! 
  • VOLUNTEER! We are always looking for stage managers, designers, carpenters, painters, photographers, and pickers to help bring these shows to life. Email us if you would be interested in getting on our list of people to indenture on a future production!

One last note: we hope you enjoyed our video. Four Pillars Production helped us share our campaign and vision with you, free of charge. We’d like to thank Vernon Lewis (ey3king) and Samia LaVerne for their incredible work. Find them at:

Ey3king: http://www.youtube.com/ey3king

Four Pillars Production: http://www.youtube.com/4pillarsproduction

story:
What we need from you: 

BigMix are a completely self-funded theatre group. In order to create something bigger and better this year we are asking for a small amount of money from you to help us.

All the money we make from this campaign will go straight towards the development of our production in Edinburgh. As these shows are not cheap we need as much funding as possible to enable us to be successfull in our endevour to create a new genre of theatre.

About Us:

BigMix are a Leicester based performance troupe that come from a wide range of backgrounds, with a range of skills that allows for a very unique theatrical experience. The core team consists of experts in performing arts and digital media, including designers, an animator, software programmers, a theatrical director, a lighting designer and teachers.

The key principle for the troupe is the need to entertain, inspire and educate. We hope to achieve this in our work by combining traditional theatre with the emerging digital technologies that more and more form a part of our everyday lives.

As a company we class ourselves as amateur as no one is paid for the work they do on the production, but we are able to bring our own work experiences together to develop productions and innovative ideas we are all passionate about.

Following on from the success of our first performance in Edinburgh 2012, for our second group project we want to carry on the research and development of looking into ways to integrate digital art into an existing story. The focus will be on ways that use visual art, music and programming to draw out elements of the narrative, and support the director and actors in the delivery of the performance.

Our aim is to produce a performance that is as accessible as possible to a wide age range of audiences by introducing new opportunities and ideas to the world of theatre. By adapting the story of Red Riding Hood into a script for the stage we will have a strong story line that allows us to be flexible in what we visually create and in doing so be able to produce a great performance with the use of the technology and skills we find most exciting.

We hope you have enjoyed our words and our drawings. We are very excited about the potential scope of this project, and hope you agree.

We want to create something really innovative, that nobody has seen before. Through traditional animation, theatre and digital media, we want to create a world where reality and fantasy are the same thing; where anything is possible through the use of technology and imagination.

Our biggest love and thanks from all the team at BigMix Theatre

story:
Looking For You is a student written play by Stacy Moon, directed by Will Sonheim and produced by Olivia Probetts in association with Vertigo Productions at Northwestern University. It goes up April 25th-27th, 2013. The whole team consists of undergraduate students who are all passionate about creating new and exciting pieces of theatre!

How does one get to know someone all over again when it may be too late? When impossible news regarding their estranged daughter hits their little desert home, George, Helen, and their son Ethan wrestle with one another and themselves to try to understand the girl they seemed to have missed all their lives. The play follows George, Helen, and Ethan as they attempt to cope with the death of their daughter and sister Evie, following her suicide in the Heaven's Gate mass suicide of1997. 

This brand new play throws you into the heat of the California desert in a home suddenly filled with grief and confusion. From the living room of their home, to Ethan's version of outer space, Looking For You explores a family's struggle to come to terms with the girl they lost.

Before Looking For You can open, however, we need your support! We need help creating the world of the play: the costumes, props, lights, sound, and set. Our set is going to be huge! It needs to represent the living room of the house as well as several other locations, including outer space. We're also working to create original stop-motion animations that will be projected to help create our world. Northwestern student theatre relies heavily on outside donations and funding in order to help us achieve our goals, and on behalf of the production team and cast, I am asking you for your help! All money donated towards this will go towards purchasing the best materials possible to create the world of Stacy's play!

This will be the world premiere of Looking For You and will not only provide an outlet to help further strengthen the Northwestern theatre community but it will also support student writers who rarely have the chance to see their work come to life!

Thank you so much for your consideration, and if this is something you feel passionate about supporting, please help us spread the word about this exciting piece of new work!

Thank you again for your support! This show could not happen without you!

story:
Short Summary

Turkish American Repertory Theater&Entertainment TARTE is the only theater in the Northeast whose mission includes the sharing of Turkish culture and literature with American audiences. TARTE’s main specialization is Theater, Performing Arts and Video. Our company is one of the unique places where the Turkish classics, American classics and original work meet and reach a wide range of audiences.

       Works include adapted and original plays, dance theater, a one act play festival and children’s programs. For upcoming festivals and shows please stay tuned.

Bellini and the Sultan is a unique, full-length adventure-comedy (non-musical) that explores how Muslims and non-Muslims can communicate and understand one another’s cultures, in the context of an exciting entertainment experience.

The appealing and complex central character, Renaissance painter Gentile Bellini, is sent to paint a famous portrait of the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire. He finds himself fighting to survive in exotic 15th Century Istanbul in the midst of eunuchs, concubines, romance, executions and an evil Vizier out to get him.

A multi-ethnic, multi-racial cast brings the story to life using minimal set, costumes and technical
requirements, employing age-old theater craft and vivid characterizations.

Mario Fratti, author of NINE and reviewer for AmericaOggi, called the play an “Exciting interpretation of an unusual encounter between art and politics.”

Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

In order to put this productions up on stage with a proper set and costumes we will need to raise $2500. 

It is a unique experience and you will meet East and West in Istanbul and experience that era with the set and the costumes. 

The funds will help pay for the set and the costumes and the actors stipends. 

The Impact

It is an unusual original project that everyone will want to see. We are planning on taking the show to tour in the USA and Turkey. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our show and campaign
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Our company is one of the unique places where the Turkish classics, American classics and original work meet and reach a wide range of audiences.
       Works include adapted and original plays, dance theater, a one act play festival and children’s programs. For upcoming festivals and shows please stay tuned.

Bellini and the Sultan is a unique, full-length adventure-comedy (non-musical) that explores how Muslims and non-Muslims can communicate and understand one another’s cultures, in the context of an exciting entertainment experience.The appealing and complex central character, Renaissance painter Gentile Bellini, is sent to paint a famous portrait of the Sultan of the Ottoman Empire. He finds himself fighting to survive in exotic 15th Century Istanbul in the midst of eunuchs, concubines, romance, executions and an evil Vizier out to get him.A multi-ethnic, multi-racial cast brings the story to life using minimal set, costumes and technicalrequirements, employing age-old theater craft and vivid characterizations.Mario Fratti, author of NINE and reviewer for AmericaOggi, called the play an “Exciting interpretation of an unusual encounter between art and politics.”
Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.
Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?


What We Need & What You Get
In order to put this productions up on stage with a proper set and costumes we will need to raise $2500. 
It is a unique experience and you will meet East and West in Istanbul and experience that era with the set and the costumes. 
The funds will help pay for the set and the costumes and the actors stipends. 


The Impact
It is an unusual original project that everyone will want to see. We are planning on taking the show to tour in the USA and Turkey. 
Other Ways You Can Help



Spread the word about our show and campaign
Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Sometimes I Laugh Like My Sister (SILLMS) is a solo piece of theatre about a BBC producer, Kate Peyton, who was based in Johannesburg when she was sent to report on the situation in Mogadishu, where she was killed. The play is performed by Kate's sister, the actress Rebecca Peyton who co-wrote the piece with director Martin Bartelt. It is a passionately political, sharply comical and painfully personal account of life after Kate as is a performance in which movement, gesture and voice are all equal in importance and merge together. 

This is a story about politics, journalists and death, told through the eyes of Rebecca, whose sister was stolen from her by faceless gunmen with no compunction about shooting a non-combatant in the back. It’s about politics, racism, migration, women’s rights and censorship; it’s about drinking yourself silly so that you can dance with abandon even as grief consumes every element of your personality. It's about leaving the house looking like you've been run over by a tractor, deciding not to have a drink for breakfast, press freedom and human rights. 

It is a one-woman show where Rebecca talks to the audience directly, with a stage design which is limited to a chair, a table and some water to drink during the performance. Out of 27 performances at the Edinburgh Fringe, only one left Rebecca free to leave straight after the show, after the other 26 one or more - often more - people wanted to spend time with Martin and Rebecca, asking questions, telling their stories, just being together. The show allows talk and sharing in a way which is beyond our wildest hopes but which is inspiring and important.

Vital Digression and Obviam Est are taking the show to South Africa, where Kate lived and worked for the last ten years of her life. We can take this show anywhere and everywhere including church halls, community centres, schools, universities, shebeens, anywhere and everywhere people might like to see the show, and where we can talk and be together afterwards.  We do not want to be restricted by the wealth of any given audience, but this means we need to find the money to make the tour work from other avenues, and in a short space of time. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking around $10,000 or £6,000 financial support to assist with accommodation, travel and food, as well as associated costs with taking the show to less conventional performance spaces. At present Rebecca, Martin and Jacques are donating their fees so all of the money will go towards the production.

The actual production costs are very minimal as the show has very simple staging and lighting. We have found a lot of interest from people in all regions in having the show, and there has already been some media interest. However many venues are unable to provide these costs mentioned above, and so the support we are looking for is really to enable the company to stay on in South Africa and do as many performances as we can. 

Performing the show where Kate lived and worked has been a long-term aim. We want to share the story, and explore the issues it raises, with audiences in the country she loved so much.

Other Ways You Can Help

Should want to help the project in other ways, you certainly can by:

  • Connecting us with potential Sponsors
  • Connecting us with Journalists, writers and bloggers ain South Africa
  • Connecting us with venues or performance spaces in Durban, Cape Town, Johannesburg, Pretoria or elsewhere
  • Spread the word and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The London Ballet Company

TLBC, Tutus and Trainers!

The dancers of The London Ballet Company are doing a sponsored dance-run in order to raise money for our upcoming international tours. The company have been invited to perform in China, Panama and Greece within the next six months.

This fundraising event; TLBC, Tutus and Trainers will see us dance/run our way round ten of London's most famous landmarks on the 28th April 2013. The money we raise will help us take our unique productions to wider audiences who don't have access to the arts. 

Our Aim

We are aiming to raise £1,000 through this event, any donation you can spare will help us achieve our goal.

On the 28th April you will see us...

  • Jeté over Tower Bridge
  • Fouetté in Trafalgar Square
  • Perform 'Queens' outside Buckingham Palace
  • Perform 'Diamonds' at Harrods
  • Create a tower of dancers at The Shard
  • Pose with the dancer at Royal Opera House
  • Pillar pencheé at St.Paul's Cathedral
  • Cartwheel outside Downing Street
  • Become ballet statues at the Houses of Parliment. 
  • Cool down with splits on the steps of Royal Albert Hall. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We would really appreciate any donation and/or your support on the day. Please spread the word to your friends and keep updated on TLBC news through:

http://thelondonballetcompany.com/

http://thelondonballetcompany.tumblr.com/ 

like us on Facebook 

http://en-gb.facebook.com/pages/The-London-Ballet-Company/394853130545440 

follow us on twitter

@LondonBalletCo 

 

Thank you, see you soon!

story:
An Opportunity For Activism: 

Kultar's Mime invites audiences to understand the 1984 Anti-Sikh Pogroms through a series of paintings. The artists use their work to tell the story of the children whose families were taken from them in the genocide; who relive the tragedy each day, waiting for someone to stand up and speak for them. This experimental performance is not only to raise awareness of this event, but to invoke the desire to achieve justice for those opressed worldwide.  

 

You Can Help!

In order to efficiently tell this story without having to charge money for attendance, we need to raise money through alternative means such as this campaign. With your donations, we will be better able to create a work that is moving, thoughtful, and personal in its message.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1200 to cover performance costs for this show.

Estimated costs will cover:

  • props
  • costumes
  • sets
  • lighting
  • publicity
  • compensation for our artist

 

The Impact

It is our hope that Kultar's Mime will not only be an enjoyable theatrical experience, but a thought-provoking piece that encourages its audience and cast to foster change and progress towards justice. This campaign goes beyond raising money for a performance. It is a step closer to an educated and tolerant world. While this project is the beginning of the road for Two Paths Productions, it is our hope that it can be the start of an illustrious string of informed and quality performances.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to donate at this time, you can still help us! We hope to have as large of an audience as possible, and that could only happen if people are aware of the event. Tell anyone you know who may be interested in attending, and spread the word through email, Facebook, Twitter, and other social networking sites.

 

  

Any fundraising that exceeds the costs for Kultar's Mime will be used to fund future productions.

 

Thank You, from the Team at TPP

story:
We're producing the first staged production of Christopher Mohr's music drama From the Realm of the Shadow.  This workshop production is a collaboration between Jeremy Williams of Convergences Theatre Collective (NYC), Christra Ray of Giving Voice Productions (Boulder, CO), and Chris Mohr and will include a full cast of 12 incredible dancers.  We hope that you will consider supporting this collaboration through a contribution. 

About the music drama:

Factions are at war.  A woman is raped.  A hero is born.  Is the light he brings enough to justify the violence of his conception? Could anything ever be enough? From the Realm of the Shadow is an epic story that confronts some of humanity’s deepest conflicts through sublime imagery in music and dance.  The storyplays out in mythological proportions, but it is very much of this world.  A heart-wrenching tale about a mother’s love for her child, and the destiny that awaits him.

Singing, dancing, rejoicing, it delves into the heart of some of our messiest, darkest, most painful human truths.  New choreography brings to life Christopher Mohr’s critically acclaimed, stunning score. A captivating journey to a realm filled with glory, honor, betrayal, and the battle between shadow and light.

Light is found in darkness. Step into the shadow.

story:
Hi! 

I'm Kevin, and I have this idea for creating a cool, new production of Peter Pan. No, this ain't your Momma's Peter Pan, this is an entirely new Peter Pan and an entirely new kind of theater!

 

What's it like? 

Well... it's a rock concert that tells a story, or theater that makes you want to play air guitar or a film that makes you want to jump up on your chair and yell "Hell Yeah!"

It's all three and more, and I call it Vox Lumiere.

 

So, what's up?

Well, I've concocted what I think is our most awesome show yet, and we need your help to cover the costs of mounting the production!

 

 

OK, so how much are you raising?

We're raising $25,000 for our new production of Peter Pan.

That's pretty amazing. 

I know, right?
Who can put together a full on, Broadway quality show, with...
- 4 singers
- 6 dancers
- 3 musicians

as well as a behind the scenes Creative Team that includes...
- a Director
- a Choreographer
- a Costume Designer
- a Make-Up Designer
- a Lighting Designer
- a Lighting Director
- a Sound Mixer
- a Musical Director

as well as make and buy...
- costumes
- hats
- make-up
- props

and... rent rehearsal space for only $25k?

We can.  And we will with your help!

Cool, so what do I get?

I thought you'd never ask! The cool perks alone are reason enough to contribute to the show. 
So... in addition to our eternal love, gratitude, and your free upgrade to our "A+" Christmas Card List (you get much better cards), just some of the awesome perks we've cooked up for you include…

- Your pal Kevin coming to clean your house (awesome)
- A Cupcake Party with Tinkerbell, Kevin, Victoria and some of the other creative folk involved in the show (amazing)
- I'll write, sing and record you a song! (fantastic)
- Heck, we'll even give you a part in the show! (unbelievable)

That's right, a chance to do something cool, and get your big break in show biz!

Nice. I'm in!
But I want to do more.
What else can I do to help?

You... are awesome. What else can you do to help? The number one thing you can do to help us would be to spread the word! Tell your friends, tell strangers, post it on Facebook, tweet it on Twitter, dig us on Digg. It all helps!

Seriously, thanks for stopping by. I hope you'll want to be part of our journey to create something new, special and extraordinary. Thanks for helping us bring Vox Lumiere - Peter Pan to life! ~ Kevin

More Info?

Want to know more?
Here's the Vox Lumiere Website

Have a question?
Here's my email address: kevin@voxlumiere.com

Future Goals

• 2013 - 2014 North American Tour  
• 2014 - 2015 International Tour

Special love & thanks to the folks who helped with the video:

Victoria Levy (my awesome partner in craziness), Victoria Vaus (for our killer "Tink" logo), Alison Janes (for being Tink), Kai Chubb (for love and teaching Tink that cool trick with the wine glass), Jaime Babbitt (for being a damn good sport) and Brian C. Janes (for shooting and editing our video)!

story:
the project

Resurrection, or the Terrible Repercussions of Making Tangible the Intangible is a new one-act play by Jonathan Fitts.

Two years after graduating from college, Juan shows up at the doorstep of his could-have-been soul mate Lisa, only to find her barely recognizable and involved with Neil, the fiercely territorial, corrosive frontman of a death metal band who's determined to run Juan out.  What begins as a friendly, weekend visit quickly spirals into a dark, twisted, life-changing series of events where each individual must ask at what point they can no longer affect change.

June 20-22nd @ 8:00pm

The Producer's Club (358 44th Street)

Directed by: Lee August Praley

Featuring:

Adam Jonas Segaller*

Michelle Polera

and Victor Rivera

 *Appearing Courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

 

the people

JONATHAN FITTS (Playwright) is an award-winning playwright, composer and director. His play WHITE OR THE MUSKOX PLAY (2012 Kennedy Center National Short Play Award Winner, 2012 O'Neill National Playwrights Conference Finalist) will be published by Applause Books this summer.  His play LOBOTOMOBILE was a finalist for the 2013 terraNOVA Groundbreakers Playwrights Group and was recently workshopped at The Public Theater.  He is currently working with the Woodshed Collective on an upcoming immersive play.  His plays have been produced and read across the country.  As a composer, Jon wrote the music for the American premiere of David Edgar’s THE SHAPE OF THE TABLE at Burning Coal Theatre Company, the world premiere of E. Bert Wallace’s QUEM QUERITIS, and a regionally acclaimed production of Gao Xingjian’s THE OTHER SHORE.  He also co-composed the music for Burning Coal Theatre Company’s adaptation of Thomas Hardy’s JUDE THE OBSCURE, PARTS 1 & 2.  Jon is a graduating MFA Candidate in Dramatic Writing at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and a company member with Burning Coal Theatre Company. www.jonathanfitts.wordpress.com.

LEE AUGUST PRALEY (Director) is an award-winning Brooklyn based director, writer and producer. His films include “NOTHING IS FUN ANYMORE”, “HELLO, OLD FRIEND”, “A MATTER OF TASTE” and “WHAT COLOR IS YOUR TUESDAY?” Praley’s work in theatre has been seen across the world in cities including Chicago, Washington, DC, New York and Tbilisi, Georgia. His play “EUPHORIA: SOMETHING BETTER IS COMING” had its world Premiere at the Rustavelli Theatre in Georgia as a co-production with the US State Department. Most recently, his play “THANKSGIVING AT CHEKOV’S” was a finalist in the highly competitive Eugene O’Neill National Playwright’s Conference. As a stage actor he has worked with Forum Theatre (bobrauschenbergamerica), No Rules (YOU’RE A GOOD MAN CHARLIE BROWN), dog & pony DC (COURAGE) in Washington, DC. For the theatre he has directed “BAT BOY,” “IS THERE LIFE AFTER HIGH SCHOOL,” “IT’S A SMALL WORLD,” and “MACBETH.” Praley is a 2013 MFA Candidate in Dramatic Writing at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. 

ADAM JONAS SEGALLER (Neil) was recently seen worldwide as Andrew Carnegie on History’s hit miniseries, “The Men Who Built America.” His credits include: Brutus, Julius Caesar, The American Shakespeare Center; Albert Einstein, Einstein’s Dreams, Spooky Action DC; Christopher Marlowe, Kit Marlowe, Rorschach DC; Lovborg, Hedda Gabler, and Lopakhin, The Cherry Orchard, Washington Shakespeare Company; and Sir Walter Raleigh, The Lost Colony. He is a company member at Radio Theatre NYC, with whom he has performed The Alfred Hitchock Festival and The Haunting of St. Marks Place.

MICHELLE POLERA (Lisa) hails from the Northern, VA/DC area and is pleased to finally call herself a New Yorker.  Favorite credits include Sarah Norman (Children of a Lesser God), Viola (Twelfth Night), and Callie (Stop Kiss).  She was most recently found co-producing, directing, and starring in HeartStop Theater’s Almost, Maine and frequently works with NYU’s Graduate Writing Program. She is so excited to have the opportunity to work on this show with so many talented artists. 

VICTOR RIVERA (Juan) is a recent graduate of Appalachian State University with his Bachelors of Arts in Theatre Arts: Performance concentration, Summa Cum Laude. His credits include: Dr. Einstein, Arsenic and Old Lace, and Ensemble, Shipwrecked: An Entertainment, ASU Theatre and Dance: Valborg Stage; John Dodge, Middletown, and Hamlet, 15 Minute Hamlet, I.G. Greer Studio Theatre; Carl, Lobotomobile, and John Williamson, Glengarry Glen Ross, In/Visible Theatre NC; and Adam, The Complete History of America (abridged), and Renfield, Dracula, Ensemble Stage.

 

the brass tacks

$2,250 is our goal!  This money will be used to fund the production, helping to cover:

  • Space! (The lovely Producer's Club in midtown!)

  • Our insanely talented actors!
  • Our incredibly talented crew!

  • Set!

  • Costumes!

  • Props!

If this goal is met, any additional funds will be used to extend our run, currently slated for June 20-22nd.

Every little bit counts in getting this play off the ground.  We've assembled a simply stunning team of artists to work on this piece and we cannot wait to share it with you!

Even if you can't contribute financially, spreading the word about this project will be a huge help.  Thank you!

JONATHAN FITTS (Playwright) is an award-winning playwright, composer and director. His play WHITE OR THE MUSKOX PLAY (2012 Kennedy Center National Short Play Award Winner, 2012 O'Neill National Playwrights Conference Finalist) will be published by Applause Books this summer.  His play LOBOTOMOBILE was a finalist for the 2013 terraNOVA Groundbreakers Playwrights Group and was recently workshopped at The Public Theater.  He is currently working with the Woodshed Collective on an upcoming immersive play.  His plays have been produced and read across the country.  As a composer, Jon wrote the music for the American premiere of David Edgar’s THE SHAPE OF THE TABLE at Burning Coal Theatre Company, the world premiere of E. Bert Wallace’s QUEM QUERITIS, and a regionally acclaimed production of Gao Xingjian’s THE OTHER SHORE.  He also co-composed the music for Burning Coal Theatre Company’s adaptation of Thomas Hardy’s JUDE THE OBSCURE, PARTS 1 & 2.  Jon is a graduating MFA Candidate in Dramatic Writing at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and a company member with Burning Coal Theatre Company. www.jonathanfitts.wordpress.com.
LEE AUGUST PRALEY (Director) is an award-winning Brooklyn based director, writer and producer. His films include “NOTHING IS FUN ANYMORE”, “HELLO, OLD FRIEND”, “A MATTER OF TASTE” and “WHAT COLOR IS YOUR TUESDAY?” Praley’s work in theatre has been seen across the world in cities including Chicago, Washington, DC, New York and Tbilisi, Georgia. His play “EUPHORIA: SOMETHING BETTER IS COMING” had its world Premiere at the Rustavelli Theatre in Georgia as a co-production with the US State Department. Most recently, his play “THANKSGIVING AT CHEKOV’S” was a finalist in the highly competitive Eugene O’Neill National Playwright’s Conference. As a stage actor he has worked with Forum Theatre (bobrauschenbergamerica), No Rules (YOU’RE A GOOD MAN CHARLIE BROWN), dog & pony DC (COURAGE) in Washington, DC. For the theatre he has directed “BAT BOY,” “IS THERE LIFE AFTER HIGH SCHOOL,” “IT’S A SMALL WORLD,” and “MACBETH.” Praley is a 2013 MFA Candidate in Dramatic Writing at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. 
ADAM JONAS SEGALLER (Neil) was recently seen worldwide as Andrew Carnegie on History’s hit miniseries, “The Men Who Built America.” His credits include: Brutus, Julius Caesar, The American Shakespeare Center; Albert Einstein, Einstein’s Dreams, Spooky Action DC; Christopher Marlowe, Kit Marlowe, Rorschach DC; Lovborg, Hedda Gabler, and Lopakhin, The Cherry Orchard, Washington Shakespeare Company; and Sir Walter Raleigh, The Lost Colony. He is a company member at Radio Theatre NYC, with whom he has performed The Alfred Hitchock Festival and The Haunting of St. Marks Place.
MICHELLE POLERA (Lisa) hails from the Northern, VA/DC area and is pleased to finally call herself a New Yorker.  Favorite credits include Sarah Norman (Children of a Lesser God), Viola (Twelfth Night), and Callie (Stop Kiss).  She was most recently found co-producing, directing, and starring in HeartStop Theater’s Almost, Maine and frequently works with NYU’s Graduate Writing Program. She is so excited to have the opportunity to work on this show with so many talented artists. 
VICTOR RIVERA (Juan) is a recent graduate of Appalachian State University with his Bachelors of Arts in Theatre Arts: Performance concentration, Summa Cum Laude. His credits include: Dr. Einstein, Arsenic and Old Lace, and Ensemble, Shipwrecked: An Entertainment, ASU Theatre and Dance: Valborg Stage; John Dodge, Middletown, and Hamlet, 15 Minute Hamlet, I.G. Greer Studio Theatre; Carl, Lobotomobile, and John Williamson, Glengarry Glen Ross, In/Visible Theatre NC; and Adam, The Complete History of America (abridged), and Renfield, Dracula, Ensemble Stage.
 
the brass tacks

$2,250 is our goal!  This money will be used to fund the production, helping to cover:


Space! (The lovely Producer's Club in midtown!)

Our insanely talented actors!


Our incredibly talented crew!

Set!


Costumes!



Props!

If this goal is met, any additional funds will be used to extend our run, currently slated for June 20-22nd.
Every little bit counts in getting this play off the ground.  We've assembled a simply stunning team of artists to work on this piece and we cannot wait to share it with you!
Even if you can't contribute financially, spreading the word about this project will be a huge help.  Thank you!

story:
***RENOVATION CAMPAIGN UPDATE - 8/10/13***

THANK YOU to the more than 180 individuals who have already generously donated to our State Park renovation campaign enabling us to reach our stretch goal of $12,500! This should allow us to install badly needed air conditioning in our State Park. If we can manage to hit $15,000 before our campaign ends - we might even be able to talk about those bathrooms...

---

"Partner, lemme upgrade u." *

The Neo-Futurists create meaningful artistic programming for the Chicago community on a weekly basis. We are known for producing the longest running show in Chicago theater history: Too Much Light Makes The Baby Go Blind (30 Plays in 60 Minutes). Since 1988, we’ve written and produced 8,400 World Premiere short plays for 500,000 audience members . . . and counting. On top of that, we’ve created over 60 World Premiere full-length plays, such as this summer’s Miss Neo Pageant and 2011’s Burning Bluebeard. And our education programs, exploring the aesthetic of Neo-Futurism, have served 1,000+ students. For the last 20 years all of that work has been created, rehearsed, taught and performed in our theater on the corner of Foster & Ashland.

Our point? A lot of people walk in and out of our space. We love working here, you love spending time here, and we all want to be here for a long time. So we’ve decided on an upgrade. For our ensemble, our students, and our audience. We’ve all earned it.

 

“Lemme introduce you to some new things.” *

We're raising money to make some facility upgrades to our space, which includes the Theater, State Park and bathrooms. These improvements will offer heightened comfort and functionality for anyone who experiences our theater and our work.

WISH LIST:

  • Refurbished floors for the State Park.
  • Focusable lighting for the State Park.
  • New furnace to heat both the State Park and the Theater.
  • Clean drywall in the State Park, offering a system to hang visual art, production information and company history.
  • Sound dampening on the walls, ideal for when we have workshops and rehearsals going on at the same time.
  • New speakers for the Theater, and refurbishing the current set to serve the State Park.
  • Sparkly new tile and fixtures for the bathrooms.
  • Pivoting projector that can be focused on any wall in the State Park.
  • Storage space for sets & props.
  • New digital photobooth to entertain as you wait for the show to start.
  • Room divider in the State Park, allowing two rehearsals or workshops simultaneously.
  • New A/C system for the State Park.

So what does all of this do?

Suddenly our space is activated, in useful and purposeful ways. New floors and walls offer a clean place to work, learn and experience. Track lighting provides ways to inform our audiences of upcoming productions, or to showcase visual art by our ensemble or artistic affiliates. Quality speakers let us turn it to “11,” and let you hear it at “11.” HVAC heats up our winters, and cools down our summers. Essentially, things get better.

 

“[Our] dynasty ain’t complete without a chief like [you].” *

We need your help to make this revitalization of our space a reality, and to make a more functional and comfortable venue in which to create and experience our work.

Our base goal for this campaign is $10,000. This covers all our essential needs: new drywall, ceiling and lighting for the State Park. Also installation of the furnace to provide sufficient heat in the winter.

Our stretch goal is $15,000. In addition to our base goals, the State Park floors get a makeover, and we buy new speakers for the Theater.

Our dream goal is $20,000. This allows everything mentioned above and green-lights full A/C installation in the State Park and a comfortable venue for the next 500,000 audience members who participate with our work.

If we raise over $20,000 we can also give our bathrooms a full makeover with new tile and fixtures.

Thanks for being a fan. And if you are not familiar with our work, please come visit us soon.

 

* headings courtesy of Beyonce’s jam, “Upgrade U”


Our endless thanks to Neo-Futurist Board Member, Doug Snider and Studio Talo Architecture (www.studiotalo.com) for developing out State Park renovation designs!

 

The Neo-Futurists are a non-profit 501(c)3 corporation and ALL contributions to this campaign are tax-deductible less the value of any goods/services received.

story:
Une tête d’enfant dans un corps de femme avec des envies de femme.

GABIE est la deuxième création du Théâtre Sans Borne. Les représentations qui auront lieu du 21 au 30 mars 2013 au Studio de l’Espace Libre à 19h30, nous serviront de tremplin pour produire le spectacle à plus grande échelle. Et qui dit tremplin, dit : besoin de soutien !

Née lors du spectacle Parlons Chasse et Pêche, pièce collective produite en 2005, la rencontre de cette « simplette magnifique » avec le public a été fracassante; un des moments forts du spectacle, un coup de foudre réciproque.

“Le personnage récurrent de gamine, habilement campé par Caroline Gendron, est délicieux.” (Marie Labrecque, Le Devoir)

 “… le personnage de Gabie, collant des Post-it jaunes sur son corps en énumérant des noms de garçons, présente avec une poésie singulière, irrésistible, les premiers balbutiements du désir.” (Catherine Cyr, Jeu: revue de théâtre)

L’idée d’un solo pour cette « gamine » « lumineuse et empotée » devient vite une évidence pour nous.

Gabie fait partie de ces personnages, mésadaptés du réel mais distillateurs involontaires de sagesse dans la fiction. On les classe socialement comme incompétents. Gabie est entièrement de cette nature, incompétente selon les standards sociaux. Mais c’est cette « incompétence » qui fait qu’on l’écoute plus aisément. C’est une adulte de 30 ans qui dévisage les êtres et les choses sans gêne et qui dit tout ce qui lui passe par la tête. Elle fait rire avec et malgré elle.

Entendre Gabie nous permet d’oublier d’être performant, d’être sexy, d’être riche, d’oublier de vouloir contrôler la vie, le temps et les êtres. Une heure d’oubli salutaire où la seule condition est d’être en vie et là. Une heure où Gabie vous aimera inconditionnellement, mais pourra aussi vous mordre si vous ne l’écoutez pas.

Le projet GABIE donne la parole aux étranges, ces gens qui mettent leurs pieds dans la même chaussure et surtout, surtout à ce petit côté en nous qui refuse l’ordre établi et le conformisme.

Merci de nous aider à accoucher de ce spectacle en gestation depuis huit ans.

Avec toute notre gratitude,

L’équipe du Théâtre Sans Borne, dont les contractions sont maintenant au cinq minutes.

Synopsis

Gabie travaille aux « petites sacoches » tous les jours de sa vie depuis toute sa vie.

Aujourd’hui c’est une journée très spéciale, elle a invité Martin du Club Vidéotron à souper. Ce soir ils vont se marier, faire l’amour pour la première fois, avoir des bébés et ensuite s’aimer toute leur vie. Tout ça en mangeant du Kraft Dinner. 

En résumé, pendant une heure et sept minutes, assistée d’objets qui bougent, Gabie vous raconte son histoire. L’histoire d’une petite fille différente, d’une mère sans yeux morte de tristesse, d’une grand-mère excentrique jardinière de mots-réconforts, d’un répondeur acharné et d’un invité en retard.

Dramaturge et metteure en scène : Marie-Ève Gagnon

Auteure et interprète : Caroline Gendron

Scénographe et accessoiriste : Véronique Poirier

Conceptrice d’éclairage : Maïtée Lafontaine-Guilbert

Consultant effets sonores : Jean Gaudreau (Larsen Lupin)

story:
Campaign Overview

FreeGeek Chicago will again offer a paid summer internship to an individual who can tackle some of our toughest problems.  In exchange, FreeGeek will be able to provide an opportunity to someone who is looking to use and expand their technology/communications/recycling skillset. A full internship description is available on our website.

Campaign Amounts

We have again set a goal of $3,000 for our Summer Internship campaign.

  • $2,400 will be paid to the intern ($15 per hour, 20 hours per week, for 8 weeks).
  • $600 will be retained by FreeGeek Chicago to cover staff time and expenses dedicated to the internship program (ex: Campaign fees will be about $200).
  • All donations that exceed the final published internship budget will go towards our recycling fees.

Summer Intern Program

This year, FreeGeek Chicago will offer a Summer Intern a range of potential projects to tackle. Depending on the selected intern’s skillset and interest, the summer internship may focus on one or a combination of the following:

  • Creating new social media promotions and promotional material, with a strong focus on creating Spanish-language materials.
  • Improving our donation/recycling intake process and ensuring FreeGeek’s compliance with industry best practices and state/federal law.
  • Documenting FreeGeek’s current in-house server, rebuilding it on newer hardware, expanding its functionality, and documenting any new infrastructure.
  • Producing an educational curriculum to cover an assortment of essential digital skills.
  • Following through on a project or program developed independently by the internship candidate.

2011 Intern Success

Last year FreeGeek hired Axel R. as our first summer intern.  During his internship, he focused on cleaning, organizing, and running our laptop repair area.  His work helped FreeGeek get through a backlog of laptops for repair and get them up for sale. Laptops are always in demand at FreeGeek and Axel's efforts produced some great summer revenue for the community.  We want to repeat this success with this year's internship program.

 

Other Ways to Donate

If you would like to make an anonymous cash donation, just come visit and ask any on-duty staff person to make a donation. Additionally, we’ll pass around a hat at the end of every OpenBuild day. Finally, you can support FreeGeek and our Summer Internship by donating your old hardware, especially used laptop systems.

As much as we need your money, we hope that you come in and donate your time. Being a member of the FreeGeek volunteer community can help just as much. Please let your friends and family know about our 2012 Summer Internship Campaign and about our volunteer opportunities.

story:
Southern Baptist Sissies - Chicago 2013

A story more relevant now than ever before

Ludicrous Theatre-Chicago! explores the richness of human existence by focusing on sexuality, gender identity and spirituality. In Del Shores' Southern Baptist Sissies, we see a message of hope in spite of heartbreak and hate. In a current climate of increasing acceptance for the LGBTQ community, religious organizations have increased their message of intolerance. Please help us bring this message of hope to life for Chicago PRIDE 2013.

Here are the Details:

Southern Baptist Sissies, Presented by Ludicrous Theatre at

The Greenhouse Theater, 2257 North Lincoln Avenue, Chicago, IL

June 20th through July 1st.

How you can make it happen

Our goal is to raise $2,500.00 (which is equivelent to the cost of space rental) to pay for many different aspects of the production. Here is a break down of how your contribution helps bring this moving story to life:

  • $25 will pay for one of the six wigs worn in the production
  • $50 will pay for printing of audience hymnal copies
  • $100 will pay for one of our eight actor's salary
  • $250 will pay for our lighting costs
  • $300 will pay our pianist
  • $500 will help cover our tech crew costs

Any funds we raise go directly to paying the artists we employ and supplying them with the tools, props, costumes and space they need to bring this immersive experience to you, our audience.

There are multiple donation levels that come with perks

  • $10 gets you a direct thank you on Facebook
  • $25 gets the above + listing in our hymnal as A Friend of Ludicrous
  • $50 gets all the above + a Ludicrous Theatre mug
  • $100 gets all the above + invited to a special post-show reception with the cast on Saturday, June 29th and the first round on us!
  • $250 gets all the above + two (2) tickets to the show on June 29th, a Playbill signed by the cast and listing in our hymnal as a Ludicrous Supporter
  • $500 gets all the above + two (2) tickets for our next production, The Sugar Witch
  • $1000 gets all the above + two (2) season tickets for our next two seasons, Southern Gothic season and A Season in Hell

What your contribution can do

Ludicrous Theatre-Chicago! is continuing to grow and give voice to the LGBTQ community through theater. Southern Baptist Sissies is the second production of our On Southern Shores season, featuring the works of the dynamic gay playwright, Del Shores. Our first production, Sordid Lives, sold out it's original run and was brought back for an encore weekend. It garnered the first ever award for a Ludicous Theatre production, for Best Actress in a Non-Equity Play, Michelle McKenzie-Voigt in the role of Sissy, from Broadway World Chicago.

With your help, we can build on this great honor and bring this hard-hitting and touching story to life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Knowing that most of our friends are fiscally challenged, even if you can't donate, you can still help!

  • Share our Indie GoGo campaign with all your friends
  • Help promote us via your favorite social media outlets
  • Ask how you can volunteer to help with the production

Don't let the voice go silent and the message be lost, your support in any form is greatly appreciated!

Southern Baptist Sissies is the second production of our On Southern Shores season, featuring the works of the dynamic gay playwright, Del Shores. Our first production, Sordid Lives, sold out it's original run and was brought back for an encore weekend. It garnered the first ever award for a Ludicous Theatre production, for Best Actress in a Non-Equity Play, Michelle McKenzie-Voigt in the role of Sissy, from Broadway World Chicago.
With your help, we can build on this great honor and bring this hard-hitting and touching story to life. 


Other Ways You Can Help
Knowing that most of our friends are fiscally challenged, even if you can't donate, you can still help!

Share our Indie GoGo campaign with all your friends
Help promote us via your favorite social media outlets
Ask how you can volunteer to help with the production

Don't let the voice go silent and the message be lost, your support in any form is greatly appreciated!

story:
FAST IN FIRE

Directed by Mason Beggs

Script by EJC Calvert

 

In this irreverent interpretation of Hamlet, we witness the story of a father who won't stay dead, a mother unfaithful, the most loyal Bichon Frise you’ve ever met, and the son that is trying to save them all from the fire.

FAST IN FIRE will be presented as part of Dream-up Festival 2012 hosted by Theater for the New City in NYC this September. Dream-up Festival will present wide-ranging and original theatrical visions embracing drama, poetry, music, and dance in the summer time in the East Village, NYC. http://dreamupfestival.org/

PERFORMANCE:
9/2 at 8pm
9/3 at 6:30pm
9/4 at 9pm
9/8 at 8pm
9/9 at 2pm

At Cabaret Theater at Theater for the New City Complex 155 1st Ave. (Near 10th St.), NYC 

What We Need 

To fully realize our artistic vision on stage, we need the amount of $2000.

 Our Mission &  Hope

“Theatre HAN, a new company with a worthy mission” – The New York Times

Theatre HAN was founded by Alice Oh, in 2009 with its mission to be the bridge that connects diverse cultures on stage, and to recreate the classic with new perspectives.

www.theatrehan.com

http://www.facebook.com/theatrehan

 

Rediscovery and Re-illumination of the Classic 

The power of the classic theatre lies in its universality, but also it is the storyteller’s job to make it accessible, real and to keep it fresh and intriguing to our contemporaries at the same time. Fast in Fire was inspired by HAMLET, one of the greatest of all time, and with this project Theatre HAN would like to show the exciting possibilities of remolding and reshaping a classical piece, in such a way it becomes something entirely different and contemporary, yet maintains the primal power of universal human conflicts in classics.

Promoting Diversity in Theatre

One of Theatre HAN’s missions is to promote and to empower theatre artists from diverse cultural and racial backgrounds. As we always have, in Fast in Fire we are presenting an artistic team comprised of the actors and designers from various cultures and nations. We believe we can enrich American Theatre by bringing international, authentic artistic ideas on stage as well as by reflecting the melting-pot-ness of America.

story:
It's all about the Crunch.

Based in Sydney, Australia, Burnt Food started as the working title of an independent 4th year Theatre Studies research project being done on the subject of verbatim* theatre, food addiction and food addicts, their lives and relationships. Twelve months into the project, it is now giving birth to the next phase, the building of a collaborative group of actors committed to the vision and development of a viable production at the end of 2011.


*Verbatim is known as a style of playwrighting in which plays are constructed from, but not limited to, the exact words spoken by the people interviewed about a particular event or topic. Plays of this style share certain characteristics; all words in the plays can be verbatim from interviews with people in the story itself or from public records like newspapers or court transcripts. The writer will then take the words and arrange and edit them to pinpoint particular themes within the stories. Unlike an historical documentary, the final written piece is not necessarily the 'true' history of the particular time or event but the authors take on the story and the key dramatic elements.


Burnt Food will be utilising a variety of theatrical conventions that vary from collaborative group effort and feedback to Brechtian elements used to weave the piece together, such as narration, imagery, sound, addressing the audience and re-enactment.

Affecting the latent desire to change.

Burnt Food's primary focus as a performance work is to bring awareness and realistic viewpoints on the subject of eating disorders, food addiction and body dysmorphic disorders through live performance, movement, and multimedia. Raising consciousness about eating disorders, sharing experience and giving hope to those that are suffering from this physical, emotional, mental and spiritual illness is the key vision of the Burnt Food project.


Helping Burnt Food get delivered.

In terms of funding at this stage Burnt Food is in need of funding for a variety of production costs.Rehearsals begin in June and the rental of rehearsal space for the next 6 months, guest director workshop fees, early production costs with regards to creating an original film, sound and lightingscape, plus any early advertising costs for auditions are the first things that need these funds.  If the goal of $5000 is not met the money that is raised will still go towards paying for rehearsal costs and director workshops in this phase of development. This project will continue on regardless of whether the full goal is reached this time.

Other Ways You Can Help.

Pass the word around to friends and family. Food addiction and eating disorders are not pretty. Nor is it something to be ignored. The more informed the community can be... while being entertained, of course, the better. Help make this project a reality. Or if you don't have any money, and have a theatrical calling come to Sydney and audition and/or help with the creation and producing of the show.

story:
RENEGADE PERFORMANCE GROUP/2012 PORTUGAL TOUR CAMPAIGN

Renegade Performance Group is embarking on our first European tour! RPG will perform as part of the dance series of the Cistermúsica Festival in Alcobaça, Portugal on 23 June 2012. This is an amazing opportunity to share the voice of RPG with an international audience.

RPG is now in it’s fifth year of existence as a company. Since our first performance at The Tank in September 2007, RPG has maintained a steady growth in artistic performance, research, and presentation.  RPG is asking for your help to secure $3000 for performance salaries and company expenses for this European tour.  

Be a part of making our first international tour a success with a gift via our Indie Gogo campaign.  Your generous donations are what make RPG continue to thrive!

Many thanks for your support!

André M. Zachery, co-founder/Artistic Director

story:
Wolf 359 Needs You for the Fall 2015 Takeover!

WOLF 359 IS BACK!

And taking over the East Coast:

  • temping, our newest show, will premiere at the New York Film Festival Convergence in September. 
  • In October, we bring SONG OF A CONVALESCENT AYN RAND GIVING THANKS TO THE GODHEAD (IN THE LYDIAN MODE) to the A.R.T. in Cambridge, MA for a two-week run. 
  • Finally, in November, we'll celebrate the 10th anniversary of HEARTH GODS, our reading series/party/salon since 2005. 

This is a crazy ambitious and exciting year for us. We've covered $1,000 of the $8,000 we need to raise, but now WE NEED YOUR HELP to make it happen.   Your tax-deductible donation will bring Ayn Rand  and temping to new audiences, and allow us to develop our next experiments in narrative technology. And since our administrative costs are covered by the board, 100% of your donation will go directly to our artists and production costs. 

temping premieres at Lincoln Center

Are you ready to work?

Sarah Jane Tully, a 50-year-old actuary, is taking her first vacation in years, and you've been hired to take her place. temping, the strange and comic tale of the inner life of an actuary, is performed for an audience of one by a Windows PC, a corporate phone, a laser printer, and the Microsoft Office Suite. Filling in at Sarah Jane's cubicle, you'll update client records, send emails, and eavesdrop on intra-office romance as you discover the secrets of your new employer. 

temping is officially open for business at the 53rd New York Film Festival Convergence on September 26th & 27th, but tickets are extremely limited. See our perks for the chance to reserve a slot if you donate $375 or more. 

Ayn Rand at Harvard Square

Our musical lecture/dance/wrecking ball on Ayn Rand, Beethoven, and migraines is returning to A.R.T.'s Oberon in Cambridge, MA. Song of a Convalescent Ayn Rand... last played to friends and libertarians at the West Village's IRT Theater and Joe's Pub at The Public in 2013. 

A mostly true tale about migraines, Song of a Convalescent Ayn Rand Giving Thanks to the Godhead (In the Lydian Mode) is a tragicomic play about illness and art, featuring the music of Beethoven, the novels of Ayn Rand, and the musings of an intellectual drag queen in Peoria, Illinois. From pop stars to tortured poets to pre-teens on YouTube, Song of a Convalescent Ayn Rand… explores what it really means to suffer for your art.

Tickets on sale now -- meet us in Massachusetts from October 15-23!

Hearth Gods' 10th Anniversary!

Hearth Gods is Wolf 359's quarterly party, lab, and spiritual revival. Since 2005, we've been hosting playwrights, poets, fiction writers, essayists, musicians, and uncategorizable others in the back room of Jimmy's No. 43 in the East Village. This November, Hearth Gods celebrates its 10th anniversary with a party and performance featuring some of the best of Hearth Gods past. Be there.

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to donate? Help us spread the word! TELL TWITTER TELL FACEBOOM TELL INSTAMAN: WOLF 359 NEEDS THEM TOO!

story:
Dear Reader Friend Acquaintance Person,

A few years ago we started writing a play. We'd been watching film noir, had seen the classics, both serious (like The Maltese Falcon) as well as the spoofs (like Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid), and wanted to do a parody for ourselves. The first thing we needed, we realized, was a great terrible detective for our protagonist, with as ridiculous a name as possible. Thus Flint Dangerstone, P.I. was born.

Soon we added a whole cast of characters, ranging from the classic damsel in distress (a southern belle named Belle Southern) to inept henchmen (Flapjack and Rhino). We had enough painful metaphors to drown an English teacher, and we had our perfect ending. Basically, the play was done.

So we sent it in to the Massachusetts Educational Theatre Guild's "Sherwood Collins Playwriting Contest" on a whim, mostly because the contest had sent us an email and we were really excited about what we had done. We were proud of it, but not optimistic. It's not exactly a normal play, after all. And we'd seen the type of plays that had won in the past. 

And yet somehow it won first place. When we received the call, we had honestly forgotten we'd sent it in, and it probably the best surprise either of us had ever received. We were requested to prepare a short scene from the show to present at the ceremony. We called upon two of the most talented performers we know, Mike Skerret and Anna Shuliger, to play Dangerstone and Belle, respectively. If we do say so ourselves, it was a roaring success. The performance went better than we had ever hoped, and for better or for worse (we hope for better), we got a taste for it. 

We realized it wasn't enough. What we realized from that tiny taste of performance was that it was fun. It was a fun show. Really fun. Fun for the actors, for the director, for the writers, and most importantly, fun for the audience. Too fun to abandon where it was, before it had ever been produced in its entirety. 

So we approached our theatre teacher, a bearded mentor by the name of Joe Gels, who had just opened up a theatre in Jamaica Plain, The Riot. We secured three show dates for this summer, July 11, July 25, Aug 8, a cast of eight incredibly talented actors and improvisers (Mike and Anna among them), a lovable Stage Manager/Tech Director, and a final copy of the script. 

The rest is up to you. WE NEED YOU. 

YES. YOU.

We need you to donate, to fill our relatively small budget with your hard won cash. We need it for prop guns, paper cranes, fedoras, suits, dresses, fake blood, and lots and lots of posters. (if that list doesn't look like awesome, we don't know what does) With the moolah you give us, we'll give you one of the funniest shows you've ever seen. A show you'll tell your great-grandchildren about, and they'll tell their robots. An award-winning show. A show produced by friends, for the people we hope will soon be our friends. So donate! We can use all the money we can get, and if we reach our goal, that's even better. But every penny you send our way will go towards a once in a lifetime experience, for us as well as you. (or if you come to all three shows, a thrice in a lifetime experience)

So donate! And if you donate even just ten dollars you'll qualify for one of our painstakingly chosen perks. Check them out before you click out of this page, because we promise you'll love 'em. Almost as much as we love you, anonymous reader. 

Thank you. Thank you so so so so much in advance for your donation, and know that it's going to a good cause. It's going to produce a play that has been in the work for years, produced entirely by people under 20 years old, for all ages. This will make your summer, just like it has already made ours. We promise. We won't let you down. Now don't let us down. Please.

Thank you kindly, good sirs and madams,

Nate and Gus (the writers)
