story:
DONATIONS AND PERKS

Alfajiri Productions Ltd, the producers of “Silent Voices” is partnering with Solidarity Uganda to make your donation, a charitable donation with tax benefit. Solidarity Uganda is a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) non-profit organization working to empower communities with alternative transformational educational experiences useful for cultivating holistic peace and justice throughout Uganda. Their local staff members and volunteers in rural Amuru have provided their community with non-violent protest training and human rights monitoring technology in an effort to provide a way to address the land conflict. To find out more about this organization, please visit http://www.solidarityuganda.com

SILENT VOICES: A Play and Advocacy for War Crimes Victims' Rights Project

Silent Voices is a play and advocacy for justice project that reveals and witnesses the terror experienced by countless victims of the 20-year conflict in Northern Uganda, including children, enhancing victims’ healing process and empowerment to take action to improve current policies affecting their lives.  

PROJECT SUMMARY

Written by renowned Ugandan playwright, Judith Adong and partly developed at the Sundance Theater Lab, the play is based on interviews with victims of the 20-year conflict between the Ugandan Government and the Notorious Joseph Kony and his LRA Rebel forces in Northern Uganda. It mirrors the views and emotions of actual victims of the Northern Uganda war (which do relate in many ways to the victims of the Rwanda genocide and the Kenyan’s post-election violence). The project explores how victims have been ignored in the constant calls to “forgive” and “reconcile” at the expense of justice. Through the protagonist, (Mother – a symbolic representation of life and death) Silent Voices examines what good citizens can be driven into by unhealthy policies. Coupled in a two-frontier approach, play production and advocacy; the project gives the victims a platform and voice to express themselves.

WHO IS JUDITH ADONG

Judith Adong is a renowned Ugandan playwright and filmmaker currently on a Fulbright Fellowship at Temple University in Philadelphia. Prior to her current study, she was a professor at Makerere University in Kampala, where she taught writing and film studies. Judith was a writer in residence with Sundance Institute, where she development “Silent Voices” and the Royal Court Theater, where she developed her play “Just Me, You and THE SILENCE,” which explores the impact of Uganda’s harsh anti-homosexuality laws on one family. The play received a gala benefit reading in 2012 at the Old Vic Theatre in London, thanks to Kevin Spacey generous invite to Judy to share her play with an audience of over 1,000 Londoners. Judith’s plays have also featured in New York at the National Black Theater, The Signature Theater, and The New Black Fest among others.

SILENT VOICES INSPIRATIONAL JOURNEY

In the words of the playwright, Judith Adong,

As an Acholi woman born and raised in this region, I was one of the young people who walked every evening to spend the night at the infamous Gulu bus park referenced in the viral “KONY 2012” video. I attended the high school from which 44 girls were abducted by Joseph Kony and his LRA rebels. These horrifying events are deeply personal to me, and yet I was fortunate: due to miracle of a chance, I was able to leave war-ravaged Gulu for college and thereafter work in Kampala. As a result, I knew only the feeling of terror, but was not aware of the bitterness, betrayal and injustice that so many Acholi survivors feel towards local and national government leaders.

Between 2007- 2010, I returned to Gulu and began to interview the men, women and children who survived Kony’s reign of terror. I visited rehabilitation centers for child soldiers in Gulu to study how theater was being used in the psychosocial therapy of the children who filled the ranks of Kony’s army, one of the largest child armies in human history. I also listened to the anger and frustration expressed by victims about the Amnesty Act, which they felt ‘rewarded’ perpetrators for confessing to often heinous crimes. So rather than write a research thesis that would gather dust on the shelves of Makerere University Library, I felt so strongly that these stories – these war-weary yet defiant voices – needed to be heard and witnessed by the world.

This is why I wrote Silent Voices. The title isn’t a reference to the people of Northern Uganda, whose voices are powerful, raw and stunning. Rather, it speaks to the repressive silencing these victims feel that their government is forcing on them in the name of forgiveness.”

THE IMPACT

Developed at the Sundance Theater Lab, Silent Voices had its world premiere at the National Theater of Uganda in 2012. This production brought victims, political, religious and cultural leaders, members of the Amnesty Commission and transitional justice leaders together for critical, transformative conversations about the compensation of victims and the National Peace and Reconciliation Bill.  For many in the Kampala audience, the atrocities in Gulu were unfamiliar and shocking. It was stunning to realize that so many in southern Uganda were oblivious to the horrors taking place in the north. While this performance was a huge critical success, playing to sold-out audiences, few victims had the opportunity to view the play or contribute to this discussion.

We would like to continue this discussions and advocacy giving a platform to more voices from Northern Uganda!

OUR NEED

However, the play has yet to reach the majority of victims of the atrocities. 

We are calling on you to help us take this production directly to the people of the Northern Uganda communities in Gulu, Lira, and Kitgum – in the Luo language of the area – and involve them in community discussions and other programming. 

Your support will help us cover the costs of: live play production and advocacy talk back sessions in four cities of Uganda, play book publication of the play both in English and Luo language and a live video recording of the production. Through these activities, we will be able to expand the immediate impact of the play, empower more people to become advocates on this issue, and provide them with confidence in their voice in speaking up for their human rights.

We are looking to raise $50,000 that will enable us to tour the production. These funds will help cover all production costs, including nine touring performances in Gulu, Kitgum, and Lira, and six performances in Kampala. All shows will include a structured, moderated discussion in which audience members will engage their leaders and offer feedback to in the National Peace and Reconciliation process.  This budget also includes a high quality video recording of the performance, so that the story can be shared far and wide through the popular DVD market in Uganda and other African nations.

(Map of Northern Uganda-Gulu, Lira and Kitgun)

WAYS TO GIVE VOICE TO SILENT VOICES

  • Philanthropy. We would be grateful if you would consider making a tax-deductible donation of any amount to help us raise the remaining $50,000 of our budget. 

In recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available.  Everything from recognition on the Silent Voices facebook page, website, playbook to the traditional Ugandan instrument, “nanga” and even the opportunity to see Silent Voices in person are available as a thank you for your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your help.

  • In-Kind support. If you have in-kind support such as offers of services you could provide to support the project, for instance graphic services, still and motion pictures cameras and other services, please contact us at alfajiriproductions@gmail.com 

  • Community Building.  Talk about the show and its message with your families and friends.  Please visit our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/pages/Silent-Voices/166525216726873  and twitter https://twitter.com/SilentVoices5 to learn more about the show and watch some videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We can't spread our message without your help.  Share Silent Voices with your network via social media and the Indiegogo share buttons. Help us give voice, today!

FOR UGANDAN SUPPORTERS

You can donate any amount and get from a shout out on our pages to a picture with your favourite cast or crewmember, DVD of the play, CD of Silent Voices theme song and producer credit depending on your donation. Use any of the mobile phone money transfer services below:

MTN:  MTN Mobile Money (+256 776 617 450)

UTL:  M-Sente (+256 713 973 553)

AIRTEL:  Airtel Money (+256 704 814 506)

ORANGE:  Orange Money (+256 794 246 365)

Your support could not be more timely! Our production tour will makes its way around Northern Uganda in the year leading up to our 2016 elections. By creating forums for victims to expose fellow Ugandans to the realities of what has happened in Northern Uganda, we have a critical opportunity for real justice, recognition and relief for victims. Speaking truth to power does have impact – even President Museveni has finally acknowledged the atrocities suffered by the people of Northern Uganda at the hands of both rebels and government soldiers.

We hope you will help us tell this important story. We look forward to your response and thank you in advance for any support you can offer.

Questions? Suggestions? Comments? 

Contact us at alfajiriproductions@gmail.com

PLEASE NOTE THAT PERKS WHICH MUST BE SHIPPED MAY NOT BE ABLE TO REACH CERTAIN DESTINATIONS OUTSIDE THE US AND CANADA. CONTACT US FOR MORE INFORMATION BEFORE MAKING YOUR CONTRIBUTION.
story_txt:
DONATIONS
AND PERKS
Alfajiri Productions
Ltd, the producers of “Silent Voices” is partnering with Solidarity Uganda to
make your donation, a charitable donation with tax benefit. Solidarity Uganda is a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) non-profit organization
working to empower communities with alternative transformational
educational experiences useful for cultivating holistic peace and justice
throughout Uganda. Their local staff members and volunteers in rural Amuru have
provided their community with non-violent protest training and human rights
monitoring technology in an effort to provide a way to address the land
conflict. To find out more about this organization, please visit http://www.solidarityuganda.com
SILENT
VOICES: A Play and Advocacy for War Crimes Victims' Rights Project
Silent Voices is a play
and advocacy for justice project that reveals and witnesses the terror
experienced by countless victims of the 20-year conflict in Northern Uganda,
including children, enhancing victims’ healing process and empowerment to take
action to improve current policies affecting their lives.  

PROJECT
SUMMARY
Written by renowned Ugandan playwright, Judith Adong and partly
developed at the Sundance Theater Lab, the play is based on interviews with
victims of the 20-year conflict between the Ugandan Government and the Notorious
Joseph Kony and his LRA Rebel forces in Northern Uganda. It mirrors the views and emotions of actual victims of the
Northern Uganda war (which do relate in many ways to the victims of the Rwanda
genocide and the Kenyan’s post-election violence). The project explores how
victims have been ignored in the constant calls to “forgive” and “reconcile” at
the expense of justice. Through the protagonist, (Mother – a symbolic
representation of life and death) Silent
Voices examines what good citizens can be driven into by unhealthy
policies. Coupled in a two-frontier approach, play production and advocacy; the
project gives the victims a platform and voice to express themselves.
WHO IS JUDITH ADONG
Judith Adong is a renowned Ugandan playwright and filmmaker
currently on a Fulbright Fellowship at Temple University in Philadelphia. Prior
to her current study, she was a professor at Makerere University in Kampala,
where she taught writing and film studies. Judith was a writer in residence
with Sundance Institute, where she development “Silent Voices” and the Royal
Court Theater, where she developed her play “Just Me, You and THE SILENCE,”
which explores the impact of Uganda’s harsh anti-homosexuality laws on one
family. The play received a gala benefit reading in 2012 at the Old Vic Theatre
in London, thanks to Kevin Spacey generous invite to Judy to share her play
with an audience of over 1,000 Londoners. Judith’s plays have also featured in
New York at the National Black Theater, The Signature Theater, and The New
Black Fest among others.
SILENT VOICES INSPIRATIONAL JOURNEY
In the words of the playwright, Judith Adong, 
As an Acholi woman born and raised in this
region, I was one of the young people who walked every evening to spend the
night at the infamous Gulu bus park referenced in the viral “KONY 2012” video.
I attended the high school from which 44 girls were abducted by Joseph Kony and
his LRA rebels. These horrifying events are deeply personal to me, and yet I
was fortunate: due to miracle of a chance, I was able to leave war-ravaged Gulu
for college and thereafter work in Kampala. As a result, I knew only the
feeling of terror, but was not aware of the bitterness, betrayal and injustice
that so many Acholi survivors feel towards local and national government
leaders.
Between 2007- 2010, I returned to Gulu and
began to interview the men, women and children who survived Kony’s reign of
terror. I visited rehabilitation centers for child soldiers in Gulu to study
how theater was being used in the psychosocial therapy of the children who
filled the ranks of Kony’s army, one of the largest child armies in human
history. I also listened to the anger and frustration expressed by victims
about the Amnesty Act, which they felt ‘rewarded’ perpetrators for confessing
to often heinous crimes. So rather than write a research thesis that would
gather dust on the shelves of Makerere University Library, I felt so strongly
that these stories – these war-weary yet defiant voices – needed to be heard
and witnessed by the world.
This is why I wrote Silent Voices. The title isn’t a reference to the people of
Northern Uganda, whose voices are powerful, raw and stunning. Rather, it speaks
to the repressive silencing these victims feel that their government is forcing
on them in the name of forgiveness.” 
THE IMPACT
Developed at the Sundance Theater Lab, Silent Voices had its world premiere at
the National Theater of Uganda in 2012. This production brought victims,
political, religious and cultural leaders, members of the Amnesty Commission
and transitional justice leaders together for critical, transformative
conversations about the compensation of victims and the National Peace and
Reconciliation Bill.  For many in the
Kampala audience, the atrocities in Gulu were unfamiliar and shocking. It was
stunning to realize that so many in southern Uganda were oblivious to the
horrors taking place in the north. While this performance was a huge critical
success, playing to sold-out audiences, few victims had the opportunity to view
the play or contribute to this discussion.
We would like to continue this discussions
and advocacy giving a platform to more voices from Northern Uganda!
OUR NEED
However,
the play has yet to reach the majority of victims of the atrocities.  
We are calling on you to help us
take this production directly to the people of the Northern Uganda
communities in Gulu, Lira, and Kitgum – in the Luo
language of the area – and involve them in community discussions and other
programming.  
Your support will help us cover the costs of: live play
production and advocacy talk back sessions in four cities of Uganda, play book
publication of the play both in English and Luo language and a live video
recording of the production. Through these activities, we will be able to expand
the immediate impact of the play, empower more people to become advocates on
this issue, and provide them with confidence in their voice in speaking up for
their human rights.
We are looking to raise $50,000 that will
enable us to tour the production. These funds will help cover all production
costs, including nine touring performances in Gulu, Kitgum, and Lira, and six
performances in Kampala. All shows will include a structured, moderated
discussion in which audience members will engage their leaders and offer
feedback to in the National Peace and Reconciliation process.  This budget also includes a high quality
video recording of the performance, so that the story can be shared far and
wide through the popular DVD market in Uganda and other African nations.
(Map of Northern Uganda-Gulu, Lira and
Kitgun)
WAYS TO GIVE VOICE TO SILENT VOICES 
Philanthropy. We would be grateful if
you would consider making a tax-deductible donation of any amount to help us
raise the remaining $50,000 of our budget. 
In
recognition of your support, certain "perks" will be made available.
 Everything from recognition on the Silent Voices facebook page, website,
playbook to the traditional Ugandan instrument, “nanga” and even the
opportunity to see Silent Voices in person are available as a thank you for
your contribution.  Please, pledge today.  We deeply appreciate your
help.
In-Kind support. If you have in-kind
support such as offers of services you could provide to support the project,
for instance graphic services, still and motion pictures cameras and other
services, please contact us at alfajiriproductions@gmail.com  
Community Building.  Talk about the show and its message with your
families and friends.  Please visit our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/pages/Silent-Voices/166525216726873  and twitter https://twitter.com/SilentVoices5 to learn more about the show and watch some
videos, and see just how incredibly powerful this story truly is.  We
can't spread our message without your help. 
Share Silent Voices with your network via social media and the Indiegogo share
buttons. Help us give voice, today!

FOR UGANDAN SUPPORTERS
You can donate any amount and get from a
shout out on our pages to a picture with your favourite cast or crewmember, DVD
of the play, CD of Silent Voices theme song and producer credit depending on
your donation. Use any of the mobile phone money transfer services below:
MTN:  MTN
Mobile Money (+256 776 617 450)
UTL:  M-Sente
(+256 713 973 553)
AIRTEL:  Airtel
Money (+256 704 814 506)
ORANGE:  Orange
Money (+256 794 246 365)

Your support could not be more timely! Our production tour will
makes its way around Northern Uganda in the year leading up to our 2016
elections. By creating forums for victims to expose
fellow Ugandans to the realities of what has happened in Northern Uganda, we
have a critical opportunity for real justice, recognition and relief for
victims. Speaking truth to power does have impact – even President Museveni has
finally acknowledged the atrocities suffered by the people of Northern Uganda
at the hands of both rebels and government soldiers. 
We hope you will help us tell this important story. We look forward to your response and thank you in advance for
any support you can offer.Questions? Suggestions? Comments? Contact us at alfajiriproductions@gmail.comPLEASE NOTE THAT PERKS WHICH MUST BE SHIPPED MAY NOT BE ABLE TO REACH CERTAIN DESTINATIONS OUTSIDE THE US AND CANADA. CONTACT US FOR MORE INFORMATION BEFORE MAKING YOUR CONTRIBUTION.

story:
Who? What? Why?
  • The All Stories Theater Company is a group of theater artists from the Boston area who are dedicated to sharing a diverse array of exciting and compelling stories with our audiences.

  • Our play, "The Van Meder Trust," a multi-generational, multi-racial family drama, has been accepted to FringeNYC 2014! Woohoo! We're looking for help defraying the costs.

  • NYCFringe offers a fantastic opportunity! The festival gets 75,000 visitors a year, including theater professionals, other artists and theater fans from around the world. We can't wait to mix and mingle with them and share "The Van Meder Trust" with as many of them as possible. 
This play means a lot to us; we've been working on it off and on for over a year. We believe in its themes of hope, love, forgiveness and perseverance.  We love sharing this story.

In NYC, we know we will hear some great stories, too, and learn a lot. This is a big step forward for our group and our play, and we are excited to see who will sponsor us and come along on the journey!


What We Need....

FringeNYC allows low-budget, independent theater groups like ours to perform in The Big Apple on the cheap. But inexpensive for New York is not necessarily inexpensive in the general sense. Donations made from this campaign will go to:

  • Fringe Festival mandatory fees: $700 registration, $100 venue director gratuity, a little over a hundred dollars for insurance
  • Transportation costs to get our Massachusetts cast and crew to NYC and around the city when we get there; food and other living expenses for the approx. one week the 10-12 of us will be in the city.
  • Funding for props, printing, publicity/marketing, and other production-related expenses.


We formed The All Stories Theater Company in 2013 because we believe, as artists, we are responsible for getting our stories to our audiences. And that often means taking initiative and self-producing.  If you can be one of the generous donors who helps us do that,  we thank you in advance. And please know, no amount is too small! If can't donate funds, please do share this link with your network. And most of all, we hope you will come see us in the city this August! (Stay tuned for specific dates!)

story:
Who we are

The Other Side is an initiative to empower women and girls cross-culturally through theater and music. Our theater education projects are dedicated to promoting social awareness, intercultural connection, and women's empowerment. Participants create their own plays and songs using devised theater techniques. The process and final products of these dramatic pieces then become a platform to make social change in their communities. As part of the creative process, each group will undergo a cross-cultural exchange of ideas, thereby creating an intercultural dialog as part of the ongoing curriculum and discussion at each location.

Laugh. Grow. and Learn through creating art from one part of the globe to the next.

Sharing my experience 

I have always been interested in working with woman and empowering others through theater to be the best they can be. I took the two things I loved the most theater and helping others and combined my passion and somehow found The Other Side who was already doing for years what I had thought of. I participated in an exchange and i learned how much these girls are gaining confidence and becoming more comfortable with in  themselves the progress and attitudes of these young women are tremendously increasing the more they partake in this program because there is finally a safe and secure place in which they can express themselves freely while creating beautiful art. For me to see and feel  that taking place during this exchanged grounded me in my beliefs that this organization is going beyond what we said we would do.


Many people say they want to make a difference, but the truth is many don't know how they can make a difference. Donating 20 dollars can help enroll a girl in the curriculum for an entire semester. Donating a hundred can help five. Even donating 5 dollars can help the other side to continue to expand to help more girls around the world at that first step begins with you no matter how big or small your donation is it make a difference. To find out more information on how you can help visit the links below


 Other Ways You Can Help

  • Give what you can. Even $ 5 will help us get a long way to our goal.
  • Spread the word about The Other Side campaign. 
  • Use all of the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Join our family. Volunteer with us!  email us at info@theothersidenyc.org 
  • Like our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/othersideproject
  • Add us to your Twitter feed https://theothersidenyc/


  Thank You

  • To Melanie Closs , our amazing founder and director of The Other Side. She has donated her time and resources to help us create an awesome campaign.
  • To all our interns, volunteers, staff and students who work to keep The Other Side moving , you are greatly appreciated members of our team.
  • And, Finally, You!! Thank you for taking the time to learn and support The Other Side.

story:
My Favorite Character Was the Talking Vase is a lens on legacy. An amalgamation of honest fact and ridiculous fiction, it considers how we position ourselves within the larger framework of history, and how history positions us. Drawing from academic texts, art, and public knowledge about culturally significant figures, and with an interest in figures we do not know or have forgotten, My Favorite Character Was the Talking Vase is a heavily researched exploration of identity, immortality, and personal agency. Vying for the audience’s attention and compassion are Mia Hamm, Charlotte Brontë, and the father of binomial nomenclature. In the midst of performance, the last vestige of an earlier draft of the play — an endearing yet morbid young Boy Scout — derails the production in an attempt to revive the previous version that originated him. With an innocent yearning to be liked, a human desire to live on, and a hubristic need to be remembered, these driven individuals shape, distort, and find themselves subject to perception as they are forced to confront their own senses of self.


Conceived by Sarah Blush and Michael Norton
Written by Michael Norton, Sarah Blush, and the cast
Directed by Sarah Blush
Produced by Rachel Christiansen

story:
This is Miwa Yanagi’s first international tour throughout North America, where story takes place. This journey, blending history and fiction, begins now. 

There was once a Japanese-American woman who was arrested in Japan and subsequently found guilty of treason in her homeland of America, after WWII.

Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape is a story of “the voices without voice”, created and based on the true story of a sad fate in a time of turbulence.  


2015 is an important year, marking 70 years since the end of WWII. There are many things that must not be forgotten, although, inevitably our memories gradually fade away year by year. We believe this story embraces many still-relevant  themes such as state of authority, war and mass media, racism, sexism; themes that should be revisited generation after generation.

Stage is to regain the lost and labelled voices, a ritual of channeling through the devices of theater and the living flesh of human beings. Theatre can only recall voices to the limited spaces of the proscenium. However, the value of going to the land, the place where these voices once existed through this particular art form is immeasurable.

2016 marks the 100th anniversary of the birth as well as 10 years since the death of Iva Toguri D’Aquino, the source of inspiration for this story. Japanese-Americans who were subjected to internment camps lived in silence about their experiences in order to survive post-war life as Americans. We have learned the importance of redressing the past over time, even with its difficulties, from Iva Toguri D’Aquino and, most recently, from the devastation of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in 2011. And the time has come where we cannot turn a blind eye to the increasing tensions arising between neighboring countries on every continent, a disturbing echo of the past.  


“Zero Hour” is the name of the radio program that broadcasted propaganda by the Japanese government to the Americans during WWII. The alluring voices of female announcers, brought to the soldiers fighting in the South Pacific, were initially dubbed ‘oriental witch’,  eventually becoming “Tokyo Rose”.  After the war, American soldiers and journalists flooded the ruins of Tokyo to lay their eyes on her.

These were women of Japanese descent who began as typists, dictating foreign short-wave before becoming announcers, broadcasting propaganda to American soldiers at sea; “Orphans in the Pacific.” They worked out of an isolated broadcasting studio, most of them far from their homeland. As such, they were also ‘orphans in the pacific’ themselves. The announcers were considered as enemies; whose own voices were sealed and before long, were accused as traitors by their own country, disappearing in the waves of history.

Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape is a story around “voices” blending truth and fiction. In the world of set, costume and projection, voices of women are heard in various states, drifting between truth and falsehood, through the use of electronic amplification, radio technology, and in its natural state. Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape was premiered in 2013 at KAAT(Kanagawa Arts Theatre) and AICHI TRIENNALE 2013 receiving rave reviews. Through invitation and support by Japan Society, we are now able to bring this story to North America, including California where this story takes place, with a new cast and script for an English-speaking audience.

(This production is predominantly performed in English and occasionally in Japanese with English subtitles.)


Iva Toguri D'Aquino was born on July 4th, 1916, in California, USA. Her father, Jun, from Yamanashi, Japan, was manager of a general store that sold imported goods. Her mother, Fumi, originally from Tokyo, was a 2nd generation Japanese-American. In 1941, Iva travelled to her parents’ homeland of Japan to visit her sick aunt. Shortly after, WWII broke out and she lost her chance to go home. (Her mother died of illness en route to an internment camp for Japanese-Americans.)

Iva got a job at Radio Tokyo to contrive her living. She was selected to be an announcer, quickly becoming popular among American soldiers. While many female Japanese announcers revoked their American citizenship under pressure from Japanese authorities, Iva, with her strong patriotism, protected her American citizenship to the end. However, Japan’s defeat marked the beginning of Iva’s tragedy.  She was the first woman in American history to be found guilty of treason, charged and convicted of being an American supporting the propaganda broadcasting of enemies. She was sentenced to 10 years of imprisonment with revocation of her American citizenship.

In 1970s, the validity of her verdict was brought under public scrutiny to be reconsidered.  Further inquiry revealed that the trial was beleaguered with systemic racism and the prejudice of the times, including an all-white jury, coupled with a conspiracy theory of Tom C. Clark, the attorney general under the Truman administration. In 1979, two witnesses from the trial, Iva’s former superior authorities, confessed; “The testimony was not based on facts but fabricated and forced by FBI.” In 1977, President Ford gave Iva a full pardon and reinstated her American citizenship.

In 1942, late February, Presidential Decree 9066 was officially announced. 120,000 Japanese-Americans and Japanese immigrants residing on the west coast of the USA, such as California and Washington and the territory of Hawaii, were forcibly removed. Noted former imprisoners include George Hasato Takei Altman and Isamu Noguchi. After the war, Japanese-Americans were denied their rightful citizenship, for the sole reason of having ancestral roots in America’s former enemy. It was not until June of 1952 that the Walter Emigrant Naturalization law was administered. In the beginning, German and Italian immigrants were also interned, but were soon released. Only Japanese immigrants were subjected to the forced renunciation of all private properties and long-term imprisonment in internment camps.

In 1976, President Gerald R. Ford officially proclaimed that enforced relocation was “wrong”, and a “national mistake” which “shall never again be repeated.” In 1988, President Ronald Regan signed Civil Liberties Act of 1988 (Restitution for WWII internment of Japanese-Americans and Aleuts). Federal Parliament gave an official apology to Japanese-Americans for violating the civil rights and liberties promised by the Constitution, granting each surviving internee $20,000.

These internment camps also existed in Canada and other allied countries. 20,000 people of Japanese descent, among which more than 75% held Canadian citizenship, were stripped of their properties and sent to internment camps.


Because… we don’t have enough money!!!

We are invited by Japan Society but they can only provide funding for costs incurred after arriving in the USA. Because of the difference in timing between the fiscal years in Japan and the USA, we were ineligible to apply for funding within Japan for this production.

In this production, we have freshly recreated many parts, including the script itself. We have a new cast for this tour and the rehearsal period is extensive. For this show to be effective in the North American context, we have included more English in the script, for which the actors are working on the language very hard. We also have new costumes. However, none of these are funded yet.  

We believe that being able to fund a theatre production by tickets sales are ideal, but in reality, this is extremely difficult to achieve…much more so with an international tour. You all know that Japan is far away from North America, right?

If this “financially difficult” production can be made into “not so financially difficult” production by your support through crowd funding, we will largely benefit this year and we will all benefit into the future!

With its historical and contemporary significance, we need your help to tell this important and true story of Tokyo Rose, and expand the potential of how art can be made!

Miwa Yanagi is a contemporary artist, playwright and director based in Kyoto, Japan. She received attention for her photographic work such as “Elevator Girl” series and “My Grandmother” series, where she uses CG and special makeup. She held solo exhibitions at Deutsche Guggenheim, Germany, The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Texas, and others.  

Recently she has been energetically engaged in the world of theatre as both playwright and director. Her work, such as “1984”, a trilogy of the cradle of Japanese avant-garde art movement, taking place in Taisho Era, caught  great attention. She is currently embarking on a unprecedented project of importing a traveling stage trailer, which she exhibit as an art piece in Yokohama Triennial 2014, to tour around Japan to host theater shows on it. She is one of the most followed artists from both the visual art and theater world.  This tour of Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tapewill be her first international theatre production.

story_txt:
This is Miwa Yanagi’s first international tour throughout North America, where story takes place. This journey, blending history and fiction, begins now. 
There was once a Japanese-American woman who was arrested in Japan and subsequently found guilty of treason in her homeland of America, after WWII.
Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape is a story of “the voices without voice”, created and based on the true story of a sad fate in a time of turbulence.  2015 is an important year, marking 70 years since the end of WWII. There are many things that must not be forgotten, although, inevitably our memories gradually fade away year by year. We believe this story embraces many still-relevant  themes such as state of authority, war and mass media, racism, sexism; themes that should be revisited generation after generation.
Stage is to regain the lost and labelled voices, a ritual of channeling through the devices of theater and the living flesh of human beings. Theatre can only recall voices to the limited spaces of the proscenium. However, the value of going to the land, the place where these voices once existed through this particular art form is immeasurable.
2016 marks the 100th anniversary of the birth as well as 10 years since the death of Iva Toguri D’Aquino, the source of inspiration for this story. Japanese-Americans who were subjected to internment camps lived in silence about their experiences in order to survive post-war life as Americans. We have learned the importance of redressing the past over time, even with its difficulties, from Iva Toguri D’Aquino and, most recently, from the devastation of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in 2011. And the time has come where we cannot turn a blind eye to the increasing tensions arising between neighboring countries on every continent, a disturbing echo of the past.  “Zero Hour” is the name of the radio program that broadcasted propaganda by the Japanese government to the Americans during WWII. The alluring voices of female announcers, brought to the soldiers fighting in the South Pacific, were initially dubbed ‘oriental witch’,  eventually becoming “Tokyo Rose”.  After the war, American soldiers and journalists flooded the ruins of Tokyo to lay their eyes on her.
These were women of Japanese descent who began as typists, dictating foreign short-wave before becoming announcers, broadcasting propaganda to American soldiers at sea; “Orphans in the Pacific.” They worked out of an isolated broadcasting studio, most of them far from their homeland. As such, they were also ‘orphans in the pacific’ themselves. The announcers were considered as enemies; whose own voices were sealed and before long, were accused as traitors by their own country, disappearing in the waves of history.
Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape is a story around “voices” blending truth and fiction. In the world of set, costume and projection, voices of women are heard in various states, drifting between truth and falsehood, through the use of electronic amplification, radio technology, and in its natural state. Zero Hour: Tokyo Rose's Last Tape was premiered in 2013 at KAAT(Kanagawa Arts Theatre) and AICHI TRIENNALE 2013 receiving rave reviews. Through invitation and support by Japan Society, we are now able to bring this story to North America, including California where this story takes place, with a new cast and script for an English-speaking audience.
(This production is predominantly performed in English and occasionally in Japanese with English subtitles.)Iva Toguri D'Aquino was born on July 4th, 1916, in California, USA. Her father, Jun, from Yamanashi, Japan, was manager of a general store that sold imported goods. Her mother, Fumi, originally from Tokyo, was a 2nd generation Japanese-American. In 1941, Iva travelled to her parents’ homeland of Japan to visit her sick aunt. Shortly after, WWII broke out and she lost her chance to go home. (Her mother died of illness en route to an internment camp for Japanese-Americans.)
Iva got a job at Radio Tokyo to contrive her living. She was selected to be an announcer, quickly becoming popular among American soldiers. While many female Japanese announcers revoked their American citizenship under pressure from Japanese authorities, Iva, with her strong patriotism, protected her American citizenship to the end. However, Japan’s defeat marked the beginning of Iva’s tragedy.  She was the first woman in American history to be found guilty of treason, charged and convicted of being an American supporting the propaganda broadcasting of enemies. She was sentenced to 10 years of imprisonment with revocation of her American citizenship.
In 1970s, the validity of her verdict was brought under public scrutiny to be reconsidered.  Further inquiry revealed that the trial was beleaguered with systemic racism and the prejudice of the times, including an all-white jury, coupled with a conspiracy theory of Tom C. Clark, the attorney general under the Truman administration. In 1979, two witnesses from the trial, Iva’s former superior authorities, confessed; “The testimony was not based on facts but fabricated and forced by FBI.” In 1977, President Ford gave Iva a full pardon and reinstated her American citizenship.
In 1942, late February, Presidential Decree 9066 was officially announced. 120,000 Japanese-Americans and Japanese immigrants residing on the west coast of the USA, such as California and Washington and the territory of Hawaii, were forcibly removed. Noted former imprisoners include George Hasato Takei Altman and Isamu Noguchi. After the war, Japanese-Americans were denied their rightful citizenship, for the sole reason of having ancestral roots in America’s former enemy. It was not until June of 1952 that the Walter Emigrant Naturalization law was administered. In the beginning, German and Italian immigrants were also interned, but were soon released. Only Japanese immigrants were subjected to the forced renunciation of all private properties and long-term imprisonment in internment camps.
In 1976, President Gerald R. Ford officially proclaimed that enforced relocation was “wrong”, and a “national mistake” which “shall never again be repeated.” In 1988, President Ronald Regan signed Civil Liberties Act of 1988 (Restitution for WWII internment of Japanese-Americans and Aleuts). Federal Parliament gave an official apology to Japanese-Americans for violating the civil rights and liberties promised by the Constitution, granting each surviving internee $20,000.
These internment camps also existed in Canada and other allied countries. 20,000 people of Japanese descent, among which more than 75% held Canadian citizenship, were stripped of their properties and sent to internment camps.Because… we don’t have enough money!!!
We are invited by Japan Society but they can only provide funding for costs incurred after arriving in the USA. Because of the difference in timing between the fiscal years in Japan and the USA, we were ineligible to apply for funding within Japan for this production.
In this production, we have freshly recreated many parts, including the script itself. We have a new cast for this tour and the rehearsal period is extensive. For this show to be effective in the North American context, we have included more English in the script, for which the actors are working on the language very hard. We also have new costumes. However, none of these are funded yet.  
We believe that being able to fund a theatre production by tickets sales are ideal, but in reality, this is extremely difficult to achieve…much more so with an international tour. You all know that Japan is far away from North America, right?
If this “financially difficult” production can be made into “not so financially difficult” production by your support through crowd funding, we will largely benefit this year and we will all benefit into the future!
With its historical and contemporary significance, we need your help to tell this important and true story of Tokyo Rose, and expand the potential of how art can be made!

story:
THE STORY
Linda Louis, mid-fifties, is a woman on the verge. Of what exactly, she doesn’t quite know, but her dissatisfaction is palpable. Her husband, Raymond – to absolve his own fears, would just as soon blame menopause for his wife’s unrest. But when Linda’s daughter moves back home to take a breather from a troubled relationship, Linda reaches a breaking point. Kicked into overdrive are her suspicions about her own stalled marriage, latent insecurities about motherhood, and a burgeoning sexuality she can no longer control, suppress, or ignore. What ensues in this daring, razor sharp comedy is a run in of seismic portions, and ironically nothing short of A LOVELY MALFUNCTION.

WHO IS SHONTINA

SHONTINA VERNON, writer/musician/performer, has written several plays exploring themes that are universal to women. The LA Times called her play, PSYCHOLOGY OF CHROMOSOME X, “surprising, radical, and audacious for its candid exploration of black women and their sexuality.” Vernon is a recipient of this year’s 4 Culture Artists’ Grant, a past recipient of the Louise McKinney Playwriting Fellowship, and was the selected inaugural playwright of the Ntozake-Gurfein Reading Series at New Federal Theater. Her work has been produced by Seattle’s ACT Theatre, the Hansberry Project, SoloNova Festival, the Central District Forum for Arts and Ideas, and featured at the World Wide Words International Festival in Copenhagen, Denmark. Other plays include, ETTA PHIFER’S TESTIMONIAL SHOE KISMET, IN BETWEEN THE ZEBRA’S STRIPES, WOMEN OF THE WILD ROOT, and a solo show titled WANTED – a coming of age tale about forgery, fear, and belonging. She is a National Performance Network touring artist, and a nominated playwright on the 2014 Kilroy’s List.

WHAT THEY ARE SAYING ABOUT SHONTINA, THE PLAYWRIGHT

“Her voice immediately stood out as one of the freshest I’d ever read.” –Woodie King, New Federal Theater

“This woman is a visionary. We need her work.” Ntozake Shange

DATES:

A LOVELY MALFUNCTION will be presented

February 5-8; February 12-15; February 19-22, 2015

Performances Times:

Thursdays – Fridays 8:00 PM; Saturdays 3:00 and 8:00 PM and Sundays 3:00 PM

THE CREATIVE TEAM:

Director: Bette Howard

Cast: Bebe Drake and Ralph McCain (Additional cast to be announced)

Executive Producer: The Negro Ensemble Company (NEC)


WHAT WE NEED:

Producing a show anywhere is expensive but producing in New York City is very expensive. We are raising $10,000.00 to cover the cost of the production for a 2 week run. The NEC is known for it's dynamic productions and always has top notch talent on the cast and creative team. Our costs include rental of rehearsal and production spaces, printing and distributing of publicity materials, and materials for set and props construction.

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

By making a donation to this production you are enabling us to provide this story and all the hard work we are putting into it, the production it deserves. Please see our different perk packages below.

If you are unable to help, please spread the word and pass along this campaign to those people who might be interested in helping our cause.

scroll down for english.

berika ve KAM - Şubat 2015'te PRÖMİYER

Çağdaş dans & tiyatro üzerine işler üreten, disiplinlerarası sanat topluluğu olan berika, 2011 senesinde, Can Bora tarafından İstanbul'da kuruldu. Topluluk özgün yazılmış türkçe metinleri ve "yeni teknolojiler" ismiyle anılan mültimedya araçlarını kullanır. 

(Kampanyanın GALLERY bölümüne bir göz atın!) Sahnedeki oyuncunun "canlı" görüntüsünü bilgisayarda önceden kaydedilmiş görüntünün üzerine montajlayarak, tiyatro sahnesinde "simultane bir film" sunulmasına izin verilen Green Box tekniğiyle tasarlanmış trilojinin ilk gösterisi DANTEL (2011)'den sonra, şu anda KAM için prova aşamasındayız. Oyunda kullanacağımız videoların yarısının çekimini kasım-aralık ayında bitirdik. Ocak 2015'te CANON bize ihtiyacımız olan birkaç kamerayı bir haftalığına ödünç vererek, ocak ayında gösterinin tüm çekim ve "video art"larını da bitirmiş olacağız. KAM, İstanbul'da yaşayan dört arkadaşın birkaç günlük doğaya kaçışlarını ve burada bir şamanla karşılaşmalarını anlatıyor. Tüm gösterinin sahne tasarımı Green Box üzerinden kurulmuş olup, oyun tiyatro sahnesini bir film stüdyosuna dönüştürmeyi hedefliyor.

DANTEL için lütfen aşağıdaki link'e göz atın: 

http://www.can-bora.com/#!dantel/c1mzk 
DETAYLI BİLGİ İÇİN: www.can-bora.com 

Green Box (ya da Blue Screen)'lı tiyatro nasıl oluyor? diye soruyorsanız, lütfen aşağıdaki link'ten videoya ulaşın. Şifre olarak dan20tel14 yazın. KAM'da bütün oyun ve sahne Green Box ile oluşturulmuş olacak.
https://vimeo.com/100048032

Sorunlar

Türkiye'deki kültürel politika ve ekonomi eksiklerinden dolayı, maalesef herhangi bir kurumsal yardım ya da destek yokluğundan projelerimizi gerçekleştirmek için bu bağış fonunu açtık. Vazgeçmek yok! Sadece iyi titreşimlerden yanayız!

Evet, yeni teknolojiler kullanarak bir tiyatro oyunu gerçekleştirmek pahalı, ama isteğimiz bizi canlı tutuyor!

Oyunu oynayacağımız profesyonel tiyatro sahnesinin günlük kirası 1.500 TL. Buna ek olarak; ekip, provalar, kostüm ve ışık tasarımı, ses tasarımı, videografi ve canlı montaj için sahne modüllerini de ekleyelim.

İki tane Green Box sistemi, iki yeni Mac PRO (HD kameralarla uyumlu), iki büyük LCD ekran ve Green Box sistemi için profesyonel ışıklara ihtiyacımız var ki toplam bütçe 30.000 TL'yi buluyor. 

KÜNYE

yazan-yöneten: Can Bora oyuncular: Goncagül Sunar, Yunus Günçe, Başak Kıvılcım Ertanoğlu, Halil İbrahim Irklı, Can Bora proje asistanı: Fuat Özsavaş videografi: Fırat Gürgen canlı montaj sahne modülü: Utku Öğüt müzik: Mabel Matiz, Selin Damar, Utku Öğüt kostüm: Selim Baklacı stilist: Melis Erdoğan destekçiler: Salt Galata sponsor: CANON

berika olarak, 4 projemiz daha yaratılmayı bekliyor!

Hatırlatalım: evet, yapacağınız bağış bizim için çok çok önemli! Lakin, bağışınızla sadece KAM için değil, berika'nın 4 yeni projesine de destek veriyor olacaksınız! 

Münevver Rezidans: Green Box tekniği ile tasarlanan trilojinin son oyunu ve Sorgu. 

Devinimsel Hareket ve Bölünme : mültimedya kullanarak tasarlanmış çağdaş dans projeleri. Video taslakları ve dansçılarımız şimdiden hazır!

Projelerimizin, metinleri ve sahne taslakları şu anda "tamamlanmış" halde fakat hayata geçmek için bahsettiğimiz tüm teknik materyellere ihtiyacımız var!

Bağışlarınız için size samimi bir şekilde şöyle teşekkür etmek istedik : yapacağınız bağış (PERK) karşılığında - istediğiniz gösterime davetiye, sosyal medyalarımızda adınıza özel teşekkürler; bireysel tiyatro, dans ya da yoga dersi! ve sürpriz video ve fotoğraflar!

Neden yaratmak için bu kadar derin ve kararlı bir arzu?

10 yaşımda kafamın içinden ne geçti de tiyatro kursuna başladım, bilmiyorum. Lakin tiyatro, dans, yoga "kendini tanıma ve keşfetme" konusunda önemli adımlar oldular ve olmaya da devam ediyor. Sandığımızdan daha "engin" olduğumuzu düşünüyorum. 

Yaratma sürecine girdiğinizde içinizden bir coşku yükseliyor. Ve ruhunuzun sizden arzu ettiğini gerçekleştirene kadar da durmak yok! Yolculuk kolay değil ama devam etmek zorunda. Bizler yaratmak zorundayız, yoksa asla zihnimiz durmayacak!

Genç bir sanatçı olarak, özellikle "insan bedeninin duyumsal (algı) sistemi ve bunun sınır ve yapabileceklerini" önemsiyorum. Derin varlıklarız, ve kendimize dair, varoluşumuza dair keşfedilecek çooook şey var! berika'nın tüm projeleri zihin-beden ve ruh farkındalığı konusunu içeriyor. 

Riskler ve Fırsatlar

Tiyatro ile anlaşmamız imzalanmış durumda ve gösterimler ne şekilde olursa olsun devam etmek zorunda!

Total fon rakamımıza ulaşmış olalım olmayalım, bu hayalimizi gerçekleştirmekte kararlıyız!

Şimdiden teşekkürler ve KAM'ın size getireceği "iyi titreşimler" için hazırlanın!

english:

berika and the SHAMAN - PREMIER IN FEBRUARY 2015.

berika is an interdisciplinary art collective based in Istanbul. The collective works both on the fields of contemporary dance and theatre. It uses original texts and new technologies tools. After the success of the first performance The LACEWORK, actually we are in the middle of the rehearsals for the new work using the Green Box Trilogy : The SHAMAN. The half part of all of video shooting is done but CANON will lead some cameras (first week of January 2015) we need for one week in order to achieve our video shootings and the VIDEO ARTS (inspired by Bill Viola's work) for the performance. The play tells about the journey of four friends to the nature for a few days where they meet (?) a Shaman. The work aims to turn the stage into a film studio where the simultaneous images of the actors and the pre-recorded images will permit to the audience to see in the same time the making and the result of a new movie. 

Take a look for THE LACEWORK or GALLERY on this window.

http://www.can-bora.com/#!dantel/c1mzk
For more info: www.can-bora.com 
If you are asking "what is like a theatre using Green Box (or Blue Screen technique), have a look on the video : https://vimeo.com/100048032 
The password is: dan20tel14
For THE SHAMAN, the whole play and the stage will be surrounded by Green Box Technique.

Problems

As we are living in Turkey where the cultural conditions are getting worse, we are in the middle of a stuck! But never give up! We only welcome the good vibes! 

Yes, using multimedia in a theatre is expensive! but it keeps us alive! 

Theater rental alone will cost 500 $ per show. Add to this the cost of promotion, staff, rehearsal, lighting & costume design, sound design, videography and the making  of the stage modules. 

We need two big Green Box systems, two new Mac Pro (convenient with HD cameras), two LCD screens and professional lighting for the Green Box. It figures over 10.000$.

THE CREW

text and direction: Can Bora performers: Goncagul Sunar, Yunus Gunce, Basak Kivilcim Ertanoglu, Halil Ibrahim Irkli, Can Bora project assistant: Fuat Ozsavas videography: Firat Gurgen live stage module: Utku Ogut music: Mabel Matiz, Selin Damar, Utku Ogut costume: Selim Baklaci stylist: Melis Erdogan with the collaboration of SALT Galata sponsor: CANON

as berika, we have already 4 projects attending to be created!

So, as your help is extremely important for us; you don't help us just for one production but for 4 PRODUCTIONS!

The Munevver Residence - the third project of the Green Box trilogy and The Interrogation are already written by Can Bora and are waiting to be staged!

The Perpetual Movement and The Division are the contemporary dance projects using multimedia. The dancers and the video sketches are ready!

The projects are ready but they don't get materialised without the elements we need!

To show our profound gratitude for your support we are offering special thank-you perks including: 

  • Priority Tickets to Any Performance
  • Signed Memorabilia
  • Specialized Coaching in Dance, Theater and Yoga !

Why a strong desire for creating?

Never give up! I don't even remember what was my deepest ambition to take drama classes when I was ten years old. Theatre, dance, yoga were important steps to live an introspection and to understand "what we really are." I think we are bigger than we think what we are. 

An enthusiasm comes when you create and you can't stop what your soul wants to achieve. The journey is not easy but it has to be continued. You have to create, if not, your mind will never stop dreaming.

As a young artist, I care of the human body's sensorial system and its possibilities and boundaries. All of our projects are focused on the connection of the mind with the soul and the body. 

Risks & Challenges

The theater is booked and the show will go on! 

Regardless of whether we meet our goal in this campaign, we are determined to make this ambitious performance run a reality.

Your generous tax-deductible donation will help ensure that every member of this cast and crew is compensated quickly and appropriately. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are many other ways to support The Shaman. You can:

  • Share this campaign via social media--tweet and post your heart out!
  • Let us know if you have any special skills to share. We are still looking for a program designer and ushers.

Thank you so much and... get ready for the good vibes !! 


As we are living in Turkey where the cultural conditions are getting worse, we are in the middle of a stuck! But never give up! We only welcome the good vibes!
story_txt:
scroll down for english.
berika ve KAM - Şubat 2015'te PRÖMİYER
Çağdaş dans & tiyatro üzerine işler üreten, disiplinlerarası sanat topluluğu olan berika, 2011 senesinde, Can Bora tarafından İstanbul'da kuruldu. Topluluk özgün yazılmış türkçe metinleri ve "yeni teknolojiler" ismiyle anılan mültimedya araçlarını kullanır. 
(Kampanyanın GALLERY bölümüne bir göz atın!) Sahnedeki oyuncunun "canlı" görüntüsünü bilgisayarda önceden kaydedilmiş görüntünün üzerine montajlayarak, tiyatro sahnesinde "simultane bir film" sunulmasına izin verilen Green Box tekniğiyle tasarlanmış trilojinin ilk gösterisi DANTEL (2011)'den sonra, şu anda KAM için prova aşamasındayız. Oyunda kullanacağımız videoların yarısının çekimini kasım-aralık ayında bitirdik. Ocak 2015'te CANON bize ihtiyacımız olan birkaç kamerayı bir haftalığına ödünç vererek, ocak ayında gösterinin tüm çekim ve "video art"larını da bitirmiş olacağız. KAM, İstanbul'da yaşayan dört arkadaşın birkaç günlük doğaya kaçışlarını ve burada bir şamanla karşılaşmalarını anlatıyor. Tüm gösterinin sahne tasarımı Green Box üzerinden kurulmuş olup, oyun tiyatro sahnesini bir film stüdyosuna dönüştürmeyi hedefliyor.
DANTEL için lütfen aşağıdaki link'e göz atın: 
http://www.can-bora.com/#!dantel/c1mzk DETAYLI BİLGİ İÇİN: www.can-bora.com Green Box (ya da Blue Screen)'lı tiyatro nasıl oluyor? diye soruyorsanız, lütfen aşağıdaki link'ten videoya ulaşın. Şifre olarak dan20tel14 yazın. KAM'da bütün oyun ve sahne Green Box ile oluşturulmuş olacak.https://vimeo.com/100048032

Evet, yeni teknolojiler kullanarak bir tiyatro oyunu gerçekleştirmek pahalı, ama isteğimiz bizi canlı tutuyor!
Oyunu oynayacağımız profesyonel tiyatro sahnesinin günlük kirası 1.500 TL. Buna ek olarak; ekip, provalar, kostüm ve ışık tasarımı, ses tasarımı, videografi ve canlı montaj için sahne modüllerini de ekleyelim.
İki tane Green Box sistemi, iki yeni Mac PRO (HD kameralarla uyumlu), iki büyük LCD ekran ve Green Box sistemi için profesyonel ışıklara ihtiyacımız var ki toplam bütçe 30.000 TL'yi buluyor.

story:
who we are...

Verge Dance Company is a professional contemporary dance company based in Austin, TX. Although our company has been around for many years, we have recently begun a movement within ourselves to push our boundaries and open our doors to the dance community through fully funded performances, collaborative projects, open classes, and eventually film. 

Our first step in the process: producing an evening-length show. Without proper funding, though, all that we want to accomplish is next to impossible. 

The cost of putting on an evening length performance is far from small, which leaves very little to pay the dancers for their time and work, not to mention anything to contribute to future projects. 

Your contribution will not only help us get our upcoming show out of the studio and onto the stage, but will help us begin to carve a new path for our dancers and our artistic community. 

what we need & what you get

we need proper funding. let us break it down for you in detail:

  • $800 // performance venue rental - this will get a great space and the rehearsal time we need to put on a proper evening length show.
  • $500 // performance staff costs - this will fund lighting designers, videographers, stage mangers, ticket sales, and other personnel necessary for the show to go on.
  • $500 // costumes - 9 bodies to cover in a specific theme is expensive, but this cost will cover costumes for an entire year. 
  • $200 // promotional material - flyers, posters, and online promotion costs.
  • $3000 // dancer fees - the amount we need to allow us to compensate our dancers for their time for performances for 1 year. all of our dancers rehearse for free to stay in touch with their passion and help our community grow through our mission, but we would like to be able to compensate them accordingly for their work.
These funds will help us hit the ground running and hopefully help us pave the way to our future goals. Should we not reach our goal, funds will be focused on smaller projects while bigger future projects will be put on hold until we have the means to adequately produce them.

risks & challenges

Being an independent artist is difficult. All of our dancers hold full-time jobs, and allot time in their busy schedules to come to rehearsal 2-3 times per week. While we provide a means for these artists to stay connected to their passion, they have to sacrifice valuable time and money to be a part of the company, or work long/inconsistent hours at their jobs to make up for the time they are in     rehearsal. 

Not only is this not ideal for scheduling rehearsals or regular work, it is dangerous. High level dancing without adequate rest can lead to injury. 

With monies to allow us to compensate our dancers for performances and possibly even rehearsals, we can immediately alleviate both mental and physical stress. 

other ways you can help

We understand not everyone can contribute, but there are other ways to help:

  • Spread the word! Tell people about our campaign, and help us draw attention to get the help that we need!
  • Like us on Facebook & follow us on Instagram @vergedanceco.

Any help is greatly appreciated.

story:
My Background

Beth earned her M.A. from the Adler Graduate School. She works as a Customized Social Coach and Post Secondary Navigator for Autism Works (Minneapolis) and is also a therapist at the Autism Society of Minnesota (St. Paul). With family members on the Autism Spectrum, she is a passionate and tenacious advocate for neurodiversity and educating the public about Autism.

In addition to her work within the Autism community, Beth directs North Star Irish Dance (NSID) which is an Irish dance program that expands the offering of Irish step and céilí dance to dance studios that traditionally do not offer Irish dance. NSID is based out of Deanne’s Dance Studio (Minnetonka, Minnesota) and Division Street Dance (Northfield, Minnesota). Beth dances and competes with O’Shea Irish Dance (St. Paul, Minnesota) which is directed by Cormac O’Sé, TCRG.

Combining her passion for working with Autistic people to navigate social (fellowship) barriers and her love of Irish dance, Beth wrote her thesis on using social dances, specifically Irish ceili dance, to directly teach, practice, and integrate social skills.

Why Fundraising?

The trip to Ireland has been planned for a year. The trip is centered around the dispersal of the ashes of Beth's father, who was a brilliant man and most likely an undiagnosed aspie. He is one of the main reasons Beth is so passionate about working in this field.
While planning the trip to Ireland, the opportunity to present her thesis at the summer school hosted by the Adlerian Network of Ireland. However, the Sumemr School is in an area of Ireland that Beth wasn't initially planning to be in (Tipperary) as she will be dispersing her father's ashes in the mountains of the West (Beth's father was a proud West Virginian and wanted his ashes in West Virginia and the mountains of Ireland). Beth is raising money for the travel expenses to get down to Tipperary and for room and board while there. The gig is unpaid but an opportunity of a lifetime!

The Impact

If there was ever an audience that could truly appreciate the combination of Adlerian concepts braided with Irish ceili dancing teaching social skills it would be the Adlerians of Ireland. Beth's goal is to get this curriculum out there for people to use and to promote the use of special interests to teach social skills as well as the idea that there are more fun ways to host social skills classes!

Other Ways You Can Help

At my graduation party will be a small silent auction and a sweets-basket of Irish candies to raffle for. I know money is tight for most people but any contribution is helpful.

While planning the trip to Ireland, the opportunity to present her thesis at the summer school hosted by the Adlerian Network of Ireland. However, the Sumemr School is in an area of Ireland that Beth wasn't initially planning to be in (Tipperary) as she will be dispersing her father's ashes in the mountains of the West (Beth's father was a proud West Virginian and wanted his ashes in West Virginia and the mountains of Ireland). Beth is raising money for the travel expenses to get down to Tipperary and for room and board while there. The gig is unpaid but an opportunity of a lifetime!The ImpactIf there was ever an audience that could truly appreciate the combination of Adlerian concepts braided with Irish ceili dancing teaching social skills it would be the Adlerians of Ireland. Beth's goal is to get this curriculum out there for people to use and to promote the use of special interests to teach social skills as well as the idea that there are more fun ways to host social skills classes!Other Ways You Can HelpAt my graduation party will be a small silent auction and a sweets-basket of Irish candies to raffle for. I know money is tight for most people but any contribution is helpful.

story:
We are TwoFourSeven Company, a non-profit dance group based in Vancouver, British Columbia, who pride ourselves in our passion for dance 24/7. Under the direction of Jerome Esplana, Roberta Bierman, Carlo Atienza, and Jon “JB” Bongato, we consist of 30 members who come from the Greater Vancouver dance community.  TwoFourSeven Company specializes in Street Dance choreography which brings together elements of Hip Hop and Urban Contemporary styles. We create dance routines that embrace our craft and culture to share with our community through performances and competitions locally and internationally.


Last year, we had the amazing opportunity to represent Team Canada for the first time at the World Hip Hop Championships in Las Vegas, Nevada, USA, placing 10th in the MegaCrew division. We are very fortunate this year as Canadian MegaCrew Champions to be given another opportunity to represent our country, our city, our friends and family and especially ourselves, full throttle at Worlds.


The purpose of this campaign is to help supplement the costs it requires to participate in this competition. It includes competition fees, hotel accommodations at the competition resort, and flights to and from Las Vegas. Your donation can help alleviate some of our financial stress! Each member of TwoFourSeven has contributed their hard work, sweat, and tears along their journey to HHI and we can't wait to show the world what Canada has to offer!


We can't express how much your support means to us! Thank you!

story: Its no new thing for a college student to be unable to afford traveling abroad. Opportunities are everywhere in this day and age. Being given the opportunity to be able to participate in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, however, is a once in a lifetime opportunity. I was given the opportunity to be a part of a brilliant new piece that was submitted and accepted into the festival. I feel endlessly lucky to be able to do this. However, there is no way I will be able to afford it if I am not given help. I am a full time student at California Institute of the Arts with a partial scholarship. I work a part time job in order to sustain myself while at school. My mother has also contributed immensely to my college fund as well as living situation. She is an elementary school teacher as well as a single mother with two children who is unable to contribute to this opportunity, as much as she wishes she was able to. This is why I am asking for the help of outsiders such as my friends, family, as well as peers. Any amount at all helps, and is greatly appreciated. If you cannot help please spread the word!

story:
This Summer, get prepared for a dose of self-loathing so strong, you'll release your inner wolf. Blind Pug is pleased to announce our partnership with the cutting-edge Theatre of Self-Loathing (ToSL) for the 2015 Capital Fringe Festival. Eddie and Cassilda (winners of the 2003 CAPB Award), of ToSL, will be in residence with Blind Pug for the Summer months to bring their original, critically acclaimed meta-theatrical piece Who’s Afraid of Virginia Wolf? to the US. We need your help to bring this avant garde theatrical form to America for the first time. Help us get there by donating your funds!​

Join the WOLF PACK!

Where your money is going:

Fringe participation fee: $575
Actor and crew stipends: $500
Actor housing: $200
Hats, trunks & puppets: $375
Posters, programs & advertising: $350
Grand total: $2,000

Praise for The Theatre of Self-Loathing:
*Does not translate to English*

Praise for Blind Pug Arts Collective:

"One of the great pleasures of Fringe is discovering new companies you don't want to miss again, artists so hungry to perform that they go on with a missing actor, no understudy .... they hold nothing back. It makes you love theater more than you already do." - WASHINGTON CITY PAPER

"There's a lot of raw talent here .... a young company whose work I’m interested in following further." - WE LOVE DC

Praise for TAME. (Capital Fringe 2014):

"...the production [TAME.] manages to transport a centuries-old story into 1960s America while still raising questions that are unequivocally now" - DC THEATRE SCENE

"...ghastly but captivating...bound to leave its audience with chills." -DCist

"*****" "[Jonelle] Walker not only demonstrates the chops to write strong and dynamic female characters, she has the rare ability to write scenes with sky-high stakes that cut right to the most uncomfortable and intriguing of situations."
- DC METRO THEATER ARTS

What is Blind Pug Arts Collective?

Founded in 2013 by American University alumni, Blind Pug is committed to adaptations and reworkings. The founding group worked throughout their college careers creating beautiful theatre, and after they graduated and got jobs all over the city, they realized they didn't want to stop making art together.

We believe that art doesn’t repeat, but it does rhyme. Blind Pug Arts Collective embraces the referential nature of art to address its contradiction – it is never in the present, rather always in the past or the future, as will we be. Join us as we invoke the past to prepare for the future.
