story:
Description of Carmen: Shadow of my shadow

Carmen: Shadow of my Shadow is an original theatrical work in the form of an Operatic Choreopoem. Through flamenco dance, re-purposed songs from southern Spain, excerpts from Bizet’s Opera, Carmen, and vocal and physical improvisation, two women, played by Audrey Babcock and Paola Escobar, deconstruct the the mystique of the impenetrable femme fatale as represented by one of the most popular images of women in theater - Carmen. Sometimes violent, sometimes vulnerable, Carmen: Shadow of my Shadow digs beneath the surface to ultimately reveal the messy, imperfect, human core - the woman who is both desperate and daring, terrified and terrifying, broken and yet unbreakable.

Music is sung live and accompanied by guitar, percussion and piano. There is a minimalist set design, costumes, and lighting and this first workshop performance will be presented in the state of the art performance space; the Wild Beast, at CalArts, in Valencia, CA on April 20th @ 8pm.


The story behind this production

I met Carmen at a young age and knew this character would be a part of my life - if only I had the courage to claim her. Carmen: Shadow of my shadow is the culmination of over 30 productions and 100 performances of inside a woman who has long represented an epic embodiment of female strength, sexuality, and determination, and though the curtain closes and the audiences go home after each performance, Carmen remains, like the ever present scent of a lover.

Choreographer Paola Escobar first saw a production of Carmen as a young girl and immediately felt the visceral pull of her calling. Originally from Colombia, Paola left for Spain as soon as she was able and embarked on a career in flamenco dance that has spanned 20 years to date.

Carmen gave each of us many things; she also took things away. What were they? How does Carmen live on beyond the stage and in our everyday existence? The blurring lines of life and work take on many layers when up against the idea of what it is to be a woman.


Why do we need you now?

We have an incredible opportunity to create and workshop a truly unique and powerful piece through the eyes of three visionary female artists, all from different disciplines, backgrounds, and cultures, and all dedicated to pushing the envelopes of art, theatre, dance, and music. Because of the complexity of the piece, both conceptually, musically, dramatically and physically, we need your help now to give Carmen: Shadow of my shadow the solid foundation and rehearsal time necessary to ensure her future.

With your help, this workshop will serve as the calling card for a piece that is conceptually sound, executed with attention to detail–dramaturgically, musically and physically, with the goal of having Carmen: Shadow of my shadow ready for her next step in her evolution to the national stage,


What happens if we do not reach our goal?

Carmen: Shadow of my Shadow will open April 20, 2016 at CalArts, no matter what. We are resourceful women, but of course, we are also working artists and students. Every little ounce of financial support helps.

 

My Track Record

I produced, created and performed Lily; her life his music in NYC, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n6azzrFPLCE, with a workshop performance also in NYC 2 years prior. I fundraised for that piece at the crash of the economy and opened in the middle of the coldest winter in New York to-date. I produced Lily  without fail, and without compromise to quality. My artistic teams are always of the highest caliber and my dedication to craft is paramount.  As a performer one can look to my many credits across the country and beyond, awards from the Metropolitan Opera, George London Foundation, Sullivan Foundation and many more, her reviews from Opera News, New York Times, Washington Post etc. You may not know what you are in for with this piece, but I can guarantee it will be something you will not want to miss nor will you ever forget.


We need to raise $7000

Flamenco Guitarist $1800

Flamenco Singer - $400

Dance Floor - $800 (our performance space has a cement floor)

Tech time in the theater - $400

Costume materials - $500

Stipends for student supporting artists (stage manager, photographer, sound engineer, lighting designer, costume designer) - $200 each = $1000

2 pair of Flamenco Shoes - $500

Props (flamenco fans (pericone), shawls (manton), cigars and weapons) - $800

Advertising - $100

Indiegogo - $700 (10%)



Meet the team...

Audrey Babcock, Carmen

Audrey Babcock is an award-winning, versatile, and highly sought after singer and actor known for bringing startling poignancy and depth to her performances. Broadway World called her voice “stunningly full-throated,” and The Salt Lake Tribune wrote "Audrey Babcock commands the stage and is a vocal and dramatic knockout.” As Aldonza/Dulcinea (Man of LaMancha), The San Diego Union-Tribune praised her as "character-defining...a beautiful and sexy young singing actress admirably willing to take physical and dramatic risks.”

Her portrayal of Jo in Little Women won her artist of the year with Syracuse Opera and the Post Standard proclaimed “...masterfully portrayed, undoubtedly powerful...Babcock's emotionally volatile acting is electric. Her [character] Jo, unruly impetuous and selfish, is at all times believable, and the audience finds itself empathizing with her sufferings, laughing at her jests, and encouraging her in her successes.”As Mrs. Lovett in Sweeney Todd, the Washington Times declared her to be “…a strutting, comic sensation!” and Opera Pulse wrote “Bedazzling mezzo-soprano, Audrey Babcock...has an electrifying voice and negotiates the contrast of silken humbleness and intense madness with paralyzing ferociousness. Add such a strong voice to her ability to embody a character and her chiseled physique – she’s a force to be reckoned with!"

Often called upon to debut new works, Ms. Babcock commanded the lead in Tobias Picker’s Therese Raquin (DiCapo Opera), Ellen Reid’s Winter’s Child (Beth Morrison / Prototype), Daniel Crozier’s With Blood, With Ink (Fort Worth Opera), Jorge Sosa’s La Reina (American Lyric Theatre), and Tobin Stokes’s Fallujah, which premiered at the Kennedy Center.

TV performances include two televised performances for PBS including Crossing Borders with legendary opera singer, Regina Resnik and Flamenco Sephardit, a concert featuring Flamenco and ancient Judeo-Spanish music.


She is the recipient of the George London Award, the Fritz and Lavinia Jensen Foundation award, the Friday Morning Music Club Washington International Voice Competition, the Liederkranz Foundation Scholarship Award and an Opera Index Encouragement Award. She was also a finalist in the Metropolitan Opera Regional, the Florida Grand YPO Voice Competition, the Palm Beach Opera Voice Competition.

In addition to performing, Ms. Babcock is an active producer who garnered much acclaim for her show Beyond Carmen as well as the one-woman tour-de-force, Lily; her life, his music of which Arlene Klotzo of concerto.net wrote, “Ms. Babcock’s performance was a revelation!” Recording under the name Aviva, Ms. Babcock released Songs for Carmen, a collection of ancient works from Spain, inspired by the character Carmen.


Paola Escobar, La Flamenca

Paola Escobar, a native of Colombia, has been part of the South Florida dance community since 2006, performing and choreographing contemporary works within the language of Flamenco and modern dance. Before relocating to South Florida, Paola was a company member of L’explose Danza Contemporanea Company (2003 to 2005), known for it’s work in Dance Theater, and has toured in Europe, Asia, and Latin America. As a company member, Escobar gained a sense of awareness of the dramatic thread, consciousness and raw emotion that has carried through in her own work as a dancer and choreographer.

From 2003 to 2005 Escobar was also part of the 34% Visibles , an Afro-contemporary dance project directed by Rafael Palacios which participated in festivals in Canada, Spain and Colombia. Working with Mr Palacios gave Paola the opportunity to explore the expressive underlying load when taking the body beyond the limit of fatigue, which she further explored in her 2007 solo work Viaje de Regreso which premiered in The Colony Theatre, and then presented in south Florida in University Center for the Performing Arts, and in Bogota in different scenarios.

Through her interest in the process of how to create and/or find emotion through art, Escobar continues to incorporate and blend different dance and theater ideologies to achieve her creative purpose. Flamenco 24 Horas was a trio created in Columbia and re staged as part of Flamenco in the Sun 2009 at the Broward Center for the Performing Arts, which blended dance and theater with live music, and to create a story of three women that out of context made of Flamenco their lifestyle.

Through experimentation and improvisation, Paola has been able to constantly expand her movement vocabulary to express her current journey. Flamenco has provided Escobar with a completely different approach to movement (compare with traditional western dance techniques), training Paola in the field of improvisation within the parameters of musical structures. From 2000 to 2005 while living in Bogota, Escobar directed her own Flamenco project which was awarded the National Dance Award in 2005 granted by the Colombian Ministry of Culture for her work Flamenco 24 Hours, among others. In 2006 Escobar moved to Florida where she has worked as a dancer and choreographer for the local Flamenco Companies as Bailes Ferrer, Siempre Flamenco, and Ballet Flamenco La Rosa performing in Jackie Gleason Theater, Broward Center for the Performing Arts, Parker Playhouse, Arsht Center Black Box, South Miami Dade Cultural Arts Center, among others. In recent years Escobar has ventured outside the boundaries of dance by becoming a member of the theater group Antiheroes; and by collaborating with filmmakers and video directors Claudio Marcotulli, Roberto Garrido, and Cristobal Valencillos, as actress and choreographer.

Escobar holds a BFA from New World School of the Arts obtained in 2012, and in 2015 has joined the MFA choreography program at California Institute of the Arts


Cordelia Istel, Dramaturg and Director

Cordelia Istel is a director, performer, and arts educator. After graduating from Yale with degrees in Theater Studies and Political Science, she co-founded Rudy's Meritocracy, a young company dedicated to exploring alternative models of creating, funding, and presenting theater. With Rudy’s, she has directed and performed original work at Irondale Theater Center, Downstairs @ The Irish Repertory Theater, McNally Jackson Bookstore, the Chelsea Art Walk 2012, countless basements, living rooms, street corners, alleyways, and even a crowded bar on Avenue C. After working at the Met Opera for four seasons, Cordelia has also been bitten by the opera bug; most recently assistant directing new productions Lera Auerbach's The Blind, part of the Lincoln Center Festival, and John Adams's El Nino, part of the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, SC. Her original adaptation of Bartok's Bluebeard's Castle premiered last spring, and she is currently exploring two other classics - Berg's Lulu and Bizet's Carmen.


Andres Vadin, Flamenco Guitar

Andres Vadin, a native from Cuba, is a guitarist, composer, arranger, session musician and guitar teacher. He began studying guitar at a very early age. At the age of 12, he won the first prize in the Amadeo Roldan guitar competition, held in Havana, Cuba. A graduate from the Guillermo Tomas and Amadeo Roldan Conservatory of Music in Habana. From an early age Andres also showed great passion for different music styles like Jazz, Rock, Flamenco, etc, resulting in being a versatile musician and lover of different genres. He has taken classes by masters of classical and flamenco guitar such as Joaquin Clerch, Leo Brouwer, Jose Luis Rodriguez, Gerardo Nunez, Paco Jarana, Alfredo Lagos. He has developed to accompany flamenco dancing as well as playing with different artists and different music styles. He has accompanied dance artists such as Maria Juncal, Alfonso Losa, Carmen Ledesma among others. He has played with many artists such as Aceituna sin Hueso, Asere, Billy Cobhan, El Chato, Jorge Pardo, Saul Quiros, Antonio Carmona, Marcus Nand and many others. He has toured throughout Europe numerous times including Wales, England, Holland, Belgium, Scotland and in some Middle Eastern countries such as Lebanon and Jordan and has played at many well-known music festivals like Womad from Peter Gabriel, Glastonbury, Musicport World Music Festival and many others. His work as a session musician on recordings include collaborations with many artists such as Falete, Maricela, Asere and Billy Cobham, Golden Glow, Jose Fernandez, Wadih El Safi and many others.

with......

Andy Cheng, Percussion

Heather Rebecca, Cinematographer and Photographer

Rose Malone, Lighting Deisgner

David Majzlin, Sound Designer


Like the project but can’t donate – you can still help!

Tell people about our piece.  Share this campaign and the video and help us get Carmen: Shadow of my Shadow out into the world. #carmenshadow https://www.facebook.com/carmenshadow

PERKS

$200 USD + Shipping

Carmencita Handpainted Silk

This Carmen inspired hand painted silk scarf, handmade by designer and artist

Gwenno James http://www.gwennojames.com/scarves/

her movement vocabulary to express her current journey. Flamenco has provided
Escobar with a completely different approach to movement (compare with traditional
western dance techniques), training Paola in the field of improvisation within the
parameters of musical structures. From 2000 to 2005 while living in Bogota, Escobar
directed her own Flamenco project which was awarded the National Dance Award in
2005 granted by the Colombian Ministry of Culture for her work Flamenco 24 Hours,
among others. In 2006 Escobar moved to Florida where she has worked as a dancer
and choreographer for the local Flamenco Companies as Bailes Ferrer, Siempre
Flamenco, and Ballet Flamenco La Rosa performing in Jackie Gleason Theater,
Broward Center for the Performing Arts, Parker Playhouse, Arsht Center Black Box,
South Miami Dade Cultural Arts Center, among others. In recent years Escobar has
ventured outside the boundaries of dance by becoming a member of the theater group
Antiheroes; and by collaborating with filmmakers and video directors Claudio Marcotulli,
Roberto Garrido, and Cristobal Valencillos, as actress and choreographer.

Escobar holds a BFA from New World School of the Arts obtained in 2012, and in 2015
has joined the MFA choreography program at California Institute of the Arts 




Cordelia Istel, Dramaturg and DirectorCordelia Istel is a 
director, performer, and arts educator. After graduating from Yale with 
degrees in Theater Studies and Political Science, she co-founded Rudy's 
Meritocracy, a young company dedicated to exploring alternative models 
of creating, funding, and presenting theater. With Rudy’s, she has 
directed and performed original work at Irondale Theater Center, 
Downstairs @ The Irish Repertory Theater, McNally Jackson Bookstore, the
 Chelsea Art Walk 2012, countless basements, living rooms, street 
corners, alleyways, and even a crowded bar on Avenue C. After working at
 the Met Opera for four seasons, Cordelia has also been bitten by the 
opera bug; most recently assistant directing new productions Lera 
Auerbach's The Blind, part of the Lincoln Center Festival, and John 
Adams's El Nino, part of the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, SC. Her 
original adaptation of Bartok's Bluebeard's Castle premiered last 
spring, and she is currently exploring two other classics - Berg's Lulu 
and Bizet's Carmen.


Andres Vadin, Flamenco Guitar
				
					Andres Vadin, a native from Cuba, is a guitarist, composer, arranger,
session musician and guitar teacher. He began studying guitar at a
very early age. At the age of 12, he won the first prize in the Amadeo
Roldan guitar competition, held in Havana, Cuba. A graduate from the
Guillermo Tomas and Amadeo Roldan Conservatory of Music in Habana.
From an early age Andres also showed great passion for different music
styles like Jazz, Rock, Flamenco, etc, resulting in being a versatile
musician and lover of different genres. He has taken classes by
masters of classical and flamenco guitar such as Joaquin Clerch, Leo
Brouwer, Jose Luis Rodriguez, Gerardo Nunez, Paco Jarana, Alfredo
Lagos. He has developed to accompany flamenco dancing as well as
playing with different artists and different music styles. He has
accompanied dance artists such as Maria Juncal, Alfonso Losa, Carmen
Ledesma among others. He has played with many artists such as Aceituna
sin Hueso, Asere, Billy Cobhan, El Chato, Jorge Pardo, Saul Quiros,
Antonio Carmona, Marcus Nand and many others. He has toured throughout
Europe numerous times including Wales, England, Holland, Belgium,
Scotland and in some Middle Eastern countries such as Lebanon and
Jordan and has played at many well-known music festivals like Womad
from Peter Gabriel, Glastonbury, Musicport World Music Festival and
many others. His work as a session musician on recordings include
collaborations with many artists such as Falete, Maricela, Asere and
Billy Cobham, Golden Glow, Jose Fernandez, Wadih El Safi and many
others.

story:
So, what's the story?

Farewell Chris Yee spins a tale in which the best and the brightest of California’s tech progeny are left reeling from spates of school suicides as a result of their frantic race to the top. At the start of the show, the discovery that another student has gone missing leads to the search for the body, the search for reason, and the revelation of the true cause and ultimate downfall of the school’s up-and-coming students. The contemplation of what it means to be present and what it means to be missing bring the show to its conclusion, as we witness the unexpected winners and losers in the race to nowhere, and the pursuit of perfection.

Recognizing that episodes of clustered suicides among highly-pressured, high-achieving public school students are a reality, this work of pure fiction uses the concepts of the quest for unattainable goals and the normalization of cut-throat competition as a springboard for exploration of an environment where any rule is free to be broken.

 

Meet the Team!

Hello, my name is Sierra Blanco, and I am the playwright/composer/lyricist. I am of the current generation of students who have experienced the strange world of high-pressure, high-stakes academics.  News outlets report the unfortunate results of these academic experiments on youth, but a voice of and by the young people is currently silenced in this arena. This new musical Farewell Chris Yee gives voice to and insight into the lives and current pressures of the up and coming generation. I am working on this project with an amazingly talented group of young performers, as well as the Director Beth Milles, Musical Director Matt Russell, and Dramaturg Morgan Jenness. Each and every one of those people are astounding and accomplished and I am honored to be colleagues with them. 

Every contribution, be it $1, $5, or $100, is meaningful in getting this work to a developmental reading stage. Truly, every little bit will add up to our being able to pay for rehearsal space for the actors to explore and develop the world, for us to be able to print out scores and scripts, for there to be stipends for the performers,  and on and on. Our goal is to get this project to production, but it takes long bouts of development before it can be polished to that level, This is an exciting step for the project, and we need your help to keep it moving along the path!

 

What We Need

We are trying to raise $2,500 for this week-long developmental stage of the project.  Every penny of this will go directly to the development of the project, securing rehearsal space, creating the necessary rehearsal materials, reworking the scores and polishing the music with Musical Director Matt Russell and exploring the world of the script with Director Beth Milles. 

I am asking all of my friends and colleagues - if you would ever consider buying me a Chai latte (you know how I love those!) please make a contribution to the fund instead!

Every contribution is meaningful and will help to make this developmental reading stage a success. I have worked on this script and score for two years, and I have a great deal of belief in the project's voice and story. I feel it is a timely story, coming from a unique perspective and that people will ultimately be moved by seeing and hearing it. You can be a part of this project's story - you can be a part of its development and trajectory. Please consider making a donation, small or large to help me get this off the ground. We are going to do this project one way or another, so hopefully we can gather all of the necessary funds before the developmental reading. If we don't reach our goal, we will do the project and continue to fundraise to cover the deficit.

Perks of donating to develop a new musical? Well, I will personally write and thank everyone who donates any amount of course! 

A $10 donation will get you a shoutout on Instagram or Facebook.

A $20 donation gets you a shoutout on the website

A $30 donation will get a shoutout in the program

With a donation of $60 I will send you a program signed by the cast and creators. 

With a donation of over $110, I will send you a script, signed by the cast and creators.

With a $500 donation, I will write a song specifically for you (unrelated to the show.) How's that for weird and wonderful?

 

If you would like to see some of the history of this piece to date, it's development so far please go to the website www.FarewellChrisYee-themusical.com where you can hear demo recordings, see pictures of the past readings, and experience some of the excitement of new work coming to fruition. I welcome you to join our team in bringing this piece to life. Please understand that your contribution of any size is valued, appreciated, and loved. Thank you for considering. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand these are difficult times financially for many people. If you are unable to support my work financially at this point, I would be ever so grateful if you could support it by helping to get the word out about this campaign. Please share, and encourage others to donate.  It takes a lot of people and effort to keep the ball in play, so your energy and active help would be very valued! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word.

story:
We are tired of our community being portrayed as terrorists and villains in TV, Film and theater.  These negative stereotypes lead to hate crime.  We want to tell stories and combat anti-Arab stereotypes, anti-Muslim stereotypes, and showcase the beauty of our community.

We are tired of Palestinian voices being silenced.  We will produce plays by Palestinian playwrights.  No community should ever be silenced.  

We are a Chicago based theater collective dedicated to telling stories about the SWANASA community.  
SWANASA is an English-language acronym referring to the South West Asia (The Middle East), North Africa, and South Asia region.

Medina is the Arabic word for City.
We are creating a City of SWANASA artists who are celebrating our heritage,
​taking back the narrative and
telling our own stories,
in our own words,
on our own terms.

Check out our website to learn more about us and please donate.  We need your help.

https://medinatheatercollective.weebly.com/

story:
HELP US ACHIEVE OUR CREATIVE GOALS

ABOUT THE PROJECT
Chloe London Dance has been commissioned by Triskelion Arts Presents to create and premiere an evening-length work in Triskelion's Muriel Schulman Theatre on May 1 & 2 at 8pm.

We have been exploring how to create a painting through movement: perceiving our bodies as paint and the theatre as a three-dimensional canvas.  Since August, we have been investigating how to hone our own visual art aesthetic without losing the individuality and humanity of each dancer. We look forward to sharing the product of our research with you and hope you can be a part of our journey. 

ABOUT THE COMPANY
Chloe London Dance is a project-based and highly collaborative dance company founded in 2018 in Brooklyn, NY. The company's ever-evolving works have been presented at Sans Limites Dance Festival, WaxWorks at Triskelion Arts, Small Plates Dance Festival, CURRENT Showcase, East Village Dance Project, Dixon Place, Split Bill Series at Triskelion Arts, Battery Dance Festival, and The School of Contemporary Dance and Thought. For Triskelion Arts Presents, Chloe London Dance is premiering their first evening-length work.

YOUR SUPPORT
Your donation will go towards paying the INCREDIBLE artists that are working hard every week to create this work:

  • ​dancers Tim Bendernagel, Mia Martelli, Sasha Rydlizky, Rochelle Wilbun. 
  • ​musician and composer Ryan Wolfe
  • costume designer and scenic designer Bobby Smith 

​OUR FUNDRAISING GOAL
To pay each artist a fee they deserve, we have a flexible goal of $2,500. 

A little break down of this goal for you: 
$1000 will go towards expenses accumulated throughout the process: 

  • space rental
  • dancer hourly rehearsal fees
  • residency expenses 
  • material expenses for set design and costume
  • promotional expenses 

$1500 will be distributed into: 

  • performance fees for the dancers 
  • payments for our scenic/costume designer and musician

We will be incredibly grateful for any amount we receive and appreciate you supporting our creative research.

PERKS

  • up to $10: A thank-you shoutout on our Instagram story.
  • $11-$25: A thank-you shoutout on our Instagram story and a personal thank-you email. 
  • more than $25: A personal thank-you email and an invitation to an in-process showing. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
If you cannot fiscally support us at this time, don't worry we still love YOU!

Here are some other ways you can support this endeavor:

  • COME TO OUR SHOW! Buy tickets here
  • Promote our show (May 1 & 2, 8pm @ Triskelion Arts) by telling your friends and sharing our posts (or writing one of your own!) on social media!
  •  Sharing our ticket link on social media!
  • Sharing this fundraising campaign on social media!

We look forward to sharing and experiencing this work with you in May and THANK YOU for supporting our art.

story:
Our Story

Beautiful Soup has spent the last two years creating theatre for the community, donating our box offices to charities who are connected to the piece we are presenting, and building a repertory collective of creativity.

But with the economic climate, it is growing harder and harder for us to do so. We don't need a lot of help, but we do need some from our loyal patrons.

Jump into the Soup with us and donate $1, $5, $100, whatever moves you. Every penny raised will go towards paying for a theatre for our New York premiere production of Steven Carl McCasland's "neat & tidy". The funds raised at the box office of this exciting play will all go to Beautiful Soup's upcoming third season. We want to continue to give to the community, but can't do so without your continued support.

The Impact

If we're unable to raise the funds, not only will "neat & tidy" not happen, but Beautiful Soup will find itself struggling to produce another show. We can't continue to give to the community without being able to support ourselves by renting space, buying props and/or costumes, and bringing theater to all of you. With "neat & tidy", we hope to raise enough funds to support another year of charitable theatre for all of our friends at BC/EFA, The Fortune Society, A-STEP and other wonderful organizations!

What We Need & What You Get

We've been generously donated rehearsal space, and the costumes and props for this play are very minimal and very contemporary. What we need is help paying for the theater rental -- in fact, we need just our first down payment! Once tickets to go on sale, we'll have funds coming in to lay out. But we need your help to get us there.

Other Ways You Can Help

Skip Starbucks today and send that $5.00 to Beautiful Soup! But if you can't (and even if you can, and do), SHARE the word! Tell your friends. Encourage them to donate as well. Every penny earned helps. If just 150 people donated $10, we'd reach our goal. And if just 75 people donate $20? We'd be there before you could say "Beautiful Soup"!

story:
Our Story

I started Young Actors Theater Company thinking it would be a small after school drama club with about 30 kids. In less than one week of the program I had over 80 kids signed up and 40 more on a waiting list. In the last 1 1/2 years we have added 4 schools, put on 4 productions and have had over 300 kids go through our program! Because this was an after school program, we practiced at the schools and rented a theater for our final performances.

With our program was growing so quickly and the costs to rent the schools and theaters being so excessive, we wanted to find our own space. This spring we found a building that is nearly perfect. It has several large practice rooms, a 500 seat theater with a sound and light system, storage and some office space. We can now expand the program to all the elementary schools in the area and finally be able to offer a summer camp. This fall we
are expanding our program to 10 elementary schools and adding a 6-8th grade evening class.


Recent studies from Harvard and Stanford Universities show that children involved in a theater or drama program at an early age are:
   * 4 times more likely to be recognized for academic achievement
   * 4 times more likely to be involved in their community
   * 3 times more likely to continue on with their education

Our goal is to provide a quality after school program where kids can be expressive, develop skills that will benefit them throughout their school and adult years, and to educate the kids theater arts - an area that is sorely
missing in most elementary schools.

The Impact

*More than 15 million school-age children (26 percent) are on their own after school. Among them are
more than 1 million are in grades K through 5. (After school Alliance)

*Only 8.4 million K-12 children (15 percent) participate in after school programs. An additional 18.5
million would participate if a quality program were available in their community.
(After school Alliance)

*The hours between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. are the peak hours for juvenile crime and experimentation
with drugs, alcohol, cigarettes and sex.

*An analysis of 73 after school studies concluded that afterschool programs using evidence-based
approaches were consistently successful in producing multiple benefits for youth, including improvements
in children's personal, social and academic skills as well as their self-esteem.
(The Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning)

Each day in America, millions of kids go home to an empty house after school. In recent years,
the growth of quality, affordable after school programs—programs that keep kids safe, inspire
learning and help working families—has begun to offer parents of these children positive
alternatives. Over the past five years, after school programs have played an increasingly
important role in providing valuable after school opportunities for children and families.

The funds we raise will go towards the following:
 -A donation of $5 provides a script and other printed materials for 1 student
- A donation of $20 provides the average cost per costume per student
- A donation of $50 provides scripts and other printed materials for 10 students
- A donation of $175 provides a scholarship for kids to participate who can't otherwise afford the program
- A donation of $148 provides one bus for a day
- A donation of $1,184 provides 7 buses for one week
- A donation of $14,000 provides buses for the full 14 weeks

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can help with is greatly appreciated. If you could pass this message onto 5 other people

and ask them to do the same, we will meet our goals in no time! We can always use volunteers too!!

(The Collaborative for Academic, Social, and Emotional Learning)Each day in America, millions of kids go home to an empty house after school. In recent years, the growth of quality, affordable after school programs—programs that keep kids safe, inspire learning and help working families—has begun to offer parents of these children positive alternatives. Over the past five years, after school programs have played an increasingly important role in providing valuable after school opportunities for children and families.The funds we raise will go towards the following: -A donation of $5 provides a script and other printed materials for 1 student - A donation of $20 provides the average cost per costume per student  - A donation of $50 provides scripts and other printed materials for 10 students - A donation of $175 provides a scholarship for kids to participate who can't otherwise afford the program - A donation of $148 provides one bus for a day  - A donation of $1,184 provides 7 buses for one week - A donation of $14,000 provides buses for the full 14 weeks

Other Ways You Can Help
Anything you can help with is greatly appreciated. If you could pass this message onto 5 other people 
and ask them to do the same, we will meet our goals in no time! We can always use volunteers too!!

story:
Short Summary

Ballarat. When you think of this town in Victoria, Australia, you think of Gold, the Eureka Rebellion and some of the worst child sexual abuse in the world. It has been estimated that between 5000 and 8000 children were sexually abused from 1965 to 1985 in a town that had a population of around 80,000 at the time. There were so many perpetrators that most victims were abused by multiple men. In recent years Ballarat has once again made the news because of the numbers of premature deaths and suicides of the survivors of the abuses. Now its time for the solution to rise from the abuses of the past. We need to help the survivors and stop the deaths.

Here are four victims giving evidence to the Royal Commission in Ballarat.  The stories are horrendous, and show the level of abuse and suffering in Ballarat.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=26Aj-n9aIC0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wlaP4DKMxtc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DoHyfn_ojdQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5BlTSmYvhs0

What We Need & What You Get

We want to set up a fund to help those in immediate need. There are survivors who are living in cars, are struggling to pay the rent, don't have money for medical needs etc. What most people don't realize is that there are systems in place to help most other Australians who suffer injury. If it happens at work, there is Workcover. If its a motor vehicle accident there is TAC. If it is a crime there is Victims of crime and you can sue the perpetrator. We have nothing. We can't sue the Catholic Church because they have everything tied up in trusts (see Ellis Defense), and the perpetrators take vows of poverty. Victims are left to fend for themselves. Victims of crime is not available because of the statute regarding time. Childhood sexual abuse has been described as the worst crime possible. As young minds are forming, such acts effectively alter the development of the brain resulting in possible permanent effects. Those of us that are not OK suffer from depression, PTSD, anxiety, relationship problems and have usually tried to take their own lives. Many of our brothers and sisters are no longer with us. It's a lifetime struggle. Most can't work. Many self medicate with alcohol. Health problems are numerous.

We have a Royal Commission looking at the problem, but it will not conclude for a number of years. In the meantime, we still have people taking their own lives.   We are attempting to get the church and governments to fund a trial redress scheme for those that are on the disability support pension, which could then be potentially rolled out around Australia and used as a model for the rest of the world. But in the meantime, people are suffering , need help and will die. 

We want to set up a fund that will be administered by a local law firm. It will be used to provide immediate assistance to survivors that need help. Anything that can't be provided by existing agencies can be provided by the fund. Decisions will be made by a team which comprises a lawyer, abuse survivors and professional counselors.

There really isn't anything that we can offer you in return. Except our thanks. Knowing that you are stopping people from falling further into a state where they take their own lives will be your reward. 

The Impact

The community of Ballarat is hurting. The survivors are hurting. Their families are hurting. many of you can reach out to your church for help. We can't. We have been abused by them and can't go back there. We have had our lives, childhood and our faith taken from us. Most have nothing. To know that there are people out there who care for us is a great help. Having a fund to help those in need will change their lives. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk we face is not getting enough to help people. We have buried too many of our brothers, daughters, fathers, mothers and children. No more.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word. Childhood sexual abuse destroys lives.

story:
Why Donate?

  • You'll enable us to create the visually stunning show we've imagined.
  • You'll help us invest in new equipment so we can continue to bring you our unique style of theatre
  • You'll invest in the Cincinnati theatre community and local artists

What We Need

  • New lighting equipment to bring Wonderland to life, and to reuse in future productions
  • Set pieces, costumes, and hand-made masks
  • Space rental and risers for seating (we do lots of floor work!)
  • Production team and performer stipends

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this page on your social media (use those handy buttons!)
  • Email this campaign to your contacts
  • Grab a friend and come to the show!

story:
PURGATORIO es la historia ficticia del reencuentro entre Vladimiro Montesinos, el asesor presidencial del gobierno más corrupto de la historia del Perú, con su amante, Matilde Pinchi Pinchi, quien lo traicionó y precipitó la caída del régimen de Fujimori (1990-2001).

PURGATORIO is the fictional story of the reunion between Vladimiro Montesinos, presidential adviser of the most corrupt government in the history of Peru, with his mistress, Matilde Pinchi Pinchi, who betrayed him and precipitated the fall of the Fujimori regime (1990-2001).


Los personajes de PURGATORIO nos interesan por su humanidad. Su manera de proceder nos cuestiona a nosotros mismos como peruanos: qué relación tenemos con el poder, la lealtad, la corrupción. Para nosotros es importante hacer este montaje teatral porque en abril de este año nuestro país afronta nuevas elecciones presidenciales. Por eso es esencial recordar nuestra historia reciente y revisarnos como individuos y como sociedad.

We are interested in PURGATORIO’s characters because of their humanity. The way they behave confronts us with ourselves as peruvians: what is our relationship towards power, loyalty and corruption. It’s important for us to do this theatrical production because in April of this year we are having a new presidential election. For this reason, it’s essential to remember our recent history and to examine ourselves as individuals and as a society.  


Para poder hacer realidad esta puesta en escena necesitamos mil dólares americanos ($ 1,000 US). El dinero es para cubrir los gastos de producción del montaje: escenografía, video, iluminación, vestuario, utilería y difusión. Nuestro objetivo es llegar a la mayor cantidad de personas posible. Y para esto necesitamos su ayuda.

In order to produce this play and support the theater season, we need a thousand dollars ($ 1,000 US). The money will be used to cover production costs: scenography, video, lighting, costume, theater props and the advertisement of the play toward the public. Our goal is to reach as many people as possible. And we need your help for that.


Dramaturgia: Malcolm Malca y Vera Castaño
Dirección: Malcolm Malca
Dirección Artística: Guillermo Palacios
Elenco: Vera Castaño y Gonzalo Molina
Producción Ejecutiva: Bonnie Luyo

Del 9 de marzo al 10 de abril
HORARIO ESTELAR II
Miércoles - 8:30 pm (6 funciones)
Viernes     - 8 pm (5 funciones)
Domingos - 7 pm (6 funciones)

MICROTEATRO LIMA
Batallón Ayacucho 271 - Barranco (Al lado del puente de los suspiros)
www.microteatrolima.com
facebook.com/microteatrolima

story:
Check out our first promotional video, featuring a quote from Ariana Reines in her essay on Francesca Woodman here. 

What We're About:

Why is the death of the female artist seductive

romantic

                 problematic

                                        and why

                                                       or how

                                                                     do we propagate it?

Why are we more comfortable with dead female artists than living female artists?

She Is A Problem, as a piece of theatre and movement, yearns to abandon the romantic element of suicide. This project seeks to remember the lives of female artists, valuing their work and lives for what they were; without compartmentalizing them into the idealized Western suicidal facade. The works of the “characters” in our piece are important because of their brilliance, and not because of the nature of the artist’s death. As women, and as artists, we feel responsible for making a space for both the female artist and her art; striving to liberate her from mere “posthumous fame.”

What Our Show Will Be:

In our piece will be focusing on the works and lives of the following five female artists:

                                                           Diane Arbus

                                                            Sylvia Plath

                                                              Kay Sage

                                                           Anne Sexton

                                                   Francesca Woodman

We're using a process called devising for this show, which means that we are creating all the material, as an ensemble from scratch. This method is different from traditional theater making because all of us act as collaborators, creating together the words we say, the movements we make and the vision of the piece. As an ensemble, we have begun the process of getting to know who these women are, of familiarizing ourselves with not only their lives and deaths, but with the totality of these women: their nuances, behavior, philosophy, and physicality. Sourcing imagery, text and biography from and concerning these women, we've began creating material that we'll be part of our immersive piece of theater.


How You Can Help:

As a group of current and recently graduated college students, the production, creation, and performance of an original piece of theatre is quite daunting. We need the help of contributors like you to make this piece a reality. The money raised during this campaign will help to cover the cost of: 

  • Costume
  • Props
  • Insurance 
  • The Services of a Stage Manager
  • Advertising Materials & Web Marketing
  • Packaging for our Donor Incentives

Risks & Challenges:

If we do not reach our entire fundraising goal, our vision for this piece will be compromised but our passion will not! No matter what we receive, we will complete this project. But your donations we help to realize this project to it's fullest potential. We are a professional, knowledgeable and resilient group of young theatre artists hoping to fill the space that we’ve found in our world with our work. We feel a responsibility to all of our fellow female artists (of past, present, and future) to make a piece of theatre about them, for them. Contributions from donors like you will help to guarantee that our vivid dream can become a most brilliant reality.

Who We Are:

The She Is A Problem is made up of a company of entirely women who are dedicated to the creation of new and challenging works of theatre that question the meaning of what it means to be a woman and an artist. The ensemble is made up of the following members:

The She Is A Problem ensemble from left to right: 

Rebecca Buckley, Gracie Martin, Kahla Brown, Nia Benjamin, and Emily Alexander

Emily Alexander || aspires to be more problematic in the future; this piece is just the beginning of her journey to finding her voice. She makes theater because when you move others, you create waves. She wants to create theatrical experiences that push boundaries—of what we think bodies can do, of what we think narrative can do, of what we think theater can do. She is so grateful for working with this amazing ensemble of women and can’t wait to see where life takes her next.

Nia Benjamin || is an emerging Philadelphia theatre artist currently pursuing her BFA Acting degree from the University of the Arts. She devotes her spare time to things that make her happy, especially crushing the patriarchy. She is honored to be among this innovative group of lady theatre warriors. 

Kahla Brown || is an artist struggling with the place and value of art in a world torn up by ignorance and oppression. She believes the greatest hope for women lies in the formation of communities and disinterest in competition. She believes the greatest way to solve problems is to ask questions. She hopes you arrive at She Is A Problem with a lot of questions, and leave with even more.

Rebecca Buckley || is a problem because she puts her whole body as a medium into her work as an artist, movement based performer, and model.  She is a problem because she is versed in eight stage combat weapons, and because she continues to create characters that upset the patriarchy with their femininity and feminism. She currently produces the Philadelphia-based YouTube sketch comedy series Second State with co producer and best friend Andrew Schiffrin. She is a Problem is Rebecca’s fourth devised show she has had the special privilege to be part of creating.

Gracie Martin || is an actor, singer, writer and explorative artist. Devised theatre came into her life in a big way when trying to wrap her mind around the fraught and frustrating progression of human rights in Russia. Gracie believes not only in revolt against forces that harm women, but in positive, creative endeavors that celebrate what feminists throughout history have fought for, while also asking audiences explore and discover their own path to a more equal society.

Amy Harper || is a designer, writer, illustrator, and seamstress. She uses art as a medium to question accepted societal norms and eradicate defective institutions. She hopes to incite change by spreading excitement and fervor to her community. Amy is a compulsive creator and believes in spreading ideas like dandelion seeds in the hopes that if a hundred and one are thrown at least a few will bloom. She believes in seeking out and recording both the whimsical magic of our world along with its dysfunctional cruelty. 

See our full bios at Sheisaproblem.com

Performance Dates:

08/28: Opening Night at 8pm & 10pm

08/29: Performances at 8pm, 10pm & 12pm

08/30: Performances at 8pm, 10pm & 12pm

Find Us On:

Website: sheisaproblem.com

Facebook: Sheisaproblem

If you have any questions or are a female artist and want to contribute to our digital zine, please contact us at: sheisaproblemproject@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

John Moreno of the critically acclaimed sketch comedy group Murderfist, and stand up comedian Alex Moore have joined forces to write a play about not growing up. Gary was formerly the host of America's beloved children's television show, Curiosity Cat with Gary. That was until the...incident. Now Gary is back home and living in his mother's basement. :( But with a little help and encouragement from some old friends, Gary is going to start his own brand new underground kids show and rocket ship back to his former glory! 

Gary's Basement is a project over two years in the making and we just need the tiniest bit of help to cross the finish line. With your support we'll be able to make this play all it can be, including muppet-esque puppets, multimedia shorts AND musical numbers! Isn't that awesome?!

What We Need & What You Get

Props, Costumes, Puppets, and Videos aren't cheap, but we're not asking for a lot. With a series of $5, $10, ad $25 dollar donations you'll be supporting us and helping us support other independent artists. You'll also have our eternal gratitude and for only $25 bucks we'll give you a digital link to the final show!!!

The Impact

This is our ode to our favorite kids shows growing up, like Mr. Rogers, Sesame Street, and Peewee's Play House (to name a few). It's a story about growing up without sacrificing your inner child and maybe, just maybe, with your help we can achieve our ultimate goal of creating a new lasting kids show that is also for adults.  

Risks & Challenges

This is a brand new play by brand new playwrights! Both John and Alex have theater backgrounds, and years of experience in the New York comedy scene, but that doesn't change the fact that this is a HUGE risk for both of us. We've put a lot of work into this project and we want to be able to give it 100%. 

Other Ways You Can Help

And if you can't donate please consider sharing our project with your friends on Facebook and Twitter. Also keep an eye our for Gary on social media and for more information on the full cast and crew be sure to check out our website garyskidshow.com!

Short Summary John Moreno of the critically acclaimed sketch comedy group Murderfist, and stand up comedian Alex Moore have joined forces to write a play about not growing up. Gary was formerly the host of America's beloved children's television show, Curiosity Cat with Gary. That was until the...incident. Now Gary is back home and living in his mother's basement. :( But with a little help and encouragement from some old friends, Gary is going to start his own brand new underground kids show and rocket ship back to his former glory! 
Gary's Basement is a project over two years in the making and we just need the tiniest bit of help to cross the finish line. With your support we'll be able to make this play all it can be, including muppet-esque puppets, multimedia shorts AND musical numbers! Isn't that awesome?!   What We Need & What You Get Props, Costumes, Puppets, and Videos aren't cheap, but we're not asking for a lot. With a series of $5, $10, ad $25 dollar donations you'll be supporting us and helping us support other independent artists. You'll also have our eternal gratitude and for only $25 bucks we'll give you a digital link to the final show!!!
    The Impact This is our ode to our favorite kids shows growing up, like Mr. Rogers, Sesame Street, and Peewee's Play House (to name a few). It's a story about growing up without sacrificing your inner child and maybe, just maybe, with your help we can achieve our ultimate goal of creating a new lasting kids show that is also for adults.  
    Risks & Challenges This is a brand new play by brand new playwrights! Both John and Alex have theater backgrounds, and years of experience in the New York comedy scene, but that doesn't change the fact that this is a HUGE risk for both of us. We've put a lot of work into this project and we want to be able to give it 100%. 
    Other Ways You Can Help And if you can't donate please consider sharing our project with your friends on Facebook and Twitter. Also keep an eye our for Gary on social media and for more information on the full cast and crew be sure to check out our website garyskidshow.com!

story:
About The Project

It's always difficult to imagine a relevant conversation about war, or about how much loss we're even able to endure, whether our battles are on the ground, or in the mind. 

That is until author Rajiv Joseph gives us a sharp, and haunting voice with which to speak. 

Bengal Tiger At The Baghdad Zoo is the story of an unusual group of characters, bound together in the chaos that becomes Baghdad in 2003. A story that hits you in the gut, punches you in face, and pushes you down the stairs (going a bit overboard, but hopefully you'll come to see why this play has made us so passionate).   

You hear that? That call to prayer? A constellation of minarets surrounds this garden, each one singing at a different key. They come in like a fog, five times a day. Different mosques, all over the city, calling out to God, voices intermingling in the air. When an atheist suddenly finds himself walking around after death, he's got some serious re-evaluating to do - Tiger 

Tom and Kev have been in the city for a few months, connected by a somewhat forced friendship. While trying to endure the intense military invasion, the two American soldiers end up on watch duty at the city zoo, guarding a particularly rowdy Bengal tiger. Provoking an attack by the animal, Kev kills the tiger to save his friend, unleashing a chain of events that lead to the unraveling of all the characters. Able to walk and talk like a human being, the tiger becomes one of the many ghosts to haunt the city, looking for meaning, and redemption, in a seemingly endless mess. Confined by their experiences, and unable to find their way 'home', the soldiers face a relentless merging of reality and aberration, intertwined with their Iraqi translator, who fights a past that tears away at his humanity, and future. 

I'm a gardener! Do you understand? I'm not a terrorist! I'm not an arms dealer! I'm not a translator, or a "terp"! I am a gardener! I am an artist! - Musa

Giving a human voice to the constructed paradigms of war, this story not only tells of the choices that these characters have to make, but also of the relationships forged between them. A connection so powerful that it transcends to the metaphysical plain, echoing the traces and consequences of their existence, as well as their individual battles. 

Harsh, and at times ridiculously funny, the play has not only given us an exciting and inspired piece to tackle, but also the opportunity to work with a talented and diverse group of 15 different theatre and design artists in Montreal. With your help, we'll be able to share this project and perform for three nights, between the 26 and the 28th of February 2015, at Geordie's Espace 4001. 

We're broken, man. You, me, Tiger. It's like we fell through a prism that night at the zoo and each part of ourselves just started to separate. Does your hand still tickle? Does it still itch? It's a phantom limb, Tommy. Just because it's gone doesn't mean it's not there - Kev 

How You Can Help

By raising money to cover part of our budget, you would allow a cast of students to split the revenue from the box-office, basically helping to keep them alive. 
The amount we're hoping for will be used for two crucial elements:
We had our hearts set on a small and intimate venue, which we found in Espace 4001, a black-box theatre along Berri St. For three performances, along with the use of the space before-hand for set-up and run through, the sum of rental fees would come to around $1200. 
In addition, the copyrights to the play, payed to Dramatists Play Service, Inc. would cost $300 ($100 for every showing). 
Now, the fact that you've made it this far down the page and that you're still reading clearly states how awesome and wonderful you are, and because of this, we would like to encourage you or your friends by offering some perks as a humble "thank you" for all your support and generosity. 

The Team

Laurent McCuaig-Pitre Kev

Laurent has always had a passion for make-believe, theatre, film, television, literature and all other forms of artistic expression. An Honours graduate of Dawson College's Professional Theatre program (receiving an award per year for his work), Laurent had the chance to play many memorable characters and develop his craft as a performer. He is currently studying Playwriting at Concordia University. Despite a majority of experience in English, Laurent seeks to forge himself a unique and bilingual career as an actor, writer, director and artist.

Watch out! This young man is already making some big waves. With LAB 87, Laurent jumped onto the francophone scene by taking on the role of Evan in the bilingual production Les Flâneurs Célestes, translated from the American playThe Aliens by Annie Barker. Critics, newspapers, and the general public agree that this young man is definitely on the right track. Laurent is also an independent artist. His new theatre company, 32-Hour Theatre Company, experienced a phenomenal début in the 4th Gala for Student Drama at the Mainline Theatre in Montreal, with his play If Only. This past summer, 32-HTC also produced another play of his creation, This Is Not A Play, as part of the Montreal Saint-Ambroise FRINGE Festival, also at the Mainline Theatre. Just recently, in the event of the SIPA (Short Works) Festival at Concordia, he took on the role of an epileptic lost soul of a man, Noah, in 32-HTC's production of Cockroaches.

Laurent is blessed to be working with such an amazing group of artists and to be entrusted to tell this heartbreaking story of war through a soldier's eyes. 

Ryan Doherty Tom

Ryan is a recent graduate of Dawson's Professional Theatre Program. He is ecstatic to be part of this production, playing alongside a group of such talented actors. Ryan has been honing his craft with roles like Master Ford in Merry Wives of Windsor, Michael Lind in Lion in the Streets and Timms in The History Boys, all showcased at Dawson College. 

Vishesh Abeyratne Tiger 

Vishesh is a young emerging theatre artist and intellectual idiot currently based in his hometown of Montreal, Quebec. Throughout his life, he has harboured a passionate, almost militant belief in the power of words and of storytelling. When he is not acting on the stage, he can be found writing for it with a particular focus on social satire—arising from a natural tendency to take people’s follies and vices seriously—as well as comedy, which he slid into upon realizing that he could look forward to a lifetime of nobody ever fully taking him seriously.

Even during his time as a Playwriting student at Concordia University, Vishesh has staged several productions of his work and made substantial contributions to Montreal’s theatre scene. In his first year alone he mounted an award-winning production of his short absurdist play Fourth Wall Syndrome at the Mainline Theatre as part of the 1st Annual Gala for Student Drama (Best Writing, 2011). The following year, his one-act drama Exposure toured to several high schools across the island of Montreal before being published and licensed by YouthPLAYS, Inc. 

In his final year, his comedy Racial Roulette premiered as a workshop production at the 2013 St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival, where it was nominated for the Chapters Best English Text Award. And just last winter, in his first year out of school, Vishesh was commissioned by actor/dancer/choreographer Deepali Lindblom to write another drama called Wake, Butterfly, which was staged at the Bain St. Michel in a co-production with Infinitheatre. Vishesh also enjoys performing for the stage almost as much as he enjoys creating new work for it. Throughout the better part of last year he had a ball travelling with the Montreal Shakespeare Theatre Company in their 2014 school tour production of A Midsummer Night’s Dream, in which he played Demetrius and Francis Flute. Favourite past roles of Vishesh’s include Sanjeet in his own Racial Roulette, Ishaan in Jocasta’s Noose (Montreal Fringe Festival, 2012), and Jean in Rhinoceros (Dawson Theatre Collective, 2009).

Plays like this only come around every so often, and Vishesh is absolutely thrilled at the opportunity to sink his teeth into one as rich, as funny, as uncomfortable and as tragic as Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo. He would like to thank each and every single one of his talented and wonderful fellow artists on this show that have helped him to grow and stretch as an actor, and he hopes you will all do your part to support local theatre by coming out to see us bring this haunting tale to life.

Mustapha Aramis Musa

Originally from Algeria, Mustapha is a recent graduate of the Conservatoire d’Art Dramatique de Québec. It was in 2007, out of curiosity (and after watching the movie The Mexican), that he tried his hand at theatre for the very first time at the Cégep de Saint-Laurent. Needless to say, a huge passion for the stage was then born. It was through the Cégep’s theatre troupe, improv sessions, and student films that Mustapha quietly developed his abilities, until he finally mustered the courage to audition for a professional program, and in 2011, was admitted to the Conservatoire D’art Dramatique de Québec.

Mustapha is a big fan of comedy, film, literature, music, comics and technology, and it is with great enthusiasm that he begins his new career. This would be his first foray in English theatre, and Rajiv Joseph’s work could not have been better suited, with themes that tend to hit very close to home.

Oliver Price Uday

Oliver is a champion graduate of Concordia's Theatre Performance program. When he's not taking part in university productions like Islands Of Love, Tonight We Play A Sogetto, and Antigone, or working on it's annual Short Works Theatre Festival/SIPAs, Oliver can be found at Montreal's St-Ambroise Fringe Festival, most recently playing the part of Jake, in Gemini Productions' The Voice Of Wisdom. 

Anna Lytvynova Hadia

Anna is thrilled to have the pleasure of working on this spectacularly horrific play. Her other works include roles in Durang’s Wanda’s Visit, the musical The Hazards of Love, a short film entitled Dancing With Dea, as well as directing and stage managing a variety of student productions. Pursuing her major in Drama and Theatre Studies, coupled with a minor in Marketing at McGill University, she combines her academic needs and a thirst for reading by indulging in the writings of Martin Esslin, Bertolt Brecht, Constantin Stanislavski, Augusto Boal, and Nikolai Evreinov. She also furthers her training through workshops and performances with McGill Improv. Working with such an incredible team and portraying peculiar characters is a ghostly and rewarding experience for her. She is incredibly excited to bring this play to the people of Montreal and beyond! 
Raneem Kamal Woman

           

Raneem is an actor at heart, studying business at Concordia. She enjoys yelling at Laurent and reminding her on stage husband that their love was never real. 

Juliano El Masri Man

Juliano is also a business student, with a passion for the arts, and he would like to tell his on stage wife that he always prefered her sister anyway.  

Razanah Silawi Leper

Razanah is currently studying Theatre Design at Concordia. She likes pretzels and working on projects with her bosom friend, Raneem. 
Ahmed Sadik Language Consultant

Born in Baghdad, Iraq during the Gulf War, Ahmed has always been concerned with issues in human rights and humanitarian law. While raised in Montréal, he pursued his legal studies at the University of Ottawa, and graduated in 2013 with the highest honours. Being a passionate legal activist, Ahmed dreams of reforming the law. Multilingual and multidisciplinary by nature, his research interests are oriented toward the connection between law, human rights, medicine, arts and technology. Outside of his legal profession, he is also very passionate about the arts. In fact, he is currently taking an acting class at Concordia as an elective. 

Intrigued by the title of this play, Ahmed originally auditioned to be part of the cast. Due to scheduling conflict, was asked if he would be interested in joining the team as a consultant instead. He generously accepted without hesitation, and has been working with our actors on their pronunciation and understanding of the Iraqi language. His main concern is for them to be able to pronounce the Arabic correctly and with a genuine Iraqi dialect, to preserve the integrity and authenticity of the story. Additionally, as an advisor, he hopes he has been able to help the actors in relating to the context of the story, and reproducing the chaos of the time.

Basma Baydoun Director

Basma is a recent graduate of Concordia's Theatre Design program, but is happiest when directing unsuspecting actors. She enjoys food, long spiteful walks on the beach, and being inspired by amazing plays, like this one. Basma would like to take this opportunity to let you know how incredible the cast and crew have been. They are the kindest, most giving people she has ever had the pleasure of working with, and she's hoping that through this campaign, she'll be able to pay them back for all their hard work, dedication, and trust. She's looking forward to sharing this story with you, because she believes it's one worth telling, and would like to thank everyone (including you, dear reader) for all their love and support. Whoever made it this far down the page: You're a special kind of unicorn, my friend. 

Öykü Önder Designer

Öykü can be recognized by her curly hair and strong Turkish accent. Apart from being a theatre person, she happens to be interested in different branches of design, architecture, literature, visual arts, and various forms of expression. She really enjoys interacting with different cultures and working with people from different backgrounds. She tries to combine her own experiences, both good and bad, with other people’s, and tries to reflect that in her work. Her main interest in theatre is to communicate these different experiences and create an understanding between people.

Before moving to Montreal, Öykü worked in a few shows, both on stage and as part of a crew. She graduated from the International Baccalaureate Program in Istanbul, Turkey, and received the literature award of her graduating class. Through Concordia’s Design for the Theatre Program, she worked several plays put on stage by the theatre department. Most recently, Öykü was the assistant lighting designer for Concordia’s Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes. Currently, she is working on Concordia’s adaptation of Antigone as assistant costume designer, and she’s designing a production of Partners in Crime, which will be staged in Farsi at the Espace 4001.

Mishelle Lam Designer

Mishelle is an artist based in Montreal and Toronto. As a visual artist for most her life, her interest naturally developed towards theatre. She is currently in her third year as a student specializing in Theatre Design at Concordia University in Montreal. She enjoys set and lighting design, and she would love to pursue that further in her career. Mishelle has worked on a few small productions as the key designer for set, costume, and props. Now in the New Year, she is currently designing two shows, both being held in Montreal.

When she is not designing, Mishelle spends her time in the theatre as a technician. She has volunteered as one on many productions, and was employed as a Rover technician for the Montreal Fringe Festival. She would like to invite you to come see Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, as it is a rich and haunting story that is relevant to our time. Please come and support local theatre, and join us as we experience this story together.

Vanessa Zaurrini Sound Designer 

Vanessa likes making sounds, recording sounds, and unintentionally waking her neighbours up with said sounds in a charming unending serenade at 3 in the morning. Far from a hobby, Vanessa’s sound design and music composition has appeared in many interdisciplinary projects ranging from live design for dance at LeCollab’Art, to Concordia’s Angels in America and 60x60. She also composes for indie video games, films and animations. As a member of The Concordia Laptop Orchestra (CLOrk), she enjoys collaborating with other musicians in eclectic performances, and can additionally be found singing and playing bass with her band. She is currently completing a BFA in Electroacoustics at Concordia.

Ulayu Sequaluk Make Up Artist

Based in Montreal, Ulayu has a passion for the business and a knack for special-effect transformations. She's been gaining experience by working steadily in Theatre, and honing her skills at Collège Inter-De. 

Other Ways You Can Help

TELL THE WORLD!

Mishelle is an artist based in Montreal and Toronto. As a visual artist for most her life, her interest naturally developed towards theatre. She is currently in her third year as a student specializing in Theatre Design at Concordia University in Montreal. She enjoys set and lighting design, and she would love to pursue that further in her career. Mishelle has worked on a few small productions as the key designer for set, costume, and props. Now in the New Year, she is currently designing two shows, both being held in Montreal.
When she is not designing, Mishelle spends her time in the theatre as a technician. She has volunteered as one on many productions, and was employed as a Rover technician for the Montreal Fringe Festival. She would like to invite you to come see Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, as it is a rich and haunting story that is relevant to our time. Please come and support local theatre, and join us as we experience this story together.


Vanessa Zaurrini Sound Designer 




Vanessa likes making sounds, recording sounds, and unintentionally waking her neighbours up with said sounds in a charming unending serenade at 3 in the morning. Far from a hobby, Vanessa’s sound design and music composition has appeared in many interdisciplinary projects ranging from live design for dance at LeCollab’Art, to Concordia’s Angels in America and 60x60. She also composes for indie video games, films and animations. As a member of The Concordia Laptop Orchestra (CLOrk), she enjoys collaborating with other musicians in eclectic performances, and can additionally be found singing and playing bass with her band. She is currently completing a BFA in Electroacoustics at Concordia.

Ulayu Sequaluk Make Up Artist

Based in Montreal, Ulayu has a passion for the business and a knack for special-effect transformations. She's been gaining experience by working steadily in Theatre, and honing her skills at Collège Inter-De. 


 
  Other Ways You Can Help TELL THE WORLD!

story:
Close your eyes. Imagine a moment in your life when you had doubt, fear, regret, or challenge. Now envision yourself rising above that moment to a place of self-triumph. What if that moment of triumph was set to music, dance, harmony, and artistic bliss?

Not your mother's fairie tales~ a princess self love story!  is a vision of real vaudeville proportions that combines a narrated tableaux(still posing that tells a story), burlesque, J~set dance (hip-hop dancing) from the Twilight dance group, cabaret, live & original music from Whisky Christy and the Half Pint Orchestra and friends, and theatrical side show. It should be something that wows the audience and brings something new to the Greensboro, NC stage while actually recapturing the roots of vaudeville. These will be adult dark fairie tales of self love ~ empowerment, romance, and social tales of personal growth. In each story the Princess is the hero, the victim, and the villain. Why? Well, because as humans we are always getting ourselves into messes, but luckily as smart empowered women we also have the ability to find our ways out of it as well.

January 30th and 31st at 8pm in the Crowne Room of the Carolina Theatre (310 Greene St, Greensboro, NC) we intend to create an artistic vaudevillian experience.

Tickets will go on sale via www.carolinatheatre.com

Feline Entertainment with head kitten Tiger RoxXx (Sky Bradshaw) as synergizer has been producing innovative and successful shows since 2008. In the history of the scores of projects that have graced stages up and down the east coast the three main principles that have kept the community, artists, and these productions going strong together have been:

1) FUN ~ have fun, be fun, share fun

2) CARE ~ care about what you do, who you do it with, and the audience you do it for

3) GIVE ~ give it all on stage, give back to the entertainment community and to the community that supports you!

These principles allow amazing shows full of amazing performers year after year! We have been saving the 'princesses self love story!'  and are finally ready to put on the show of our lifetimes! That means we need some Fairie Good Parents to help us out!

We have been accepted to the 2015 Greensboro Fringe Festival. (this will be our sixth Fringe Production and hopefully our fifth sold out Fringe show!) The International Fringe festival (http://www.greensborofringefestival.org ) is a showcase of the cities best ‘fringe’ arts, bringing a variety of styles of artist interpretations to the city during a two week period of time~ in 2015 it will be held in January and February. We are always proud to be a part of such an amazing showcase of talent and are ready to bring it! This year our offerings are not only artistically intense, but their message is emotionally amazing… when you add the fact that we would like to couple with Girls Rock NC (http://www.girlsrocknc.org) by giving our tickets proceeds to support their cause makes the moral of these stories and your heart sing! If you don’t know about Girls Rock NC… well, they ROCK. They are an organization that that empowers girls and women -- through creative expression -- to become confident and engaged members of our communities. They accomplish this by focusing on the “three Cs”: creativity, confidence and collaboration. 

That’s why we need your help. If we can crowdfund our overhead costs, then all the money and awareness we raise goes straight to our charity. In the past we have beat the streets going door to door asking for support to be able to raise enough to cover our overhead costs, but let’s face it, it’s 2014 and with the internet crowdfunding is the way to go! This method is more efficient and better for everyone involved. We still draw a great deal of awareness to the Girls Rock NC through our crowdfunding, while raising money to do what we love in our performance, so we can in turn give the money we earn back to them! 

Where will this money go?

Well, as we said before we want to give all the tickets sales to our charity, plus keep our ticket prices affordable so that everyone that wants to see the show can! That means we are crowdfunding for our overhead costs… they break down pretty easy.

We also will be doing a benefit burlesque show on December 19th at Club Orion 4618 W Market St, Greensboro, NC 27407! All proceeds of this show will go towards the overhead costs of the Fringe show as well! The cast as well as Whisky Christy and the Half Pint Orchestra will be strutting our stuff starting at 10pm on Orions stage for only $7 at the door! We hope to see you there!

This year Not your mother's fairie tales~ a princesses self love story!  will be performed at the beautiful Carolina Theatre upstairs in the Crown. The rental there for two nights fully staffed will take about a little over a third of what we are asking in crowdfunding. Then we will be building a moderate set, nothing to cheap… but not too fancy and some bang up costuming, which will take another third. To run a production like this there are always costs people don’t think about from the cost of creating the incentives down to running ads and printing posters, so the last third will go into a lot of miscellaneous production overhead costs. I once spent $64 on glow sticks because an out of town performer lost all her luggage and her debit card was frozen from her bank due to out of town charges… the glow sticks were the fastest and easiest solution for the show to go on! In that overhead cost I would also like to give this hard working team of mine a little scratch if there is anything left, even if it only breaks down to $50 a performer. A little appreciation goes a long way! ALSO Any overage we receive will surely go to performer appreciation and enhanced costuming as well!

We are very proud to pour our hearts out on the stage with every performance, we are even more grateful to do it for such an amazing cause, the fact that a great community like you is willing to support our dreams and that a circular effect can be made through out our Universe really is astounding! Thanks! Even for just taking time to read this! Some times thank you just doesn’t seem to say enough… so hopefully we can show you just how we grateful we feel by putting on the most amazing show we know how!
