story:
Playing February 27th to March 7th 2015!
Gene Frankel Theatre
24 Bond Street
NYC


About The Show

After a very successful workshop last year, Toy Box Theatre Company is now proud to present the fully realized WORLD PREMIERE of Ryan Reilly’s new play, Worth House. 


Steve is in the doghouse . . . again. (Well, actually he's in a tent in the backyard.) 
A recovering alcoholic’s act of bold determination, or just a pathetic last resort? 
His wife is over it.  His 9 year-old son just wants to join him for S'mores. 
A story of last chances and knowing when to finally call it quits.



How You Can Help

It takes a village to build a show set in the Village of Worth, Illinois.  We need help to fund all aspects of the show. Everything from rehearsal space to costumes, even printing the programs.  Your donations will go directly to the world premiere production of Worth House.

Here is a look at our budget:

Here are some examples of how your contribution can help:

•  $100 pays for one of the actor’s costumes

•  $250 pays for one week of rehearsal

•  $1,000 pays for the materials we need to build the set

•  $2,500 pays for a week’s rental of the theatre space

Our perks are great, too! Each donation of $25 or more receives a gift from us.  Also, you will have our great thanks for supporting us from the very beginning.


The Worth House Family


We are so happy to have assembled this amazing group of artists to help us realize our vision of Worth House and bring it to you. Please meet our family...

Cast:

Patty: Andrea Prestinario

Steve: Tom Frank

Cheri: Deanna McGovern

Jack: Jack Clark

Carl: Andy Phillips


Creative Team:

Playwright: Ryan Reilly

Director: Ken Urso

Stage Manager: Jordan Bean

Set Designer: Jason Simms

Lighting Designer: Tony Galaska

Sound Designer: James Sparber

Costume Designer: Jennifer Paar

Projection Designer: Shashwat Gupta

Graphic Designer: Ian Toyozumi

Producer: Jon Barsness

Producer: Mike Holmes


Thank you for your support.  

See you opening night!

-Toy Box Theatre Company



About Toy Box Theatre Company

Founded in New York City as a not-for-profit corporation in 2002, Toy Box Theatre Company engages our audience in emotionally resonant and thought-provoking theatrical experiences through multi-disciplinary presentations and original works.  Toy Box believes that incorporating a variety of genres of the performing arts into our productions enriches the process for the artists involved as well as providing a unique and exciting experience for the audience.

Toy Box Theatre Company consists of Jonathan Barsness, Mike Holmes, Ryan Reilly, James Sparber, and Ken Urso, who share the role of artistic director and make all programming decisions together.  Toy Box produces at least one full scale production each year along with several readings and other developmental performances.  Since 2002, Toy Box has produced twelve full-scale productions and countless readings and workshop productions at various theatres throughout New York City.

MAKE SURE TO CHECK US OUT ONLINE:  www.toyboxtheatre.org

story:
Why Improvisation?

In my recent practice as a dance artist, I’ve moved passed an identity as a dancer and begun to consider what it means to be a human with a body who dances. In my recent training at the San Francisco Conservatory of Dance, my perspective as a dancer shifted to that of a storyteller, sensitive to the diverging details that shape every story, ones I gained access to in and through the body and in collaboration with others. These details include the struggle for power and vulnerability and the emotional reality of the human being. My role as a researcher built upon my role as a storyteller, of the body, its function, and as a surveyor of my habits and personality traits in my assessment of the former to track my progress.

In my recent experiences as an art teacher, I have learned useful lessons in the dance studio that apply to teaching students in a classroom. I have a deeper understanding of the individuality of my student's learning needs, and cultivate an environment where experimentation and risk taking is rewarded. I am consciously working to observe my student's habits and patterns in their modes of thinking, ways they begin a project, ways they talk about and perceive creative work, and ways of communicating with me and one another. I am interested in understanding the ways dance can serve as a useful tool in other art forms and modes of learning. 

 

A Little More on Contact Improvisation!

Contact Improvisation is an evolving system of movement initiated in 1972 by American choreographer Steve Paxton. The improvised dance form is based on the communication between two moving bodies that are in physical contact and their combined relationship to the physical laws that govern their motion—gravity, momentum, inertia. The body, in order to open to these sensations, learns to release excess muscular tension and abandon a certain quality of willfulness to experience the natural flow of movement. Practice includes rolling, falling, being upside down, following a physical point of contact, supporting and giving weight to a partner

(defined by Steve Paxton and others, from Contact Quarterly website)

 

A Video of Contact Improvisation!

Chris Aiken, Ray Chung and Mike Vargas perform at Judson Church in NYC.

Click Here!!!

 

A Little More on Nancy!

Nancy Stark Smith’s training as an athlete and gymnast led her to study and perform modern and postmodern dance in the early 1970s, greatly influenced by the dance/theater improvisation group the Grand Union and the Judson Dance Theater breakthroughs of the 1960s in NYC. She graduated from Oberlin College with a degree in dance and writing. In 1972, she danced in the first performances of Contact Improvisation in NYC and has since been central to its development as a dancer, teacher, performer, organizer, and writer/publisher, working extensively over the years with Steve Paxton and others. She travels throughout the world teaching and performing contact and other improvised dance work at festivals, schools, and art centers, working with many favorite dance partners and performance makers including Ray Chung, Karen Nelson, Andrew Harwood, Julyen Hamilton, and musician Mike Vargas.

In 1975 she cofounded Contact Quarterly, a vehicle for moving ideas, an international dance and improvisational journal. To continue reading her bio click here!

 

What I Need & What You Get!

The entire cost of the intensive is around $1,705.

$1,575 of that goes to Nancy Stark Smith and the individuals hosting the intensive, and to EARTHDANCE for room and board, who’s vision is to create a vibrant, curious, and equitable society grounded in social justice, healthy community living, embodied movement, and ecological stewardship.

The other $130 is for transportation to and from EARTHDANCE, a special dinner after the workshop in North Hampton at the end of the intensive, and for laundry.  The extra $295 is to help cover part of my rent back in Brooklyn for the month of February. I’ve discovered a way to survive in New York City as an artist, but it means living paycheck to paycheck. I will be away from both my jobs for three weeks, unable to earn enough money in the month of January to pay for February’s rent. I am doing what I can to make as much money before hand, but am factoring in this safety net just in case things get tight.

If I don’t reach my entire goal, I risk missing the opportunity to participate in the intensive. If I don’t reach at least 50% of my goal, I will use the funds I raise to get myself to EARTHDANCE to take class, where I can stay for as many days as I can afford. However, this means I will not be able to work with Nancy Stark Smith or the other 22 participants attending.

I will thank everyone who contributes to this campaign, and send a personal thank you to anyone who donates over $25 dollars! Other perks include detailed notes taken throughout the intensive, photos take and creative writing written during the intensive, personalized improvisational scores, written AND performed for backers, a film in which three of the scores will be featured, and an ORIGINAL limited edition print created for this occasion! 

The Impact

My training forced me to consider what remains overlooked in a dancer’s practice that informs our humanity and shapes the scope of our influence on the world; the rigor of work in the face of exhaustion, perseverance in the face of judgment, the value of treating practice as performance, embracing failure as essential to growth, and confrontation of the unknown. 

The San Francisco Conservatory of Dance introduced me to improvisation as a form that allows constant discovery and a changing landscape in which to work. One of my teachers, Christian Burns exemplifies these attributes.  He invites his students into the space to work alongside him. He is a patient and considerate teacher, which is visible in his study and practice of improvisation. His teachings on improvisation helped dis-indoctrinate me from a right or wrong mentality—a mentality that substantially limits my ability to progress, my willingness to take risks in service of a greater vision, and my belief in myself, which affects the work I am able to do.

This ongoing discovery clarifies the nature of my craft and strengthens my voice, which is articulated by my body, outside of the realm of language. It gives me the tools to deepen my understanding of embodied knowledge and allows greater insight into other art forms such as drawing, printmaking, and conceptual studies. Immersion in the conversations and practices around improvisation, and the scope of its influence, is essential to understand art's capacity to transform us—the parts of art that speak to our humanity.

Contact Improvisation bridged communities through the building and strengthening of trust, through the cultivation of self-reliance as a product of deep listening, and encourages fearlessness through a creative endeavor. It allows me to see the connections between things, that at first, that might not seem like they fit together. 

Support a dance artist to help her continue her education and skill development in a vibrant community, among a group of dedicated dance practitioners. Support a teacher who is passionate about providing her students the environment in which to cultivate a meaningful relationship to art. Support an activist who believes art is essential to the future of this planet. Thank you!  

Risks & Challenges

My biggest challenges will be the physical and emotional demands of the intensive. Dancing 40+ hours a week in a highly physical form will be challenging for my mental and physical stamina. I will also be challenged by the collaboration the form requires, a prolonged focus that will require deep listening and attentiveness. I will be challenged by the physical limitations of the body and the intensity of the three week practice of the form.

I believe I am fit to take on these challenges because they are the same reasons I want to attend the intensive. I want to experience a nine hour day in which I focus on the continuity of channeling fearlessness, and selflessness. I aim to become more intuitive, more patient and a better listener within my improvisation practice. I am driven to break habitual movement patterns in search for a more organic flow that is at the center of Contact Improvisation. The circumstances defined by the structure, environment and participants of this intensive will present a unique set of challenges that allow me to work on these goals, . 

And I am ready for the challenges! One of the most valuable things Summer Lee Rhatigan taught me at the San Francisco Conservatory is how to work. She taught me that dancing often requires more mental preparation than physical. She taught me the importance of pushing past what you believe is your limit, because you are very often surprised by what you will find when you do. She taught me the body is resilient and stubborn, able to take over control when the mind falters, and to trust it when it does. She taught me how to rely on it. She taught me how to learn new things about myself and discover . She taught me the value of falling and failing. 

The training I received at the San Francisco Conservatory of Dance has allowed me to develop a new kind of relationship to challenges. It has taught me to expect and welcome them, for they are part of all meaningful work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that is ok! Please help by spreading the word, posting to Facebook, sending an email, telling a friend! Any kind of contribution you can make, large or small, is greatly appreciated. 

THANK YOU!!!

What I Need & What You Get!
The entire cost of the intensive is around $1,705.
$1,575 of that goes to Nancy Stark Smith and the individuals hosting the intensive, and to EARTHDANCE for room and board, who’s vision is to create a vibrant, curious, and equitable society grounded in social justice, healthy community living, embodied movement, and ecological stewardship.
The other $130 is for transportation to and from EARTHDANCE, a special dinner after the workshop in North Hampton at the end of the intensive, and for laundry.  The extra $295 is to help cover part of my rent back in Brooklyn for the month of February. I’ve discovered a way to survive in New York City as an artist, but it means living paycheck to paycheck. I will be away from both my jobs for three weeks, unable to earn enough money in the month of January to pay for February’s rent. I am doing what I can to make as much money before hand, but am factoring in this safety net just in case things get tight.
If I don’t reach my entire goal, I risk missing the opportunity to participate in the intensive. If I don’t reach at least 50% of my goal, I will use the funds I raise to get myself to EARTHDANCE to take class, where I can stay for as many days as I can afford. However, this means I will not be able to work with Nancy Stark Smith or the other 22 participants attending.
I will thank everyone who contributes to this campaign, and send a personal thank you to anyone who donates over $25 dollars! Other perks include detailed notes taken throughout the intensive, photos take and creative writing written during the intensive, personalized improvisational scores, written AND performed for backers, a film in which three of the scores will be featured, and an ORIGINAL limited edition print created for this occasion! 

The Impact
My training forced me to consider what remains overlooked in a dancer’s practice that informs our humanity and shapes the scope of our influence on the world; the rigor of work in the face of exhaustion, perseverance in the face of judgment, the value of treating practice as performance, embracing failure as essential to growth, and confrontation of the unknown. 
The San Francisco Conservatory of Dance introduced me to improvisation as a form that allows constant discovery and a changing landscape in which to work. One of my teachers, Christian Burns exemplifies these attributes.  He invites his students into the space to work alongside him. He is a patient and considerate teacher, which is visible in his study and practice of improvisation. His teachings on improvisation helped dis-indoctrinate me from a right or wrong mentality—a mentality that substantially limits my ability to progress, my willingness to take risks in service of a greater vision, and my belief in myself, which affects the work I am able to do.
This ongoing discovery clarifies the nature of my craft and strengthens my voice, which is articulated by my body, outside of the realm of language. It gives me the tools to deepen my understanding of embodied knowledge and allows greater insight into other art forms such as drawing, printmaking, and conceptual studies. Immersion in the conversations and practices around improvisation, and the scope of its influence, is essential to understand art's capacity to transform us—the parts of art that speak to our humanity.
Contact Improvisation bridged communities through the building and strengthening of trust, through the cultivation of self-reliance as a product of deep listening, and encourages fearlessness through a creative endeavor. It allows me to see the connections between things, that at first, that might not seem like they fit together. 
Support a dance artist to help her continue her education and skill development in a vibrant community, among a group of dedicated dance practitioners. Support a teacher who is passionate about providing her students the environment in which to cultivate a meaningful relationship to art. Support an activist who believes art is essential to the future of this planet. Thank you!  

Risks & Challenges
My biggest challenges will be the physical and emotional demands of the intensive. Dancing 40+ hours a week in a highly physical form will be challenging for my mental and physical stamina. I will also be challenged by the collaboration the form requires, a prolonged focus that will require deep listening and attentiveness. I will be challenged by the physical limitations of the body and the intensity of the three week practice of the form.
I believe I am fit to take on these challenges because they are the same reasons I want to attend the intensive. I want to experience a nine hour day in which I focus on the continuity of channeling fearlessness, and selflessness. I aim to become more intuitive, more patient and a better listener within my improvisation practice. I am driven to break habitual movement patterns in search for a more organic flow that is at the center of Contact Improvisation. The circumstances defined by the structure, environment and participants of this intensive will present a unique set of challenges that allow me to work on these goals, . 
And I am ready for the challenges! One of the most valuable things Summer Lee Rhatigan taught me at the San Francisco Conservatory is how to work. She taught me that dancing often requires more mental preparation than physical. She taught me the importance of pushing past what you believe is your limit, because you are very often surprised by what you will find when you do. She taught me the body is resilient and stubborn, able to take over control when the mind falters, and to trust it when it does. She taught me how to rely on it. She taught me how to learn new things about myself and discover . She taught me the value of falling and failing. 
The training I received at the San Francisco Conservatory of Dance has allowed me to develop a new kind of relationship to challenges. It has taught me to expect and welcome them, for they are part of all meaningful work.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, that is ok! Please help by spreading the word, posting to Facebook, sending an email, telling a friend! Any kind of contribution you can make, large or small, is greatly appreciated. 
THANK YOU!!!

story:
Our mission: Arts in the Open fuses nature with live performance and invites our audience to enjoy the best of what Colorado has to offer. Our productions are a healthy option that gets the whole family up and moving. As a Leave No Trace Company, our goal is to educate the public about Colorado trail preservation as well as reach a wide range of audiences and expose them to a variety of theatrical productions.


What We Do: Arts in the Open performs at various locations throughout Colorado, primarily at Chautauqua Park in Boulder.  We do two shows a year - one summer production and one fall production.  Our hikes are usually at a moderate level/pace and last no more than 2 hours.  When you first arrive, you will be greeted by your hiking guide who will lead the way down the trail to each scene location.  Once you arrive at a scene location, you can sit back and relax and watch a scene from the production.  Once the scene is complete, we all gather our things and hike to the next location.  All our productions use minimal props and costumes.  Our performers literally use "what nature gives them".  We've done fun adaptations of classic fairy tales, Shakespeare, literary classics, you name it!


2016 Productions: Goldilocks by Patti Murtha. Opening June 4th - National Trails Day! Goldilocks is a curious girl who loves to explore the world around her! Follow her on the trails as she encounters unlocked doors, a family of bears, and many other adventures in her quest for what is "just right."  From the author of last year's Little Red and Her Feisty Friends, this adaptation of the classic story is sure to please. Runs June 4th (National Trails Days!) through July 31st.

The Treasures of Toothless Jack: A Pick-A-Path Play, an original script written by Joaquin Aviña and Matthew Davis. Remember those books where you got to choose your own adventure? In The Treasures of Toothless Jack two friends are pulled into a mysterious treasure hunt where they will take the audience along on their search through the Rocky mountains. Along the way you will get a chance to choose the path of our adventurers as they are pulled into a mystery of lost treasure, challenge bad guys and possibly end the debate of whether a tomato is a fruit or a vegetable. Will it lead to countless riches or will they face a less fortunate fate? 

Where We Perform: Arts in the Open performs every weekend in June/July and September/October at Chautauqua Park in Boulder.  We also do shows for Girl Scout troops, Rec Centers, Boys & Girls Clubs, and Public Schools.

What We Need & What You Get

As a non-profit, all our funding comes from donations, ticket sales, and grants.  We pride ourselves on being able to compensate our cast and crew for their time and talent.  Each performer and crew member is paid as much as we can squeeze out of the budget.  Just $150 could fund our Open Space trail permit, and $5,000 could fund over half of our entire season!  All donations are tax deductible and your contribution goes towards funding the performing arts as well as environmental preservation right here in Colorado. We have many unique perks this year for kids and adults alike.  We want to show how much we appreciate you!


The Impact


Who We Reach: On average, we reach over 500 kids per production, that's over 1,000 kids and their families per year! With such a wide range of audiences all over the front range, we have a unique opportunity to share our mission of supporting the performing arts, as well as environmental preservation, all over the state.

story:
Who are we

Broccolily Theatre began as an idea in 2014, to make theatre that has a direct interaction with the community in which it is made. Broccolily are based in Hull and strive to make drama of the highest quality with and for young people in the city.  We want to inspire a young audience in an area that traditionally has low engagement with the arts.

We’re interested in the unheard voices and stories that surround us, be them huge or tiny, with a focus on the tales of young people. Our shows will always be colourful, simple and smart, as we believe that theatre for young people should be as exciting and innovative as any.

In early 2015 Broccolily Theatre were commissioned by Hull Culture and Leisure to produce and tour a play that promoted reading and libraries in Hull for the Reading Agency's nationwide scheme, the Summer Reading Challenge. We created a play, full of snails and silliness, that we took to over 14,000 children, and with a few workshops, events and a video thrown in, we got Hull's children reading! 

It was during this commission, after a stand out show at Bridgeview Pupil Referral Unit, that Ten Foot Tales was born…

Ten Foot Tales  

Tenfoot (noun)

 A ten foot wide passageway located behind houses. Named so because of its width. (origin Hull)

The baines are larking down the tenfoot

Ten Foot Tales will create stories with young people and transform these stories into a play which is professionally produced in association with Hull Truck Theatre and performed by actors in their fantastic Studio Theatre! 

We will be working with children at Bridgeview Pupil Referral Unit, a Hull Primary School for children with Behaviour Emotion and Social Difficulties. We will facilitate extracurricular drama workshops during which stories will be created. We will then collate these these stories into an hour long play that will be played to it’s creators and a wide audience of schools and the public. 

Through specially crafted story workshops we will use drama techniques to engage with 30 children, aged 8-11. Bridgeview teaches young people of whom 95% have Social Emotional and Mental Health needs, 22% have Autistic Spectrum Disorder and 5% have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. 24% of the children have some speech, language and communication needs. 59% of children have a statement of special needs, 84% receive pupil premium funding and 24% of the children are in care (Looked After Children). 

“Many of our children have low self-esteem and lack confidence so turning their ideas and stories into a professional piece of theatre would be a great boost and is not something we as a school could normally do without partners like Broccolily Theatre.” - Gerald Fox, Teacher at Bridgeview

The workshops will develop the kid’s collaboration skills and get them to collectively create original stories. We want to provide the opportunity for them to explore their own ideas with full autonomy. The workshops will begin at the end of February 2016 and run for a term. 

We will then work with local practitioners including actors, a designer and a stage manager, to dramatise these stories. The play will be performed at Hull Truck Theatre. 

We want to create an extremely high-quality piece of Children’s theatre to celebrate the creativity of these complex kids, show just how far their imaginations can take them, and make them feel Ten Foot tall!

The show will be performed back to Bridgeview, other primary schools and members of the public.

How you can help!

Why we need to raise £1000 

£500 - will allow one facilitator to deliver 10 specialist story workshops at Bridgeview Pupil Referral Unit to 30 children aged 8-11.  

£500 -  will cover all materials used for our set and props for the production. 


If you want to find out more or track the progress of the project follow us...

on twitter:   @broccolilyuk       #tenfoottales

or visit:  www.broccolilytheatre.com


Thank you so much for your support!

story:
What is THE MAGNUS EFFECT?

The Magnus Effect is a gutsy new theatre piece, written by Hannah Van Sciver and produced by The Greenfield Collective, premiering in Philadelphia this July. It tells the story of five unlikely strangers who come together with a common goal: overcoming their fear of flying. ​One part play, one part dance and one part airline jingle, The Magnus Effect is an exploration of how and why we've come to dread the world around us. 

Why you can feel especially AWESOME about this play:
  • It features a diverse cast and production team of some of the finest emerging talent in Philadelphia.
  • We are providing free tickets for student theatre makers through Philadelphia Young Playwrights.
  • The Magnus Effect deals with mental health in an unconventional and nuanced way. We are reaching out to great organizations like HealthyMinds Philly, in order to make resources available to folks who might want to get involved with mental health in Philly, post-show.
  • Each performance will have a pre-show act, featuring a local artist sharing original work centering on the theme of anxiety. 

​Production Staff
Playwright: Hannah Van Sciver
Director: David O'Connor
Assistant Director: Sarah Zerod
Lead Designer: Sara Outing
Music Composition: Sarah Van Sciver
Production Stage Manager: Stephanie Sintef
Development Intern: Rowan Hepps Keeney
​
Cast
Richard Chan
David Pica
Zoe Richards
Amanda Jill Robinson
​Hannah Van Sciver​​


What is THE GREENFIELD COLLECTIVE?
The Greenfield Collective is a Philadelphia-based company of courageous and fiercely original theatre artists, led by Hannah Van Sciver. We are storytellers, musicians, movers and shakers. Our work is gutsy, gritty, heartfelt, provocative, and distinctly human. We create unconventional theatre for non-traditional audiences, with a strong community engagement element. 

Past productions include Fifty Days at Iliam (top-pick for Fringe: Phindie, Classicizing Philadelphia), Bicycle Face (top-pick for SolowFest: CityPaper, Phindie), and Marbles (top-pick for Fringe: Phindie).

WE ARE:
Joseph Ahmed
Elizabeth Audley
Richard Chan
Mal Cherifi
Amanda Jill Robinson
Sara Outing
Hannah Van Sciver
(Full bios: here.)

Where will the $$ go??
The Greenfield Collective is a young company of emerging artists. No matter how you cut it, making theatre costs money. Particularly when you're young. Particularly when you're emerging. Particularly when you're producing original work. 


The money raised through this campaign will go towards covering:
-Performance Space Rental 
-Stipends for Actors
-Stipends for Designers
-Sets! Lights! Sound! Props! Costumes!
-Marketing Costs & Outreach

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign. (On facebook. Via email. Via Twitter.)
  • Like us on facebook.
  • Buy tickets to the show.
  • Volunteer to help with load-in, strike, or front-of-house management. (No experience necessary.)

Many, many, many thanks, and boundless love.
-The Greenfield Collective

story:
For the past four years we have been on hand to provide the citizens of Boomtown with everything they need to continue their life long careers of claiming benefits and as with any successful public service we are expanding! Long have the frivolities at the Brighton Fringe Festival gone unchecked and unregulated but no more! The JobCentre will be there to ensure forms are filled, work books are completed and sanctions have been imposed.

 

With any expansion of services there are always associated costs and it is up to you, the job hungry public, to provide the capital we need to help you get back to work. We have a range of opportunities available to you ranging from having us fill out your forms for you (because heaven knows there is no way you could even do that properly...) all the way to your own custom made Sanction Man Jumpsuit (Note: This does not entitle you to the job of sanction man). 

 

A lot of you are very familiar with the JobCentre's rules and regulations which is why we have Rapid Reclaim Appointments available for you and your fellow benefit guzzlers. There are one-to-one appointments available for those actually looking to work and for those of you in a group that know they can shift all the work onto their one friend who never complains, there are group bookings available too.

 

Too lazy to even turn up to an appointment? Does the thought of earning your bi-weekly pay make me feel a little sick inside? Or do you just love us so much you want the whole world to know? Well we have the T-shirts for you! For a small donation you can skip the hassle of actually coming to the Jobcentre by advertising for us instead.

 

For those of you in truly dire straights (your parents have kicked you out of the spare room, your trust fund has finally run out or maybe you've reached thirty and realised you have accomplished nothing) we recommend the Mega Job Pack. This pack contains all you will need to get a job and stand on your own two feet! Stickers, a T-shirt and a Rapid Reclaim Appointment can all be yours for just a small donation.

 

Remember, we are here for your benefits.

story:
Imagine the impossible theatrical crossover of “Requiem for a Dream” with Broadway’s beloved “Rent” and a dash of much needed comedic relief. 

We’re taking our first theatre production NEXT TO NORMAL into the next phase of its development. Help us tackle mental health stigma in the United States via an innovative and provocative piece of musical theatre.

We are “The ‘Next to Normal’ Project”, we are putting on a beautiful piece of theater that can make a difference, and we would love for you to be a part of it.

What is it?

NEXT TO NORMAL is “a powerful rock musical that grapples with mental illness in a suburban family and expands the scope of subject matter for musicals.” (https://www.pulitzer.org/winners/tom-kitt-and-b...)  

The story focuses on Diana, who is this sharply witty human who has Bipolar 1 disorder (Bipolar disorder affects approximately 5.7 million adult Americans (National Institute of Mental Health)), and how her life and those of her immediate family progresses while grappling with various treatments and setbacks. Themes hit upon in the show include: addiction, ECT, mental health awareness, PTSD, trauma, modern psychiatry, and therapy.

“I couldn’t possibly write ‘Next to Normal’, but God, I could weep and watch ‘Next to Normal’ five times.” 

-Lin-Manuel Miranda

 

What are we doing to promote mental health?

Through this campaign, we’re raising funds for the next phase of NEXT TO NORMAL. A production that we intend to approach with mental health as the foremost concern. 

  • The Creative Team

The Creative Team is being entirely composed of artistic leaders in their fields who are also diagnosed with mental health disorders or past trauma. We are showing, with our actions, that people with mental health illnesses can create extraordinary things.

  • The Rehearsal Process

We are inviting in colleagues and friends who have been diagnosed with Bipolar I and II or who have dealt with addiction to come in early during the rehearsal process and share their stories with the cast and crew in a Q&A format. By opening the door to communicate with real humans, this creates a rehearsal environment based in authenticity and vulnerability that will be key to telling Diana’s story with as much integrity as possible.

The Choreographer herself has lived with a lifelong diagnosis of Bipolar II and will not only be choreographing the dance numbers, but the physical ticks and posture of our leading characters as they experience a wide range of emotions and mental states.

  • The Playbill

Rather than an ordinary playbill, Taylor Dolan will design and create a zine/booklet of statistics regarding mental health and resources to enable seeking out help in the surrounding areas. This will give the audience a tangible object to start conversations, and explore the topic once they leave the theatre.

Who are we?

“The ‘Next to Normal’ Project” is a part of a wholly new community theatre company blossoming in Bentonville, Arkansas. We will be working under the fiscal sponsorship umbrella of Trike Theatre, a professional children’s theatre in Bentonville.

What we need?

We’re very grateful to be supported by Trike Theatre and Arts Center of the Ozarks. With a mutually beneficial volunteer scheme, the members of our production have been able to trade volunteer hours in exchange for using their facilities. This has allowed us to keep down our overall costs significantly. What we are left with are the essentials for bringing this production to life, and that's what we would like to cover with this campaign.

Your donation will ensure that we can:

Cover liscensing fees

Provide our crew with small stipends

Have a live orchestra

Hire videos and sound equipment. 

Successfully market and distribute our project.

Ensure a Covid-19 safe environment

Times are tough 

We understand! You’ve made it this far and so we know that you care about supporting the arts. Here are three things you can do now to support our campaign without spending a penny:

Share this page with 3 friends

Engage with us on social media

Come to auditions! https://www.facebook.com/events/4321793471178385

Thank you.

We are so grateful for whatever you can give. Please help us make this project that we are so passionate about.
story_txt: Imagine the impossible theatrical crossover of “Requiem for a Dream” with Broadway’s beloved “Rent” and a dash of much needed comedic relief. We’re taking our first theatre production NEXT TO NORMAL into the next phase of its development. Help us tackle mental health stigma in the United States via an innovative and provocative piece of musical theatre.We are “The ‘Next to Normal’ Project”, we are putting on a beautiful piece of theater that can make a difference, and we would love for you to be a part of it.What is it?NEXT TO NORMAL is “a powerful rock musical that grapples with mental illness in a suburban family and expands the scope of subject matter for musicals.” (https://www.pulitzer.org/winners/tom-kitt-and-b...)  The story focuses on Diana, who is this sharply witty human who has Bipolar 1 disorder (Bipolar disorder affects approximately 5.7 million adult Americans (National Institute of Mental Health)), and how her life and those of her immediate family progresses while grappling with various treatments and setbacks. Themes hit upon in the show include: addiction, ECT, mental health awareness, PTSD, trauma, modern psychiatry, and therapy.“I couldn’t possibly write ‘Next to Normal’, but God, I could weep and watch ‘Next to Normal’ five times.” -Lin-Manuel Miranda What are we doing to promote mental health?Through this campaign, we’re raising funds for the next phase of NEXT TO NORMAL. A production that we intend to approach with mental health as the foremost concern. The Creative TeamThe Creative Team is being entirely composed of artistic leaders in their fields who are also diagnosed with mental health disorders or past trauma. We are showing, with our actions, that people with mental health illnesses can create extraordinary things.The Rehearsal ProcessWe are inviting in colleagues and friends who have been diagnosed with Bipolar I and II or who have dealt with addiction to come in early during the rehearsal process and share their stories with the cast and crew in a Q&A format. By opening the door to communicate with real humans, this creates a rehearsal environment based in authenticity and vulnerability that will be key to telling Diana’s story with as much integrity as possible.The Choreographer herself has lived with a lifelong diagnosis of Bipolar II and will not only be choreographing the dance numbers, but the physical ticks and posture of our leading characters as they experience a wide range of emotions and mental states.The PlaybillRather than an ordinary playbill, Taylor Dolan will design and create a zine/booklet of statistics regarding mental health and resources to enable seeking out help in the surrounding areas. This will give the audience a tangible object to start conversations, and explore the topic once they leave the theatre.Who are we?“The ‘Next to Normal’ Project” is a part of a wholly new community theatre company blossoming in Bentonville, Arkansas. We will be working under the fiscal sponsorship umbrella of Trike Theatre, a professional children’s theatre in Bentonville.What we need?We’re very grateful to be supported by Trike Theatre and Arts Center of the Ozarks. With a mutually beneficial volunteer scheme, the members of our production have been able to trade volunteer hours in exchange for using their facilities. This has allowed us to keep down our overall costs significantly. What we are left with are the essentials for bringing this production to life, and that's what we would like to cover with this campaign.Your donation will ensure that we can:Cover liscensing feesProvide our crew with small stipendsHave a live orchestraHire videos and sound equipment. Successfully market and distribute our project.Ensure a Covid-19 safe environmentTimes are tough We understand! You’ve made it this far and so we know that you care about supporting the arts. Here are three things you can do now to support our campaign without spending a penny:Share this page with 3 friendsEngage with us on social mediaCome to auditions! https://www.facebook.com/events/4321793471178385Thank you.We are so grateful for whatever you can give. Please help us make this project that we are so passionate about.

story:
OUR STORY

The second collaboration between Lauren Hlubny (creator/director) and Thomas Giles (composer/performer), Thoughts & Prayers explores America’s relationship with tragedy, catastrophe, and loss. This new hour-long show, set to premiere in September and then begin a tour, embodies the recycled responses to the daily, dull hum of media coverage, routines of political failure, and widening gaps of partisanship and class. All of these numb our capacity to be humane.

Today, what we crave most is what we lack most in a desensitized climate: empathy. The hour-length work is a reframing of a fictitious couple’s interactions with and to five Disasters,with dramatic mixtures of music, movement, and images: a dance-theatre concerto. 

Lauren and Thomas began collaborating to create this work 1.5 years ago. Much of it was made in guerrilla-style rehearsal spaces. They would take any space they could find with any time they could spare rehearse and create the structure of this unique work.

The saxophone, when played by someone who practices as much as Thomas, can sound like almost any instrument, any vocal quality, and any thing. They quickly began including incredible musicians to workshop the music and movements, dancers and actors offering insights, and designers providing their expertise to build a new and imperfect world on the stage.

This show is not easy--all the musicians have to dance and perform fully-developed characters while playing difficult music, but using the techniques we’ve been developing over the past few years, they can do it. 

It has been an absolute whirlwind, and everyone has been donating their time, and sometimes even pooling their money to rent space. 

A 6-musician ensemble (3 woodwinds, 3 strings) embodies two distinct Greek Choruses, giving full voice to the acrimonious clashes of present-day America. The announcement of each Disaster is precipitated by a virtuosic solo movement and the narrative is supported by orchestrated structures of dialogue, physical partnering, and contrary staging.

THE TEAM 

We have an unbelievable team dedicating their strengths, sweat, and honed skills to this project. I can’t rave about them enough, and am a little star-struck every time I look around the rehearsal space (and design table) at these incredible artists who were willing to reach way out of their already lucrative comfort zones to work make this dream a reality. To see our full team, click here.

We have team members that work at Alvin Ailey, at the Met Gala, with Meredith Monk, have graduate degrees from Juilliard, are masterful improvisers, tour the world performing and creating, direct rooftop Shakespeare shows, write dialogue for television, and much more. Up to this point, we have had over 30 artists involved in the creation and development of this piece (pro-bono), and their hard work shows in every measure. 

 

WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?

With your help we will:
1. Cover basic expenses for mounting a two-week run of an original performance work in an Off-Broadway Theatre in NYC (just to have typed those words is a dream!)

2. Pay everyone on our team a small stipend for their extremely valuable time. 

(Artists can make a lot more money when they don’t take on soul-driven works like this, and we want to give them the respect they deserve)

3. Put any remaining money towards touring (we think ahead!)

 

We want to make this work accessible, and a part of that is offering a sliding scale ticket and not depending on show income to compensate our team. 

 

We know your time is valuable, and with your help we hope to start a sustainable model of funding future tours of the work using net profits from ticket sales, so that it can reach more communities without new crowdfunding campaigns each time. 

RISKS/CHALLENGES

Putting Ourselves Out There

We have paid the down payment for the theatre. This show can’t happen without you.
We’ve put a lot of our own personal money, health, intellect, creative drive, and intense emotions into developing this work, and we need your help for the last step. We are very grateful for your support and belief in us and our persistence to figure out how to make new work, make it well, and make it with an impact. Making art is scary, and asking for support and faith is even scarier...But, we can’t do it alone. 

 

How Hard the Show Is

This show, even though it is only an hour, is an absolute marathon for the performers. Each of the eight performers on stage has to act, play music, and perform movement just about the entire time. That, coupled with the intensity of a tennis-court style seating arrangement and a strong artistic vision make the work extremely detailed and difficult to perform. With the real challenges of time and expense of New York City, we are sweating our way through the summer to make this work incendiary for the audience. 

 

The Conversation 

Thoughts &Prayers is important, not only because it is being delivered by a team of first-rate artists, but because it is theatre for a cause. We are offering youth workshops. We are devoting a percentage of ticket sales to an organization (chosen with the help of our supporters) dedicated to proactive disaster support.

We are also putting money earned from the show straight towards touring, so we can commit to engaging with more communities. This is more than an art piece, it is an ongoing conversation. It’s important, but it’s a terrifying amount of work to undertake, and important to do so with thoughtfulness. 

 

The Future

We are a very small non-profit determined to make a difference, but we are working on very little money and the (wo)man-hours add up. With your help, we will be able to take the right steps to secure a future for this work and for future workshop programming dedicated to activist art paired with top-notch professional artists. 

Thank you for supporting us, it means the world to our team.

story:
Your donation will help us provide performances to the residents of New York City and beyond, commission new dance works, and continue to provide a stable job environment for our dancers and collaborators.

Your support will make our 2018/2019 season possible!

 

Not Familiar with Peridance?

Peridance Contemporary Dance Company (PCDC) was founded by Artistic Director Igal Perry in 1983 and is one of New York City's foremost repertory companies. READ MORE.

 

Share The Love!

Whether you are able to donate or not, please share our campaign! With your help, we can extend our network to many more dance lovers.

story:
WHO WE ARE

ABOUT THE PLAY: 

Relationships are hard. Mouse infestations are even harder.

Join Claire and Hugh as they balance both: expertly avoiding emotional baggage, navigating painful interactions with over-the-top exes, and concealing small furry corpses in strategic hiding places. But as the body count rises, Clare and Hugh struggle to ignore the secrets between them (that and the overpowering stench of rotting flesh). Is romance the greatest exterminator of them all? Or is this one infestation that won't be contained...

Emily and Lauren have been developing this play over the past two years with support from Exquisite Corpse Company and The Drama League. The LPAC Rough Draft Festival is the first time this play is receiving a fully designed workshop production. 

Our LPAC Rough Draft team:

Featuring: Gabby Beans, Tim Nicolai*, Lowell Byers*, & Lauren LaRocca* 

Designed by: Isabelle Coler, Kate Marvin, Carolina Ortiz, Christopher M. Thompson, & Michaela Whiting.

Production team: Brittany Crowell, Gabriela Gowdie.

(*indicates AEA)

What We Need

We just need 1,000 more dollars to reach our budget goal. These funds will directly support:

  • Artist fees for our 4 actors, scenic designer, lighting designer, sound designer, costume designer, properties designer, stage manager and production manager.
  • Additional material costs.

Although we are only able to offer a small stipend to our creative team for this process, we believe that every little bit counts in showing our appreciation and respect for their time and craft.

Any additional funding that does not go directly to the artists will be used to supplement our scenic, properties, and costume materials budget. 

Impact

This play is being developed with the goal of a longer run and world premiere production . Your support as funder, audience member, and advocate is crucial to the success of this project, now and in the future.

Thank you, and see you at the theater!

story:
Who are CellarDoor Theatre?

CellarDoor Theatre is a company run by Theatre Makers Teja Boocock, Akshay Khanna and Hiranya Griffith-Unny - along with our board of associate artists! A band of keen theatre devotees and enthusiasts, the CDT team have individually strived to create lively and entertaining theatre, and, having banded our creative minds together, we hope to create even better shows on a larger scale than anything we’ve done before.

TEJA BOOCOCK:

Teja Boocock is a meticulous young director. Her passion came early on in life, when she was tasked with directing her primary school production and put on Sarah Kane’s ‘Crave’ to an audience of bewildered parents. Critics called it ‘no comment’ and ‘what the f*ck?’, and it received a three-star review from Epigram. Since then, she has directed countless shows, including an international tour of ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ at the age of 18 (a fact she is loath to let anyone forget).

AKSHAY KHANNA:

Akshay Khanna spends most of his time (as his father so eloquently puts it) ‘twatting about on stage’ rather than living in the real world. Having recently been accepted at the Bristol Old Vic Theatre School, he is provided the prospect of theatre being a legitimate career, which is exciting for him and mildly terrifying for his family and friends. He could have been a doctor, or a lawyer, or an engineer, or a CEO, if he wasn’t so blatantly terrified of success or achieving the living wage.

HIRANYA GRIFFITH-UNNY:

Hiranya Griffith-Unny is the most boring and least edgy person we have had the misfortune of drearily sitting through a production meeting with, if we even manage to register that she’s in the room in the first place, the tedious sod. Describing Hiranya as milquetoast is singularly apt, since milk and toast are the only forms of nourishment she partakes of.  Indeed, the only thing remotely remarkable about Hiranya Griffith-Unny is her name, and it’s not like she chose it herself.  No, that would have been interesting. Wait... why do we let her design our shows again?

 

What We Need & What You Get

As you can see from our portfolio, if we are one thing - it is ambitious. And, much to our eternal regret, ambition costs - and so we reach out to the public to help us make the shows we have floating around in our heads a reality.

Whether you believe in the people behind this project, really want to see the show itself, or have a vested interest in backing something wondeful - then don’t hesitate to contribute!

The majority of donations from this platform will go towards renting the venue for the performance dates, which is a fairly large portion of the budget.  The rest will be raised independently.

Any and all contributions are most graciously accepted (though larger contributions will be accepted with EVEN MORE grace than that) and we are extremely grateful for any support we receive.

Whilst we have already raised £3000, we need to raise an additional £1000 in order to ensure that we can afford a venue for the run of the show. The money raised from your kind donations will be spent exclusively on this, giving us the remaining funds to ensure that the finished production is to the highest possible artistic standard.

 

The Impact

In this time of great economic uncertainty for the arts, the only way for young theatre companies to develop, grow and expand their artistic capabilities is with the support of an equally dedicated base of theatre lovers. CellarDoor's artists do not take a salary from their work with the group; every penny raised is invested into our productions! With your support, we can help develop the next generation of theatre makers and their work, giving people the chance to see and experience new and innovative theatre at a reasonable price. 

Bristol is a city known for its vibrant and rapidly growing artistic community. As part of this community, CellarDoor has built up a successful track record of previous sell-out productions including 2018's 'Edwards Gant's Amazing Feats of Loneliness', and 2017's productions of 'Frankenstein' and 'The Corpse Bride'. We always endeavor to bring something new to our audiences and have forged artistic partnerships with the University of Bristol, Screenology, Bristol Old Vic and more!

Risks & Challenges

As with all theatre, there is a risk that turnout may be lower than we'd like. However, unlike other campaigns, we can assure that there is no risk of your money going to waste. We will be performing 'The Tragical Tale of Doctor Faustus' in early 2019, and your money will be spent on making sure that we can free the funds we need to refine and develop other aspects of the show by ensuring that we secure a suitable venue. We've never lost money on a show, and have consistently sold out nearly all of our performances.

And that's all there is to it!

story:
What We're Doing

RemoteControl Theatre is back at the Edinburgh Fringe with our second full-length piece, Project HaHa. Once again we've been invited to perform at one of the Fringe's most exciting and acclaimed venues, Summerhall, and we can't wait to make 2015 an even bigger and better success than 2013.


RemoteControl Theatre is an all-female, international, devising theatre company out of Ecole Jacques Lecoq in Paris. We've been working together since 2012 and have been fortunate enough to perform around the world, in exciting places like Norway, Germany, China and the UK (and not to mention NYC in 2016!). We're also thrilled to have been critically recognized for our brand of bold and imaginative physical theatre. 

Ingrid, Emily, Petra and Christine have been hard at work over the last two years putting together Project HaHa, an ironic and hallucinogenic exploration of our desire to be happy now - a piece for two women, one television screen, and a voice. It's a show that's been built from what matters to us personally, what we see in the world around us, and from what the people we've met along the way have to say about happiness. It's sure to be an exciting, and as always, divisive piece. We can't wait to share it with you and with the biggest international arts festival in the world! 

What We Need 
Two years ago we asked for £5,000 in support of our first piece, La Donna è Mobile, and received over 100% of our goal! This year we've worked very hard to keep our costs to a minimum and find other sources of funding, and we've already met 90% of our budget needs. We've been fortunate enough to have support from Arts Council England, the Norwegian State Department, A Younger Theatre, and Incoming Festival in the making of Project HaHa, but we need just a little help from generous people like yourselves. With this final bit, we'll be able to properly publicize Project HaHa and employ an experienced and talented technician for its run at the festival, two things that anyone will tell you can make-or-break a show at Edinburgh. And with just 100 donors contributing £5 each, we'll make our goal!

Why It's Important

Funding for the arts is becoming less and less a priority for our governments, but we still believe in the power of theatre to change lives and inspire future generations. If you feel the same, support us and other young theatre makers, and especially, women doing it for themselves! 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute now (we get it, believe us) we would be just as thrilled if you helped spread the word about the campaign and the show. Follow us on Twitter, Vimeo, and - for old geezers like us - Facebook, to get updates about performances and the company.

What We're Doing
RemoteControl Theatre is back at the Edinburgh Fringe with our second full-length piece, Project HaHa. Once again we've been invited to perform at one of the Fringe's most exciting and acclaimed venues, Summerhall, and we can't wait to make 2015 an even bigger and better success than 2013.


RemoteControl Theatre is an all-female, international, devising theatre company out of Ecole Jacques Lecoq in Paris. We've been working together since 2012 and have been fortunate enough to perform around the world, in exciting places like Norway, Germany, China and the UK (and not to mention NYC in 2016!). We're also thrilled to have been critically recognized for our brand of bold and imaginative physical theatre. 

Ingrid, Emily, Petra and Christine have been hard at work over the last two years putting together Project HaHa, an ironic and hallucinogenic exploration of our desire to be happy now - a piece for two women, one television screen, and a voice. It's a show that's been built from what matters to us personally, what we see in the world around us, and from what the people we've met along the way have to say about happiness. It's sure to be an exciting, and as always, divisive piece. We can't wait to share it with you and with the biggest international arts festival in the world! 

What We Need 

Two years ago we asked for £5,000 in support of our first piece, La Donna è Mobile, and received over 100% of our goal! This year we've worked very hard to keep our costs to a minimum and find other sources of funding, and we've already met 90% of our budget needs. We've been fortunate enough to have support from Arts Council England, the Norwegian State Department, A Younger Theatre, and Incoming Festival in the making of Project HaHa, but we need just a little help from generous people like yourselves. With this final bit, we'll be able to properly publicize Project HaHa and employ an experienced and talented technician for its run at the festival, two things that anyone will tell you can make-or-break a show at Edinburgh. And with just 100 donors contributing £5 each, we'll make our goal!



Why It's Important
Funding for the arts is becoming less and less a priority for our governments, but we still believe in the power of theatre to change lives and inspire future generations. If you feel the same, support us and other young theatre makers, and especially, women doing it for themselves! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute now (we get it, believe us) we would be just as thrilled if you helped spread the word about the campaign and the show. Follow us on Twitter, Vimeo, and - for old geezers like us - Facebook, to get updates about performances and the company.
